Post ID:221
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-20 13:00:42
Subject:Fwd: PNN STRIKE
Message:



>From: "Carol Spooner" <wildrose@...>
>To: <Undisclosed-Recipient:;>
>Subject: PNN STRIKE
>Date: Mon, 20 Mar 2000 07:47:10 -0800
>
>The following Press Release was issued on January 31st.  We are now half 
>way
>through the strike  -- but many people still don't know about it!  Please
>visit the strikers webpage at www.savepacifica.net/strike
>If you are not hearing much about the strike on your local station
>(particularly WBAI and KPFA, which supposedly don't enforce the Pacifica
>"gag rule") then please call the station manager and the news department 
>and
>ask for more on-air information.  The strikers need our support.  Help
>spread the word!
>
>(Also, for print monthly in-depth news and opinion on the Pacifica-wide
>crisis subscribe to the FOLIO http://www.ncal.verio.com/~gde/v1n4.htm)
>
>Carol Spooner
>Committee to Remove the Pacifica Board
>wildrose@...
>http://home.pon.net/wildrose/remove.htm
>
>
>Journalists strike to battle censorship at Pacifica Radio
>
>On January 31, 2000, Pacifica Radio's top free-lance reporters and
>contributors, backed by several nationally-recognized, free-speech
>organizations, struck Pacifica's national-news program to protest on-going
>censorship at the 50-year-old community-radio network.
>
>"We believe Pacifica management seeks to intimidate and censor those who 
>try
>to report on matters that management prefers to keep quiet," said PNN
>contributor Aaron Glantz from his base in Berkeley. "Management has not 
>only
>failed to stop censoring the news, management has not even bothered to
>contact us to respond to our concerns. So we have no choice but to strike,"
>Glantz added.
>
>Dozens of journalists from across the Americas, Europe and Asia, many of
>whom have won the industry's top awards, will strike for the next three
>months unless Mary Frances Berry, who chairs both the U.S. Civil Rights
>Commission and the Pacifica Foundation, publicly renounces censorship
>throughout the network, and reasserts the editorial independence of
>Pacifica's local and national-news divisions. The striking journalists
>comprise a majority of active contributors and reporters to Pacifica 
>Network
>News, PNN, a daily, half-hour news program that airs on some 70 radio
>stations nationally. In a recent two-month period, nearly 70% of Pacifica's
>stories came from its stringers.
>
>The striking reporters delivered a signed letter one week ago outlining
>their demands to Pacifica's entire national board, including chair Mary
>Frances Berry, via certified mail, fax and e-mail. To date, there has been
>no official response from Pacifica. Several attempts by the reporters to
>reach Pacifica management--which has not released its phone number to the
>public--have been unsuccessful.
>
>Since the letter was delivered to management last Monday, additional
>stringers have joined the action, and several affiliates are considering a
>boycott of Pacifica Network News as an act of solidarity with the striking
>reporters.
>The strike is supported by the media watchdog group Fairness and Accuracy 
>in
>Reporting, Project Censored and the National Association for Freedom of
>Expression. "The survival of PNN as a reliable source of information is 
>very
>much in doubt," said syndicated media critic Norman Solomon, "this strike
>may be the last chance to make PNN something trustworthy."
>
>Pacifica has long been a bastion of free speech--from broadcasting Allen
>Ginsberg's "Howl," to defying the HUAC witch hunts, to airing the
>commentaries of death-row journalist Mumia Abu Jamal. Since the crisis last
>spring, when armed guards were called in to lock out staff at KPFA, 
>Pacifica
>reporters say management has subjected journalists, contributors and
>independent producers to repeated acts of alteration, suppression and
>censorship of news stories and public-affairs programming, which they say
>are of vital interest to the listeners of Pacifica and the broader
>communities it serves. Reporters also note that management has repeatedly
>silenced programs in mid-broadcast, and ousted signature voices such as 
>Polk
>award-winner Larry Bensky.
>
>In November, Pacifica Network News director Dan Coughlin was "removed" 
>after
>airing a story on a boycott by sixteen Pacifica affiliates over the issue 
>of
>censorship. Most recently, veteran news anchor Verna Avery-Brown, the only
>African-American national-news anchor in public broadcasting, resigned
>amidst the crisis at PNN. Brown cited, among other concerns, censorship and
>a disturbing trend away from progressive coverage in Pacifica's national
>news. The strikers are also demanding that Coughlin be reinstated.
>
>The type of direct censorship of news personnel and programming which
>Pacifica management has been engaging in throughout the network's recent
>crisis would be reprehensible at any U.S. media outlet, not just one which
>claims to present an alternative viewpoint," added former Pacifica Network
>News director and former National Public Radio producer JoAnn Kawell.
>
>Kawell, who is on the steering committee of the National Writers Union, San
>Francisco Bay Area local, appeared at a press conference for the striking
>journalists today in Berkeley. Other speakers include Peter Phillips,
>director of Project Censored; Aileen Alfandary, co-director of the KPFA 
>News
>and member of CWA Local 9415; and Matthew Lasar, author of Pacifica Radio:
>the Rise of an Alternative Network. RealAudio of the press conference |
>Aileen Alfandary's comments in text format
>
>How can you support the strike?  Go to the strikers webpage
>www.savepacifica.net/strike to find out -- spread the word!
>

Post ID:222
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-29 11:41:03
Subject:Fwd: big demo in NJ
Message:



>From: Jeanne Locicero <locicero@...>
>To: Tracey Luszcz <traceyx@...>, Matt Smith <VivaOhio@...>, 
>        kristina bas <krisbas@...>,        Shana Stein 
><punky@...>, Karen Asson <renren59@...>
>Subject: big demo in NJ
>Date: Wed, 29 Mar 2000 11:27:32 -0500
>
>Florham Pk. braces for World Bank protest
>
>From: eastcoastnet@...
>
>Hundreds of police will descend on Florham Park
>on Thursday for the start of the World Bank and
>International Monetary Fund meeting, in hopes
>of averting the kind of mayhem that erupted in
>Seattle last December.
>
>Demonstrators from national unions to local civic
>groups have said they will stage an around-the-clock
>protest through the meeting's conclusion on Saturday.
>
>Agents from the Secret Service and FBI have held
>tactical sessions with officials from the Morris County
>sheriff's and prosecutor's offices, as well as the New Jersey
>State Police and borough police. At least one more
>meeting is scheduled for today, officials said.
>
>"We're hoping people do not come to protest," Florham
>Park Mayor Barbara B. Doyle said yesterday. "We're
>encouraging people not to, but we recognize their
>right to free speech, so we will be prepared."
>
>Morris County officials did not know why Florham
>Park was chosen as the site of the meeting.
>
>The rally at the Hamilton Park Conference Center,
>advertised on several groups' Internet sites and
>through mass e-mailings, is intended to highlight
>what activists contend are poor economic
>policies imposed by the World Bank on developing
>countries.
>
>The protest is a prelude to a larger demonstration
>known as the "Festival of Resistance" set for April 16 and
>17 in Washington, D.C., organizers said.
>
>"One of the main things we want to see is debt
>cancellations for all the poor, third-world countries," said
>Carol Gay, chairwoman of New Jersey Jobs with Justice
>and a Communications Workers of America union member.
>
>The protest in Morris County comes about four months
>after tens of thousands of demonstrators converged on
>Seattle for the World Trade Organization's ministers
>meeting, which saw vandalism and violent clashes
>between police and pickets.
>
>Authorities here have not made such detailed preparations
>since last June, when a 12-hour "rave" concert was
>scheduled - and highly publicized on the Internet - at
>the Mennen Sports Arena in Morris Township. The result
>was the arrest of 80 young people and a police overtime
>bill of about $46,000 still not recovered from the promoter.
>
>Sheriff Edward V. Rochford yesterday said all 225 employees
>in his department will be on duty for the protest.
>
>Also, all 39 Morris municipalities have been told they may
>be needed to respond in case of an emergency. It is the
>first time the Morris County Regional Emergency
>Deployment System (MCREDS) has been initiated.
>
>"We're hoping for the best but preparing for the worst,"
>Rochford said. "Our policy is for restraint. We're going to
>let the protesters do whatever they want that is legal."
>
>Protest organizers - which also include the New Jersey
>Industrial Union Council, AFL-CIO and the Bergen Action
>Network - said they are planning a nonviolent display that
>will include a teach-in and large rally.
>
>"One of the legacies of Seattle is it kind of woke people up
>to their concerns of economic globalization," said
>Jim Burchell, director of Morristown-based Peace Works.
>"But one of the downsides was the violence, which was
>only a small part of what went on."
>
>The World Bank's invitation-only meeting will include speeches
>by its president, James Wolfenson, and IMF Acting Managing
>Director Stanley Fisher.
>
>"We have problems in that they're not open to the public
>and that they're not open to democracy," said Bennet D.
>Zurofsky, a Newark attorney representing the rally
>coalition free of charge.
>
>"I am quite certain there are a number of people willing
>to be arrested because of civil disobedience," he said. "I
>could see someone, for example, going up to the
>conference door and asking to present a position."
>
>Officials are ready to make arrests, if necessary. The old
>county jail is overcrowded, so authorities are prepared to
>prematurely open the new jail in Morris Township, which
>is still officially under construction.
>
>"If there is an unusual number of arrests, we'll have a
>number of Superior Court judges on call, and we'll make
>sure people get a prompt hearing wherever they are,"
>Superior Court Assignment Judge Reginald Stanton
>said yesterday.
>
>Planning continues this week for the rally, but Burchell
>said appearances by several speakers, a rap poet, the Peace
>Punk Band and the Solidarity Singers, who perform
>old union songs, are confirmed.
>
>"The unknown is what will be the turnout," said Morris County
>Prosecutor John B. Dangler.
>
>"There might be 50 people or 5,000, so we'll just be prepared
>for either case. These are not terrorists, just people with different
>opinions."
>
>Zurofsky said the demonstrators he has spoken with vowed
>to adhere to four rules at the protest: no use of alcohol or
>drugs, no weapons, no destruction of property and no use
>of physical or verbal force.
>
>"We don't believe we are trying to do anything but engage
>in peaceful and lawful demonstration," he said.
>
>Zurofsky alerted Florham Park police, Hamilton Park officials
>and the provost at Fairleigh Dickinson University, which abuts
>the conference center, in a March 13 letter.
>
>It stated: "The demonstrators want to make arrangements
>to conduct their activities . . These arrangements would
>include some sort of stage or speakers platform, sound
>equipment, electricity, (portable toilets) and probably some tents
>or other temporary shelters."
>
>Burchell said organizers would supply that equipment,
>but needed the approval of Hamilton Park officials before
>setting up.
>
>"We will make sure they have a place to park and a place
>to gather near Hamilton Park," Doyle said. "We're going
>to need to have everybody on alert and we're going to incur
>a great deal of expense because of this."
>
>
>
>Article from today's Daily Record by James A. Duffy
>

Post ID:223
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <ZNowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-03-29 20:23:00
Subject:road widening
Message:

I went to the DOT road widening meeting.  They are going to make Rt 18 a 2 lane express and 2 lane local service each way from Rte 1 to the Albany Street bridge, with the express and local lanes clearly separated from eachother, to address the accidents that have occurred, and they also have taken into account projected growth in car traffic.  This was inot coordinated with the NJ transit people - the NJ Transit basically did a service study and determined that there was not enough demand to increase service.  Of course, they didnt estimate that based on what demand would be like if the service treated people like human beigns instead of leaving them stranded at night along the highway next to a measly metal post.  

Anyway as to changeable details - looks like there will be very little noise buffering.  Also the bike paths - to be on both sides of the road, although in many places the southbound paths curve around corners at crosstreets for a block only to serpentine back again onto the main road.  The guy I talked to recognized that people will take shortcuts and just walk across the crosstreet and I said you have to build it according to the shortcuts people will take to make it safer. 

Anyway if anyone wants a copy of the plan and the comment sheet to send in let me know.

Zofia

Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405

Post ID:232
Sender:"Erric L. Zdzchowski" <erricz@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-04 14:41:11
Subject:ILOVEYOU Virus Fix I put together
Message:

Here's what you can do to fix your PC:

LOVE VIRUS FIX

1.      A. In Windows 95/98, hit CTRL+ALT+DEL and see if you have a WSCRIPT 
file running in memory.  If so, highlight it and click END TASK.
B.      If NT Server/Workstation, hit CTRL+ALT+DEL and select Task 
List.  From the Processes Tab, if you find Wscript.exe, click it and click 
End task.
C.      NOTE: If this file is not resident in memory then you can stop 
searching on this machine only, the network or other PC's may be affected.
2.      Open Internet Explorer, Click Tools, click Internet Options and 
edit the Home Page Box to your normal Home Page (i.e. www.altavista.com) on 
the General Tab
3.      Next, click START, then RUN and type regedit in the Run Box and hit 
ENTER.  This will bring up the registry editor.
4.      Once in, double-click HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE
5.      Double-click SOFTWARE
6.      Double-click MICROSOFT
7.      Double-click WINDOWS
8.      Double-click CURRENT VERSION
9.      Click RUN, find MSKernel32, right-click and select Delete
10.     Click RUNSERVICES, find Win32DLL, right-click and select Delete
11.     Now, you need to do a search on each PC and the network 
drive(s).  Login to your machine as Administrator or Admin 
equivalent.  Click START, click FIND then click FILES (OR FOLDERS).
12.     In the Named box, enter .vbs and click FIND NOW.
13.     It will search out files that end with .VBS.  You can delete any 
VBS file that is 11K in size with today's date.  If it was a .JPG file, 
then the file is completely overwritten with the virus.  If it was a .MP3 
or .MP2 file, then it made the original file a hidden file and called the 
new copy ".MP3.VBS."  The .VBS file can be deleted and the original should 
be made NOT HIDDEN by right clicking on the file, selecting Properties and 
uncheck the "Hidden" box.
14.     It also affects vbe, js, jse, css, wsh, sct, hta and jpeg in a 
similar fashion.  Again, if a .VBS file is 11K with today's date, YOU MUST 
DELETE IT BUT MAKE SURE YOU NOTE THE FILE NAME SO YOU CAN RECOVER IT FROM 
YESTERDAY'S BACKUP.

Post ID:233
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-04 15:24:36
Subject:Newark-NJ-Store Kiosk to be displayed at UniverSoul Circus
Message:


Newark-NJ-Store Kiosk to be displayed at UniverSoul Circus in Newark, May 
10-14

The Outreach Committee of the Lincoln Park-Coast Cultural District, Inc.,
presents the Newark-NJ-Stores Kiosk as a first step towards The Newark 
Endowment for the Arts


A component part of the overall renewal effort for the Lincoln Park-Coast 
Cultural District, the Newark-NJ-Store kiosk will be displayed at the 
UniverSoul Circus--the only Afro-American owned and operated circus in the 
world--during its visit to Newark from May 10-14.

The Newark-NJ-Store kiosk is a concept project whose goal is to amass and 
duplicate all products of Newark's (and NJ &c) native achievers.   For 
example, Books, Records, Memorabilia, Photos, Testimonials, will be 
commercially replicated and reproduced as stock for the store. So that a 
Newark-NJ-Store would be a Newark historical-cultural archive and 
tourist/institutional/scholarly resource, able to sell these products 
directly or by mail order to the many thousands of potential customers who 
would be interested.

Just to list a few of the potential contributors to this huge resource: 
Willie "The Lion" Smith, Sarah Vaughan, Jerry Lewis, Ed Koch, Allen 
Ginsberg, Sistah Soul Jah, Philip Roth, Stephen Crane, Whitney Houston. 
Melba Moore, Wayne Shorter, Eva Marie Saint, Joe Pesci, Savion Glover, 
Nathan Beard, Claude Brown, James Moody, &c &c.


A NEWARK ENDOWMENT FOR ART, CULTURE, HUMANITIES

The most profound aspect of the Newark-NJ-Store is that by getting 
agreements from the kind of contributors mentioned above, we can also get 
these important people to contribute the same kinds of materials and revenue 
and projections, of regular appearances for benefits, &c to become 
contributors to an OVERALL ARCHIVE which will be the Value Base for the 
establishment of an Endowment, which can not only serve as a basic revenue 
engine for the development of the Lincoln Park Coast Cultural District, but 
as the material foundation for the completely innovative creation of a 
municipal endowment for the Arts, Culture, Humanities in the city of Newark, 
independent of outside philanthropy, but at the same time Enhancing and 
giving prestigious embellishment for Grant Proposals that LPCCD or any arts, 
culture, humanities project generated throughout the city.

The Newark-NJ-Store Kiosk was initially unveiled to a limited audience at 
the Newark Symphony Hall for the LPCCD Gala and Dance February 25, 2000.  
Here the concept received enthusiastic support from many in Newark's 
cultural, political, and business communities.  It has since been on display 
at the NJ School of Architecture at NJIT for a conference recently held 
there by LPCCD.  The installation at the UniverSoul Circus will be the first 
time the Newark-NJ-Store Kiosk will be opened up to a wider public audience 
in Newark.

Contact Matthew Smith
(973) 372-7130
vivaohio@...

>The White House

>Dear President Clinton:
>
>We are writing to convey our deep concern over reports that the Federal
>government is working on a plan to remove the protesters - by force if
>necessary - from their site on the island of Vieques, Puerto Rico. Use of
>force in this situation, with its potential for loss of life and the
>ensuing disruption to the fabric of civil society in Puerto Rico, would
>work to prevent a just resolution of this crisis.
>
>Thousands of people throughout Puerto Rico and the United States have
>already pledged to support the protesters should they be arrested and/or
>forcibly removed. Notwithstanding the sudden decision of the Governor of
>Puerto Rico to allow continued bombing of Vieques, there is no popular
>support for Navy presence in Vieques, and widespread actions of civil
>disobedience would seem inevitable.
>
>Vieques residents - United States citizens - have suffered fifty years of
>naval bombardment and amphibious assault drills by the Atlantic Fleet
>Weapon Training Force (A.F.W.T.F.). Enormous damage has been done to the
>island and its residents in consequence, and Puerto Ricans and their
>supporters in the United States are justly outraged at the notion of
>continued Naval presence. Coral reefs have been pulverized, the aquifer
>has been contaminated with chemicals, hundred of acres of tropical
>hardwood forests have been deforested, and endangered species have been
>destroyed. The islands' population has also been contaminated with
>excessive levels of dangerous chemicals associated with the military
>operations including lead, cadmium, arsenic and uranium: The island has
>the highest mortality rate in Puerto Rico, and the highest rates of cancer
>An innocent civilian was recently killed outright as a result of Naval
>presence on the island.
>
>The Puerto Rican people have made it clear that they will no longer accept
>use of uranium weaponry by the Navy, which is illegal and which violates
>the Navy's licensing agreement with the government of Puerto Rico.
>Similarly, the Navy's practice of renting the Island of Vieques to foreign
>governments cannot be justified as a national security necessity.
>
>This situation clearly requires delicacy and tact. Surely the national
>security of the United States should not come at the expense of a
>colonized people. We join with the people of Puerto Rico in the justice of
>their cause, and call on this administration to work harder to find a fair
>resolution to what will otherwise become an even more difficult conflict.

>propose a joint meeting to discuss this matter further. Please contact

Post ID:236
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-07 17:29:52
Subject:Cafes, Starbucks, Redevelopment issues: Right to know?
Message:

I was talking to a friend last night about the Campaign, and we started
talking about redevelopment issues, corporatization, and big business vs.
small business in NB. It turns out that a little over a year ago, he had
set out to open a cafe in the city, on Elm Street. Considering that 4-5
cafes had closed in the city in the last few years (but had generally been
popular), he saw a market as an individual businessperson for an
alternative to Starbucks. 

However, he met *serious* delays when attempting to wend his way through
city bureaucracy. Zoning applications and questions which should have
taken weeks to answer instead took months, or were never answered at all,
as when he asked about the likelihood of demolition on Elm Street for
DevCo-sponsored redevelopment projects. He met with so many delays and so
much resistance from city officials that after over a year of attempting
to make it work, he gave up the project. 

He connected this to Starbucks' influence with the city. Apparently, a few
years ago, the health food and vitamin store in Kilmer Square, Back to
Nature, was located at the George/Albany corner. A chain store came in and
bought out the store, which they kept open, but moved several doors down
in Kilmer Square. At the time, it was apparently heavily suspected that
the city was encouraging the buyout of Back to Nature (against the
original wishes of the store owner) in order to ensure the freeing-up of
the valuable real estate at George and Albany. Starbucks soon moved in,
and since then, 4-5 cafes have closed, and while attempting to ease
Starbucks' way in any way possible, city officials have repeatedly
hampered individuals attempting to open cafes and similar businesses
without the backing of a large corporation like Starbucks (which, in
addition, is a "brand" which labels its homes as cities of upper-class
prestige). 

My friend compared this to the persistent rumors of city involvement in
planting drugs at Indigo Jones, attempting to force Earthcore out of the
city, and attempting to force Quantum X Music out. While the city says it
wants investment, these examples seem to show it wants investment *only*
from the biggest of big corporations, and not from independent
residents...

Anyone know more about this?

Charlotte

Post ID:237
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-08 09:42:37
Subject:Corporate subsidies
Message:


Poverty & Race Research Action Council 


March/April, 2000 
Race, Poverty & Corporate Welfare
HI folks,

Im on a great listserve re:  corporate subsidies, by Good Jobs First.  To subscribe, write to:  goodjobs@... 

by Greg LeRoy
The last two decades have seen an explosion in the number and value of state and local "business incentives" enacted in the name of economic development. Often, these subsidies are promoted as a way to alleviate poverty or reverse urban decline. 
However, many such programs have become so deregulated that their original targeting intentions have been subverted. Some very disturbing evidence is now emerging that instead of reducing poverty or discrimination, taxpayer money some call "corporate welfare" is actually subsidizing poverty and fueling racial inequality. 
While the evidence is disturbing, news from the organizing front lines is heartening. Armed with breakthrough disclosure data and a trickle of foundation support, a small but determined network of non-profit groups is aggressively rewriting the policy dialog about development. Coalescing with many diverse movements, these groups are winning dozens of accountability precedents. Their breakthroughs suggest that "back to basics" * raising workers* living standards * is winning the day. 
Development Subsidies: Mushrooming and Loose
It*s not possible to place a dollar figure on state and local spending for development, because very few states report development budgets that combine spending in both appropriations and the tax code. Even fewer have centralized records about local property tax abatements. 
But the spending trend is undeniably up. Twenty years ago, only 21 states granted corporate income-tax credits; today, 37 do. Then, only nine states granted tax credits for research and development; today, 36 allow them. Only 20 states provided low-interest, tax-exempt bond financing; today, 44 provide it. 
It*s not at all unusual now to find deals worth more than $100,000 per job; five of our "Terrible Ten Candy Store Deals of 1998" exceeded that price * including one at $8.8 million per job! 
If such spending benefitted needy workers, perhaps it could be justified. But many such programs have become so deregulated as to moot anti-poverty intentions. For example, Louisiana, Arkansas and Ohio now have a total of 2,360 enterprise zones. Turning an anti-blight program into a "gimme" cancels the original targeting intent. 
Other subsidies undermine public services critical to equal opportunity. For example, the Louisiana Coalition for Tax Justice found that the state*s industrial property tax exemptions for the 1980s cost schools $941 million. Louisiana has one of the nation*s lowest high school graduation rates. (Almost three-fourths of the projects created no new jobs!)
So the boom in development spending not only is poorly targeted but is extremely expensive. The bottom line: real wages for average working people have declined about 15% since the late 1970s, and the share of working poor has increased by 5%. How could so much be spent for such bad results? The answer: most development subsidies still lack basic safeguards, such as real targeting, wage floors, employer-paid health care or full-time work requirements.
Job Subsidies and Equal Opportunity
There is also a small but disturbing body of evidence that development subsidies are being used by employers with discriminatory employment practices or by industries that are moving good jobs away from people of color. 
For example, a 1984 analysis of industrial revenue bonds (IRBs * low-interest loans supported by tax-free bonds) by the Illinois Advisory Committee to the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights found an adverse effect on workers and minority entrepreneurs. They examined 104 IRBs in the Chicago area. In fully one-fifth of the deals, either the recipient company or the bank that bought the bonds had recently violated the federal fair employment rules of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. 
The study also found that only three IRBs went to African Amer*ican-owned firms, one to an Asian-owned firm, and none to Hispanic-owned firms. At one-third of the companies, Black workers were far underrepresented compared to the area*s overall labor market. Two-thirds of the companies also had disproportionately small Hispanic employment, and more than half had disproportionately small female workforces. 
The auto industry presents a troubling multi-state story. Since the mid-1980s, there have been massive auto investments in the U.S. by foreign car makers, especially Japanese firms, building more than 300 plants. Virtually all received multiple state and local development subsidies. This new "auto belt" is concentrated in Kentucky, Tennessee, southern Indiana and Ohio, South Carolina and Alabama, far away from traditional metal-working cities such as Detroit and Cleveland with large minority workforces. A 1988 study by University of Michigan professors Robert Cole and Donald Deskins on three early assembly "transplants" (Honda, Nissan and Mazda) and 51 Japanese parts plants or "subplants" found that African-American workers were significantly underrepresented at almost all of the 54 plants. 
A few transplants have been charged with discriminatory practices, such as defining recruitment territories that excluded urban areas with minority populations. Cole and Deskins found that Blacks comprised 2.8% of Honda*s Marysville, Ohio workforce, although they made up 10.5% of that area*s available workforce.
The Woodstock Institute examined the geographic distribution of Small Business Administration loan guarantees in the Chicago area. It found that higher-income and outlying zip codes received more loans than lower-income and closer-in areas. Several studies have found that incentives such as IRBs, intended to benefit distressed areas, are used more often by prosperous jurisdictions.
Sprawl: A New Analytical Wedge
Although urban sprawl is often viewed as a suburban quality of life issue driven by environmentalists, there is a social equity wing of the smart growth debate focusing on race [see john powell*s article in the Sept./Oct. 1999 P&R, "Achieving Racial Justice: What*s Sprawl Got to Do With It?"] That wing views the new "metropolitics" as a way for advocates of traditional equity causes such as community reinvestment, affordable housing and fair employment to frame their work as part of a regional solution. 
A new study by Good Jobs First links development subsidies to sprawl and concludes that taxpayer-financed corporate migrations are harming people of color in the Twin Cities. The study, "Another Way Sprawl Happens," analyzes 29 companies with 1,600 jobs that relocated to a 300-acre industrial park in the distant suburb of Anoka, which gave the companies free land valued at more than $7.5 million. 
The net result of the subsidized relocations was to move the jobs away from the region*s largest concentrations of people of color, away from pockets of poverty and away from households receiving public assistance. The migrations also had a devastating effect on transit accessibility. Before the relocations, more than 70% of the jobs were accessible by regularly scheduled transit. In the Anoka Park, they are no longer accessible. 
This movement will especially harm inner-city workers, who are more likely to rely on public transportation. Only 40% of Black households in the Twin Cities region owned a vehicle in 1990. A report on the region found that 50% of the region*s employment growth will occur in the outer-ring developing area where nearly half the projects are inaccessible by transit. Many studies have shown that decentralization of employment from central city to suburban locations has disproportionately harmed minority and low-income workers because they face barriers finding housing in the suburbs.
A few journalists have made the subsidy-sprawl link. A 1995 Kansas City Star series cited several prosperous suburbs giving tax breaks to companies leaving depressed core areas. The paper found the deals particularly galling because the tools being used by the wealthy suburbs were originally intended to help central cities. "Created to combat sprawl, tax breaks now subsidize it," the Star concluded. A 1999 Milwaukee Journal Sentinel series cited a mutual fund company in suburban Menomenee Falls which received a $3 million tax credit, justified because it is "close to Milwaukee County, which continues to have higher unemployment than the state average." A state senator commented: "[I]t*s essentially a government subsidy to promote sprawl."
Disclosure and Accountability: Hope on the Horizon
As mentioned above, a small but growing network of grassroots groups is working to rewrite the policy dialog about development. Building coalitions of organized labor, consumer, religious and civic groups, and living wage campaigns, these groups are literally redefining economic development.
The Minnesota Alliance for Progressive Action (MAPA) won the nation*s first comprehensive subsidy disclosure law in 1995. It requires annual, company-specific reports on job creation and wages. The data enabled Good Jobs First to analyze 525 deals and identify 38 deals valued at $100,000 or more per job. Despite such high subsidies, 65% of the subsidized companies were paying wages so low that a family of three would still qualify for Medicaid and 25% would still qualify for Food Stamps. Armed with these findings, MAPA won major reforms, including mandatory wage standards. 
The Maine Citizens Leadership Fund and the Maine Center for Economic Policy helped win disclosure in that state in 1997; the data are being analyzed by the Cambridge-based Commonwealth Institute. Among the key findings: 27% of the subsidized jobs pay wages below a living-wage benchmark tied to the federal poverty line, prompting a reform debate. 
The Los Angeles Alliance for a New Economy, the nation*s largest local subsidy-accountability project, analyzed that city*s biggest redevelopment deals of the 1990*s. It found that low-wage retail deals got 65% of the subsidies, and that 55% of those retail jobs paid less than $8 an hour, so little that a family of three would still qualify for public assistance.
Such pioneering efforts are moving the public debate. As Good Jobs First recently documented, at least 36 states, 26 cities and five counties now attach job quality standards such as wage rules, health care requirements and full-time hours to development subsidies * an eleven-fold increase since 1994!
Greg LeRoy (goodjobs@...) directs Good Jobs First, a project of the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy (1311 L St. NW, Wash., DC 20005; 202/737-4315; www.goodjobsfirst.org. He is author of No More Candy Store: States and Cities Making Job Subsidies Accountable, published by ITEP, and 1998 winner of the Public Interest Pioneer Award of the Stern Family Fund. All of the Good Jobs First studies mentioned in the article are on their website and available (free) from the author. 
Back to Top

Generally, this analysis seems to be on target. The city's Master
Development Plan (yes there is one and it's in print) calls for
the restructuring of the city economy along, government,university,
hospital health care, and entertainment economies. If you're
not in, you don't win --especially if you lack economic standing
to participate. this is generally how cities are reorienting
themselves in the face of corporate globalization as deindustrialization
surrounds us. Cities such as New Brunswick want economies that
cater to tourists, not vagabonds.

I think the Starbuck is a bit off the mark though. Back to the
Garden did want to move, as I understand it; it was too expensive.
The bigger rumor is that DevCo subsidized the franchise to the
tune of $50,000 initially, if not continuing ot this date. Clearly,
given the "big-ticket" nature of corporate entities being wooded
to town --along with the plan to import a "gent-tocracy" we see
where the city is supposedly heading. New Brunswick, with is
central location and transportation infrastructure, is seen as
a commuter town for New York workers. It is clearly distinct
from Red Bank, a good town for comparison.

Also, as for looking at the spatial and physical infractructure
of the town, consider this: if it's pre-World War II, it's a
good candidate for demolition, and demolition will take lace
along the city's main roads, for "improvement" in a Potemkin-like
fashion. 

Regarding books on this matter, see, Mike Davis' "City of Quartz"
and Paul Knox "Urbanization" (a text used at Rutgers).

--BV

Post ID:242
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-08 14:10:42
Subject:Rent Levelling Board
Message:

Chairperson:  Patricia Lambe
Board - 5 people, appointed by the mayor

Rent Contral Ordinance:

Allows for annual rent increases up to the level of Consumer Price Index for all urban consumers (a Federal, not local metropolitan-based index) (2000 - 4.3%)
 
Other municipalities use a flat rate, say 3 or 4 % that may be .5% higher if heat is included in rent.

No application is necessary for annual permitted rent increase.

However, increases during vacancies require application and approval by the board, and landlords are subject to compliance with the inspection code  There is no limit on increases at that time.  In May 1989, vacancy decontral was eliminated.  It capped  those increases to 15%.

The landlord is also allowed to charge a hardship surcharge based on loss for a given year, and must show books.  There is a capital improvement surcharge permitted for added benefits to renters that is based on the beneficial life of an improvement, prorated over years.   Finally, there is an insurance surcharge that is rarely if ever used - if insurance exceeds 110% of prior years cost. These surcharges must be approved by the board.

Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute

New York, NY 10018

Post ID:245
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-09 17:15:00
Subject:CONVENTION SCHEDULE
Message:

My concern is with the platform.  As a member of the right to know committee I took a look at the initial draft, and it will be posted in a more final form.  The elaborations on each point go into slightly more detail than our newspaper, but just enough to require more refinement than we have the capability for at this time.  As just one example, if we put forth a vote that the city should pay for more public bus service when in fact the county and state take care of most of the bus action, we will just look plain stupid.  The last thing we want to do is to bankrupt the city - lets get as much action from the feds, state, and county.  Ideally RTK would have had more time to at least review and investigate the sense of the platform points - then allow the debate to occur around direction of the platform without having to deal with lack of info clarity at the same time.  I am concerned that we are developing a platform that 1 is not informed adequately and 2. we will not have the time to have a real debate on it.  For many people, this will be thier first intro to the campaign, and I agree we dont want to torture people too much all at once.  Perhaps we should just stick addressing the major points at the convention, especially since there is no provision (because understandably there is no time) for a real debate.  One way to go would be to vote on the general provisions and take recommendations/input around each one, write it up on a board.  This would allow for a great participation process. Then set up committees on each point (RTK has been too strapped to address each one separately) to research it, look into the recommendations made at the convention, and  the entire next meeting could be spent on developing our platform basedon the recommendations of each committee.  Perhaps voting on the candidates, general tenets of the campaign and organization is enough for one day.

Post ID:246
Sender:"Charlotte L. Kates" <ckates@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-09 18:06:56
Subject:Re: [nbpeoplescampaign] CONVENTION SCHEDULE
Message:

However, if we do this, we are not holding to the principle of the
convention as highest authority, it seems. The votes at the convention
become more or less suggestions for feasibility studies. Since the votes
at the convention, it seems, will be pretty general: eg "The People's
Campaign ticket will work to ensure that more publicly funded bus service
is provided to service all of the people of New Brunswick, encourage the
development of a truly extensive mass transit system and enable those
without cars to reach jobs and other destinations adequately", rather than
"The city will pay for more buses," this, IMO, won't be a major problem.
Certainly, after the convention, detailed positions on each point of the
platform must be developed. However, at the convention itself we should
proceed with the voting on program points with specific solutions at city
(and higher) levels where we are aware of the existence of such solutions. 

Right to Know is an essential committee of the campaign, which has done
excellent work so far, and I'm sure will be the source of much of those
position papers on platform planks. However, it doesn't have to clear
every program suggestion--and in fact, it can't, since additions and
deletions from the floor are open at the convention. In most general
political platforms of the kind we're discussing, there isn't a great deal
of specifics, except on certain key points, on how legislation or what
legislation is to be passed through what method, and how funding is to be
found--that's where position papers, etc. come in. The votes at the
convention for platform planks, it seems, will be quite general--there
won't be time for more--and after the convention, position papers can be
developed by all interested people to be voted on as accurate
representations of the campaign's platform at general meetings. This would
ensure the convention remains the highest authority of the convention,
while assuring correct specifics and plans. 

--charlotte

Post ID:248
Sender:xavier.hansen@...
Post Date/Time:2000-05-10 11:31:14
Subject:About the Convention
Message:

Speaking for myself, not the Steering Committee, I want 
to make the following points:

1) I am glad to see the impassioned interest of all 
brothers and sisters in the People's Campaign. Struggle 
is a healthy sign of life for our movement. Our 
challenge is to carry out this struggle for the greater 
unity of the people of New Brunswick.

2)  The Steering Committee only found out last Monday 
(after the last General Meeting) that Amiri Baraka was 
available to speak at the Convention. We also invited 
significant New Brunswick opposition candidates of past 
elections such as James Neal, Dave Harris and Seth 
Grodofsky. We have not yet received a definite 
confirmation from any of them at this time. However, if 
any of them comes to the Convention and wishes to speak 
and endorse the People's Campaign, we should welcome 
them to do so. The Latino brothers whom we met on Sunday 
night (again, after the General Meeting) also asked to 
have a speaker at the Convention. 
 
3)  We invited Amiri Baraka because in 1968, 1970, and 
1972, he led a independent grassroots People's 
Convention movement in Newark that ACTUALLY WON the 
elections and defeated the corrupt and viciously racist 
political machine of Newark Mayor Addonizzio -a machine 
far more powerful than the one we face today in New 
Brunswick. The Newark People's Convention movement 
united revolutionary organizations, neighborhood groups, 
businesses and churches from the Afro-American and 
Puertoriqueno communities and grew to such national 
prominence that Stevie Wonder, Dustin Hoffman, Sun Ra 
and Bill Cosby among others came to Newark to campaign 
for it. The victory in Newark had such an impact 
nationwide that Amiri Baraka was asked to chair the 
National Black Assembly in Gary Indiana in 1972 with 
14,000 delegates from all across the country. If these 
concrete accomplishments, directly related to our 
campaign today, do not qualify him to speak in someone's 
view, they should raise opposition at the People's 
Convention and a vote can settle the issue. 

3)  Despite all its amateurish shortcomings (we are all 
new at this and our resources are still meager), the New 
Brunswick People's Campaign is without a doubt the most 
democratic people�s campaign in the entire country. No 
other movement seeks to unite such a broad array of 
people (and classes) in a difficult struggle for 
political power (not a mere protest) and holds monthly 
meetings where the entire campaign, including the 
leadership, can be changed by a majority vote. We 
elected a leadership because we cannot vote on every 
decision. We debated and voted on so many important 
points at the last General Meeting that we ran out of 
time to discuss even the rules of debate and voting 
procedures for the Convention, which, in my view, are of 
great significance. That is part of the reality of our 
struggle. With a professional, full-time staff and years 
of experience in electoral politics, we would (and I 
hope we will in the future) run a much more efficient 
campaign involving many, many more people from the very 
beginning at a much higher level of political 
consciousness. In the meantime, our critical task is to 
struggle for unity at the historic first New Brunswick 
People's Convention where many inspired residents will 
join in a political campaign for the very first time. 
And we must get clear about the challenge at hand: many 
people coming this Saturday are still unclear about what 
a City Council is!   

In unity, 

X.

Subject:Re: Important campaign issues, was : Amiri Baraka's speech
Message:

Charlotte, and everyone else,

Have you followed the discussion on the NJFO mailing list re: "who is the
working class?"  I feel it is a serious mistake, tactically and
ideologically, to exclude and alienate the middle class, both by putting
such fictitious and arbitrary labels as "petty bourgeoisie" on them and by
effectively ignoring them in organizing efforts.  As I discussed with Brian,
this poses several issues -- the establishment is certainly going to do
everything in their power to organize the middle class AGAINST the People's
Campaign.  If we have not, by then, done something to pre-empt this effort,
it will be remarkably easy to turn out the middle class voters against the
People's Campaign.  NJFO organizers complain that middle class people are
not receptive.  I have an entirely different experience.  I suspect that
they simply do not understand how to communicate with middle class folk.
The decision to expend very little effort to further this goal reflects a
failure of our leadership.

Furthermore, while Frank is on the campaign, and his valiant efforts to
conscript Republicans onto the People's Campaign are commendable, they have
been unwittingly thwarted by failing to account for the necessary
concessions of a united front.  The entire concept of a united front is to
organize around a common agenda that can be sold to all those you wish to
participate.  Thinly veiled -- or even explicit -- affronts against
political moderates are not uncommon on the Campaign mailing list, and the
idiotic discussion between Cliff and Xavier two meetings ago on the
viability of "seizing power without a revolution", among other examples of
childish role-playing of "revolutionary" roles served to alienate a good
portion of people who could have offered a significant contribution to the
campaign.  NJFO would do well to stop playing self-important faux guerillas
and acknowledge the fact that you are not revolutionaries or Red Army
officers, but activists.  While I'm sure some of you would love to see a red
flag flying over New Brunswick and secret police dutifully seeking out those
failing to adhere to 'the correct ideas', revolution is not going to happen
in New Brunswick.  The possibility for real social change is there, but you
have to let go of your pipe dreams and be a little more practical.  

You can scream "united front" until you turn purple, but until you start
acting like you want to unite people around a common platform, and STOP
pushing the "maximum program", at least for the next six months, the
establishment is going to use that as a very potent weapon to get people out
to vote AGAINST the campaign.  To use Brian's example, what do you think the
old Hungarian woman is going to do when the phone banks are in full
operation on election day, telling her to go out there and vote for the
Democrats because "Communists are trying to take over New Brunswick"?

I am sending this out to the list.  I feel it is important and I would like
to hear everyone's thoughts on the issue.

Chris Kozlowski

Post ID:253
Sender:xavier.hansen@...
Post Date/Time:2000-05-10 20:01:20
Subject:DRAFT PROGRAM
Message:

From the Steering Committee:

Here is the draft version of the political program which 
will be voted at the New Brunswick People's Convention. 
It has not yet been laid out in order of importance as 
determined by the surveys. 600 surveys have already been 
typed in, and the program should be ordered accordingly 
when it is distributed on Saturday. We will also need a 
final hustle to get all the literature translated in 
Spanish. If anyone can help, please e-mail me.

On Saturday, we will discuss and take amendments to the 
program before voting on it as a whole. I want to 
encourage everyone to see this most important document 
as the basis of a broad political unity of the people of 
New Brunswick. No program can satisfy all of everyone's 
wishes. We must struggle to improve and finalize the 
draft so that it is clearly grasped and supported by 
everyone at the Convention. This program, already 
disucssed and supported and by over one thousand 
residents, must inspire the great majority of the people 
of New Brunswick so that they will struggle for it and 
for the People's Campaign candidates to win in November.

In unity, 

X.

********************DRAFT PROGRAM FOR THE PEOPLE�S 
CONVENTION

1)  COMMUNITY CONTROL OVER THE POLICE

WHAT NEW BRUNSWICK WANTS: The people must control the 
police to make sure that the police protects and serves 
the people. 

WHAT WE WILL DO: Establish a democratically-elected All-
Civilian Police Review Board with subpoena power to 
investigate police misconduct and crime, and the power 
to hire and fire officers.  

2)  COMMUNITY CONTROL OVER EDUCATION

WHAT NEW BRUNSWICK WANTS: The people must control the 
schools to ensure a better future for their children and 
the whole next generation. 

WHAT WE WILL DO: Establish an elected Board of Education 
which will also allow the people to vote on the annual 
school budget. Join the statewide struggle to move 
school board elections to November and to claim the 
millions of dollars in state funds constitutionally owed 
to New Brunswick as determined by the New Jersey Supreme 
Court in Abbot v. Burke.

3)  COMMUNITY CONTROL OVER  REDEVELOPMENT 

WHAT NEW BRUNSWICK WANTS: The people must control the 
neighborhoods in which they live.

WHAT WE WILL DO: Establish an elected Planning Board, 
Zoning Board and an Elected Development Council for New 
Brunswick, with their decisions subject to review by the 
city council. Hold referenda for any large scale 
development project in the city which the city helps 
through tax abatements or the use of its redevelopment 
and condemnation powers.

4)  JOBS FOR ALL NEW BRUNSWICK RESIDENTS

WHAT NEW BRUNSWICK WANTS: A secure union job at a fair 
wage for every resident in the city. 

WHAT WE WILL DO: Provide city contracts and tax credits 
only to companies that will hire existing residents 
first and train residents in specialized fields if no 
qualified resident can be found for a specific job. 
Provide and demand equal pay for equal work.

5)  CHILDCARE FOR ALL NEW BRUNSWICK RESIDENTS

WHAT NEW BRUNSWICK WANTS: Provide publicly controlled, 
subsidized (based on ability to pay) child care for 
every child in the city.  

WHAT WE WILL DO: Establish city-led public/private 
partnership with existing child care providers and 
Rutgers Child Development Program. Join statewide 
struggle for Pre-school funds legally and 
constitutionally owed to New Brunswick as mandated by 
the State.

6)  HEALTH CARE FOR ALL NEW BRUNSWICK RESIDENTS

WHAT NEW BRUNSWICK WANTS: preventative care and coverage 
for all residents (based on ability to pay).

WHAT WE WILL DO: Negotiate with hospitals in the city to 
provide heath care services for all residents as a 
condition for any future expansion in the city. Increase 
staff and services at existing city clinics like the 
Chandler Clinic. 

7)  RENT CONTROL AND SAFE AND DECENT PUBLIC HOUSING

WHAT NEW BRUNSWICK WANTS: Affordable, safe and adequate 
housing for all tenants making New Brunswick their home.

WHAT WE WILL DO: Pass rent control legislation to stop 
all rent increases except those necessary to preserve a 
fair rate of return for landlords' investments, such as 
to cover repairs and improvements to building by the 
owner, requiring the approval of a democratically-
elected Rent Control Board and never to exceed cost of 
living increase for that year. Rent control to apply 
whether or not tenants remain from year to year.

8)  A WOMEN�S CENTER: A publicly-funded Women's Center, 
democratically controlled by the women of New Brunswick.

WHAT NEW BRUNSWICK WANTS: 

WHAT WE WILL DO: Establish a publicly-funded Women�s 
Center, democratically controlled by the women of New 
Brunswick to provide social, cultural and political 
services for the women of New Brunswick (especially 
single mothers and their children) such as job training 
and referrals, child care, continuing education, 
counseling, voter registration, etc. 

9)  IMMIGRANT RIGHTS AND SERVICES

WHAT NEW BRUNSWICK WANTS: Fairness and equality for all 
residents, whether citizens or not.

WHAT WE WILL DO: Uphold equal rights for all New 
Brunswick residents. Provide citywide bilingual language 
classes and legal assistance in language of origin to 
secure safe immigration status for residents. Join 
nationwide struggle for immigrant voting rights and 
amnesty.    

10)  INCREASED SERVICES FOR ALL NEW BRUNSWICK SENIORS
 
WHAT NEW BRUNSWICK WANTS: Equal access to public 
services and quality of life for senior residents. 
 
WHAT WE WILL DO: Reduce city taxes (property taxes, 
sewage, water, etc.) for all residents, joining the 
statewide struggle for enhanced tax relief for seniors. 
Provide equal services and equal access to public 
facilities for all seniors. Form joint partnership with 
Rutgers University Community Service program (CASE) and 
local churches to increase volunteer service to city 
seniors.
 
11)  IMPROVED PUBLIC TRANSIT AND BIKE PATHS

WHAT NEW BRUNSWICK WANTS: Better transportation 
solutions to help people move easily around the Hub City.

WHAT WE WILL DO: Increase city bus services. Schedule 
stops directly at all major housing complexes in the 
city. Establish safe bike paths on all major city roads. 

12)  PROPERTY TAX RELIEF FOR HOMEOWNERS
 
WHAT NEW BRUNSWICK WANTS: A lower property tax rate for 
all residents to give relief to middle-class and working-
class homeowners. 

WHAT WE WILL DO: Reduce property taxes by eliminating 
waste and inefficiency in city government, and 
abolishing tax credits and abatements for corporate 
developers and companies that do not mainly employ or 
house New Brunswick residents. Reassess value of all 
corporate properties to ensure big business pays its 
fair share of taxes.
  
13)  AID FOR NEW BRUNSWICK�S SMALL BUSINESSES
 
WHAT NEW BRUNSWICK WANTS: Help the community of 
entrepreneurs and small businesspersons continue to 
thrive within our city.

WHAT WE WILL DO: Assist existing small business and 
encourage development of new small business owned by New 
Brunswick residents and employing New Brunswick 
residents. Provide tax credits for improvement to 
property and additional hiring of city residents.
 
14)  COLLEGE FOR ALL NEW BRUNSWICK GRADUATES

WHAT NEW BRUNSWICK WANTS: Access to higher education for 
all city youth.

WHAT WE WILL DO: Negotiate with Rutgers University, as a 
condition any city assistance with plans for expansion, 
new buildings, or new programs in the city, to provide 
open admissions and free college education to all New 
Brunswick High School graduates.
 
15)  ACTIVITIES FOR ALL NEW BRUNSWICK YOUTH

WHAT NEW BRUNSWICK WANTS: Enhance social, political, and 
learning opportunities for teens and young adults.

WHAT WE WILL DO: Rebuild a teen center entirely 
dedicated to teen programs and not occupied by other 
city agencies. Organize Community Service program to 
recruit Rutgers student volunteers for  cultural, 
educational and technological youth programs in school 
buildings after school hours.   
 
16) CULTURAL ACTIVITIES FOR ALL NEW BRUNSWICK RESIDENTS

WHAT NEW BRUNSWICK WANTS: Increase opportunities for 
higher education for all city youth.

WHAT WE WILL DO: Organize free city-sponsored cultural 
programs to reflect all the diverse communities of New 
Brunswick. Negotiate with local theaters and dance clubs 
to provide weekly affordable entertainment for New 
Brunswick residents (gospel, salsa, hip hop, merengue, 
R&B, etc.) Use school buildings as cultural centers for 
continuing education every evening.   

17)  OPEN GOVERNMENT WITH OPEN BOOKS

WHAT NEW BRUNSWICK WANTS: Complete accountability for 
every city employee and every city official, from top to 
bottom.

WHAT WE WILL DO: Hold all government meetings in public 
(unless in violation of individual privacy rights). Pass 
a local Freedom of Information ordinance that will 
provide public access to all information on city and 
school spending and the activities of all corporate 
partnerships with the city government and provide open 
access to all government documents.

Post ID:255
Sender:"kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-10 21:19:58
Subject:People's Convention this Saturday
Message:

Hello!

I am writing to let you know that this Saturday is the first Convention of 
the People's Campaign for New Brunswick City Council.  You are very welcome 
to attend. For those of you who may not know much about this historic event, 
I want to offer a brief background:

This November, 3 seats will open on the New Brunswick City Council. These 
seats constitute the majority of the Council, which consists of 5 seats 
total. In December 1999, NJFO (the New Jersey Freedom Organization) 
initiated the proposal that those community/student/religious/labor 
organizations that are in opposition to the parasitic Democratic Cahill 
machine get together to form a BROAD-based grass roots coalition. The 
purpose of this coalition would be to develop a united progressive political 
platform that would counter the current trends toward destruction and 
inequality in the city, and to run three community residents as candidates 
for these open seats.

After several planning meetings attended by some 20 or 30 activists and 
community members, this united front was formally adopted as "the New 
Brunswick People's Campaign".

"The Question of Revolution is the Seizure of Power". We say these words yet 
we don't really understand what that means. As Amiri Baraka puts so well 
"you want to make a revolution but you can't even elect a dog catcher". This 
campaign is our attempt to put the idea of seizing power (on a local level) 
into practice - that is, once the community elects three of its own to the 
City Council, and wins the majority, it has made the first giant step 
towards claiming control over the city.

We are taking the demands for Women's Centers/Jobs at a living 
wage/community control over the police/community control over redevelopment 
out of the sphere of mere protesting and rhetoric. If we seize power on the 
council, these demands can become realities. If we seize power on the 
council, we can begin to foster a real cultural renaissance in this City: it 
will be the culture of working people, not Starbucks.

This is hard to imagine, I know. But I for one am through with the draining 
and often fruitless protesting mode of the past. I want to dedicate my time 
to building an alternative to the death machine that is turning this City 
inside out.

If we win this Campaign, it will provide a groundbreaking example to cities 
across the nation, and will illustrate how the united front format serves as 
an effective strategy to unite the now scattered members of the working 
class and progressive communities.

This is a very meaningful application of what I believe is the most 
important task of the Left right now: Unite, Don't Split! Our enemy is 
organized, and we MUST MUST begin to organize ourselves as well, and attempt 
to seize some real power.

After four months of organizing and canvassing, we have acquired some 1000 
surveys from members of the community, outlining their needs and ideas in 
terms of establishing new public policy for the city. The Campaign now 
includes some 50 or so dedicated activists. We have a web site 
(www.newbruns.org), a newspaper, and have gotten the backing from some 
prominent local churches, civic leaders, and attorneys. Our united front 
consists of students, democrats, local teenagers, republicans (literally), 
socialists, communists, workers, landlords, church members. Obviously, we 
don't all agree on everything, but we do agree to struggle together in a 
principled way and to unite on the great amount that we do have in common.

This Saturday is the Convention of the People's Campaign. This is the climax 
of our organizing efforts, as everyone will get together and 
debate/nominate/vote on our political platform and candidates. This will be 
a major example of what we call "people's democracy", something we 
understand little about in this country.

I am writing to invite you to join us on Saturday to witness and partake in 
this wonderful and solemn ceremony, where everyday, ordinary people will put 
their ideas and voices forward in an effort to make life better for 
everyone.

The Convention will run from 10 am (registration) to 6pm. You don't have to 
come for the entire time if you can't. It will be at the Paul Robeson 
School, Commercial Ave, New Brunswick. There will be food and child care 
provided. It will be an intense and joyful time.

For more information feel free to call (732-249-9664) or email me. We seek 
your support on whatever level you can offer, even if you can't make it to 
Saturday's event. I look forward to talking with you!

in unity, and with great hope,
Kristina Bas

NEW BRUNSWICK PEOPLE�S CONVENTION

Today, residents from all of New Brunswick�s communities
unite in the struggle for people�s democracy in our
city. We are here to decide the issues that we can all
unite on and to choose 3 candidates who will run in the
November 7, 2000 election for the New Brunswick City
Council.

The City Council is the branch of city government with
the power to pass laws (ordinances) and to appoint city
officials. When the People�s Campaign wins the election
for three seats in November, we will have a majority of
the votes on the City Council. Our candidates will have
the power to pass laws to transform New Brunswick in any
way the people decide. Our candidates will also have the
power to fire corrupt city officials and replace them
with new officials chosen by the people.


THE PROGRAM OF THE PEOPLE�S CAMPAIGN

This morning, we will discuss and vote on our Campaign
Program, our plan to change the city of New Brunswick in
the interest of the people. Our campaign program has
seventeen points ranked in order of importance by over
1,000 New Brunswick residents who completed the People�s
Campaign surveys. The five most important issues the
people chose are:

We have one hour to discuss and vote on final changes to
the Campaign Program. Anyone can go up to the microphone
and use 30 seconds of speaking time to propose a change,
speak in favor of a change or speak against a change.
The Chair will call for a vote on the proposed changes
one at a time. Any proposed change that gets a majority
of the people�s votes will become part of the Campaign
Program. After the one hour of discussion, we will vote
on the entire Campaign Program as a whole.

Any New Brunswick residents and any non-resident
campaign worker can vote on the Program of the People�s
Campaign

THE ELECTION OF OUR CANDIDATES FOR THE CITY COUNCIL

After lunch, we will choose our three candidates who
will run in the November election for City Council. The
candidates must all sign a written oath saying that:

1)  They will support and fight for ALL of the points of
the People�s Campaign Program BEFORE and AFTER they are
elected to the City Council.

2)  They will follow the leadership of the People�
Campaign BEFORE and AFTER they are elected to the City
Council. They will follow all the decisions that the
people vote on at our monthly meetings and the decisions
made by the Steering Committee of the People�s Campaign.

3)  They will always follow the democratic majority rule
of the people of New Brunswick.

The city requirements to be a candidate are that you
must be an American citizen and you must have lived in
New Brunswick for the past year.

Only New Brunswick residents can vote for the candidates
for City Council.

If we have more than 6 candidates running for the three
seats, we will hold a Qualifying Round Vote and keep the
six candidates with the most votes.

Each resident will get to cast three votes, one per each
candidate of their choice.

Candidates need to get 51% of the votes or more to win.

If more than 3 candidates get 51% of the vote or more,
the three candidates with the most votes will win.

If only one or two candidates win 51% of the votes or
more, we will hold a runoff election between the
remaining candidates.

If no candidate wins 51% of the votes or more in the run-
off of election, the two candidates with the most votes
will go into a final runoff election.

THE ELECTION OF THE STEERING COMMITTEE:

After a short  afternoon break, we will vote for the
Steering Committee of the People�s Campaign.

The People�s Campaign holds General Meetings once per
month where New Brunswick residents and non-resident
campaign workers decide the next steps we will take in
the campaign.

In between the General Meetings, the People�s Campaign
is led by the Steering Committee.

The Steering Committee will have 8 members:

(3) - The three candidates for the City Council
(1) - The Campaign Manager
(1) - The Coordinator for the Referendum for an Elected
School Board
(3)  - Three more Steering Committee members-at-large

All New Brunswick residents and non-resident campaign
workers can vote for the members of the Steering
Committee.

We will take nominations and vote for the Campaign
Manager.

We will take nominations and vote for the Coordinator
for the Referendum for an Elected School Board.

We will take nominations and vote for the three Steering
Committee members at-large.

THE ELECTION OF THE WARD LEADERS

The People�s Campaign must grow in all neighborhoods
with the support of every city block. For all city
elections, the city of New Brunswick has been divided up
into six different Wards. Your Ward determines the place
where you and your neighbors must go to vote on election
day. Before we end the People�s Convention, we will
create three Ward organization that will each organize
for the campaign in their area, register everyone to
vote, collect signatures for the Elected School Board
Referendum  and promote our candidates.

The 3 Ward organizations are:

1)  Ward 3 (The Rutgers River Dorms and George St.) +
Ward 6 (College Avenue, Easton Avenue, Hamilton Street,
Somerset Street, Hutchinson St)

2)  Ward 1 (Raritan Gardens, Woodrow Wilson School) +
Ward 2 (Remsen Avenue, Livingston Avenue, Memorial
Homes, Douglass and Cook Campuses)

3) Ward 4 (French Street) + Ward 5 (Paul Robeson
Village, Wright Place, Route 27, Reed Street Apartments)

The residents of each Ward will vote for their Ward
Leader.

(As the People�s Campaign grows in the summer, we will
create a total of six ward organizations, one for each
Ward in New Brunswick.)

The program appeals to the middle class of New Brunswick. There are
different class interests represented within the campaign; the working
class has been nearly entirely excluded from the political process in this
city, and the campaign is working to change that. We've met members of the
middle class, members of the working class, who don't yet recognize that
their class interests lie in unity. It is the goal of the campaign to
show, through our unity and our *action* on our program, that unity around
this program will benefit all of their respective class interests. 

What is this lack of understanding you speak of? What, you think we're
canvassing *any* neighborhoods by saying, "Join the socialist revolution,
vote for the People's Campaign"? I don't *think* so, Chris--instead we've
been surveying, Tom's done crosstabs and statistics on the surveys to see
what different groups' main concerns are, etc. When we wrote the
invitations to join the Campaign, we addressed letters to various commuity
leaders, community groups, small businesses, students, etc--addressing the
different class interests and concerns that are jointly served by unity.
That was before the Campaign took off, so it was a solely NJFO project at
the time. NJFO has *always* attempted to unite a broad class basis in this
united front. 

Certainly the city machine will do everything it can to stop the campaign.
Someone I was speaking with tonight compared the NB city machine to an old
early 20th-century Democratic machine--complete with the danger of
beatings and the inevitability of corruption. The city machine *will*
attack us. The city machine *will* attack NJFO. Tney've done it before.
The task before us, however, is not to become callous opportunists who
abandon our honest political agendas because "someone might not like it."
What we must do is publicize the program of the Campaign, organize, draw
in new people, and lead the vast majority of classes in the City to
recognize that their common interests are best expressed by joining with
the Campaign to put our program in office.

landlords about rent control is difficult, and he's doing it. Good for

"necessary concessions" of a united front don't include abandoning one's

>

Um...we "scream" "united front," because this *is* a united front. It
doesn't mean I stop being a Communist, and it doesn't mean Frank stops
being a Republican because the majority of campaign members aren't either.
*Neither* of us gives up the right to independent advocacy. When we
represent the People's Campaign, we represent the *democratically-selected
program*. When I represent myself as a Communist, or a member of NJFO,
however, I represent not *just* that program, but also a socialist
revolutionary program. To pretend otherwise would be politically
reprehensible, dishonest and opportunist. 

The united front does *not* entail *anyone* relinquishing their political
freedom and democratic rights. This is a Communist-to-Republican
coalition, Chris, and the Communists among us aren't any more likely to
stop being so, or pretend to do so, than the Republicans are. When the
city machine attacks us, we'll prove ourselves by our action and by our
program, Chris--the campaign and *all* of its activists, including those
from NJFO. And you know what? We'll sue them for push polling and illegal
campaign tactics if they try those stunts. We're a *real* campaign
organization, and determined to win. The City Machine DOES NOT have the
right to decide what members of the People's Campaign will think, believe
and say. Do you wish to give them that right, Chris?

And seriously, Chris, again, what specifically are your criticisms of how
NJFO has apparently created some kind of campaign disunity? I don't
remember you raising any of this at the general meeting--at which everyone
had *plenty* of time to speak. You think important issues should be raised
there (even though you now are aware that the Baraka confirmation came
*after* that meeting). Why didn't you raise yours in that open, democratic
forum?

On Wed, 10 May 2000, Charlotte L. Kates wrote:

>The program appeals to the middle class of New Brunswick. There are
>different class interests represented within the campaign; the working
>class has been nearly entirely excluded from the political process in this
>city, and the campaign is working to change that. We've met members of the
>middle class, members of the working class, who don't yet recognize that
>their class interests lie in unity. It is the goal of the campaign to
>show, through our unity and our *action* on our program, that unity around
>this program will benefit all of their respective class interests. 

That's lovely in theory, Charlotte.  What has been done in practice to
mobilize the middle class and reach out to them to actively promote the
campaign in their eyes?  The actions on the program will never get a chance
to run their course if the election is not won.  And it seriously undermines
our chances to do so if we focus so extensively on the middle class.

The attitude I speak if is evident from your paragraph above, where you
imply a distinction between "middle class" and "working class".  This is
pseudo-Marxist nonsense.  The interests of working people are, of course,
not disparate between lower classes and middle classes.   But you make it
pretty clear in the above paragraph that the middle class is not the working
class to you -- that they are another creature altogether.  That is not only
a tactical mistake, it is an insult to middle class people who are just as
dependent on a paycheck for their daily lives.  This political faux pas
results from the antiquated view of class relations that has yet to be
adapted to life in New Brunswick in the 21st century.  It further
underscores the need for stronger non-Communist leadership in the People's
Campaign.

>What is this lack of understanding you speak of? What, you think we're
>canvassing *any* neighborhoods by saying, "Join the socialist revolution,
>vote for the People's Campaign"? I don't *think* so, Chris--instead we've
>been surveying, Tom's done crosstabs and statistics on the surveys to see
>what different groups' main concerns are, etc. When we wrote the
>invitations to join the Campaign, we addressed letters to various commuity
>leaders, community groups, small businesses, students, etc--addressing the
>different class interests and concerns that are jointly served by unity.
>That was before the Campaign took off, so it was a solely NJFO project at
>the time. NJFO has *always* attempted to unite a broad class basis in this
>united front. 

Don't say it -- do it.  I remember when about a year ago, NJFO managed to
convince a few businessmen and better-off middle class folk to come to a
fundraising meeting for the organization, where beautiful packets were
devised which, on the very first page, had pictures of Lenin and such
illustrious slogans as "Win the Advanced to Communism!"  Needless to say,
there were not many funds raised.  This is the type of nearsightedness and
impractical clinging to outmoded rhetoric that leaves me concerned as to the
fate of the campaign if the campaign is left in NJFO's hands, without
appropriate checks and balances.  This is the type of nonsense I expect from
Amiri Baraka as well -- the "keynote speaker" of our "united front" who also
writes about how we must "throw Republicans in the trash".  United whaaa?

>Certainly the city machine will do everything it can to stop the campaign.
>Someone I was speaking with tonight compared the NB city machine to an old
>early 20th-century Democratic machine--complete with the danger of
>beatings and the inevitability of corruption. The city machine *will*
>attack us. The city machine *will* attack NJFO. Tney've done it before.
>The task before us, however, is not to become callous opportunists who
>abandon our honest political agendas because "someone might not like it."
>What we must do is publicize the program of the Campaign, organize, draw
>in new people, and lead the vast majority of classes in the City to
>recognize that their common interests are best expressed by joining with
>the Campaign to put our program in office.

Again, examples, plans, how are we going to do this?  By saying that we are?
The same way that we are allegedly a "united front?"  As far as Communism is
concerned, not only does "someone" not like it, the vast majority of
Americans are utterly alienated from it.  Is your ideology more important

>I've not seen NJFO organizers make the claim you say we do. Quote or

>approaching small business owners about the problems they face due to

where X talks about the ballot or the bullet, and how we are going to try
the bullet next if the ballot does not suffice.  See how quickly they leave
and tell their friends that we are a bunch of lunatics.

No one said anything about hiding.  You mentioned a few messages back the
necessity of allowing people and groups to put forth their "maximum
program", and you cited the example of the unapproved "Revolutionary
Democratic Workers Party" flyers.  I disagreed with you.  There should not
be flyers that do not stress the campaign platform and the common agenda.
The essential issue with the campaign today is that there is no campaign
discipline.  People continue to practice their personal politics.  What
other organization would tolerate something like this -- especially if we
are indeed "in it to win it", and not to vindicate and promote our personal
ideologies?  

>If you *remember* that meeting so well, you'll remember that NJFO voted to

Why are you putting words in my mouth?  Did I say "exclusionary"?  No, I
said "idiotic".  *I'm* on the left, Charlotte, and I damn near cringed when
I heard the convoluted explanation of why we are not initiating a revolution
to seize power but instead are going for the ballot -- first.  None of the
new outsiders at that meeting showed up again.  I wonder why.

>The rest of the paragraph is silly anti-communism that should be

What does that mean?  What part of my paragraph is "silly anti-communism?"

>The united front does *not* entail *anyone* relinquishing their political

Again, this seems rather half-baked.  We will not prove ourselves by our
action and our program if we are not in office after November.  Suing the
city seems like a great PR move, but hardly wins us the election.  Maybe the

We really do want to be a real campaign organization, and it is damn well
