Post ID:313
Sender:xavier.hansen@...
Post Date/Time:2000-05-31 01:18:22
Subject:FROM THE STEERING COMMITTEE
Message:

The following resolution was approved 6-0 at the 
Steering Committee meeting of 5/29/2000. In attendance 
were Danny Rosado, Janice Payce, Keith Joseph, Audrey 
Allred, Frank Bright & Xavier Hansen. Joe Smith was also 
present but he left the meeting before the vote was 
taken.

************

Our historic first People�s Convention of New Brunswick 
brought together representatives from all communities 
and classes willing to struggle for democracy. We 
unanimously adopted our program and elected three 
candidates with clear majorities who will run in the 
elections to the City Council on November 7. This great 
success has given new energy to the People�s Campaign. 
We have already more than 60 active volunteers and we 
are growing every day. United, we can win.
Unfortunately, four individuals in the People�s 
Campaign, from the group Block on Lock, are currently 
distributing a letter that viciously attacks one of our 
candidates, Curtis Warren Sr. This letter slanders 
Curtis by claiming that he fails to support the People�s 
Campaign program and wants to cut a deal with the City 
Machine. Block on Lock bases this ridiculous insult on a 
single article in the Home News Tribune in which a 
reporter quoted Curtis at the Convention saying he was 
not going "to tear down the political machine" and that 
he would work with pharmaceutical companies to "solve 
the city�s drug problem" (see Home News Tribune, Sunday 
May 14, Local Section). 
The Home News Tribune is a big business newspaper tied 
to the corrupt New Brunswick City Machine No one in 
their right mind should expect them to report truthfully 
on the People�s Campaign. This is why we print our own 
newspaper to make sure we bring the real campaign news 
to the people. And this why we must prepare our 
candidates to make short and clear statements promoting 
the program of the People�s Campaign when dealing with 
other reporters. Because we had so much work to get 
ready for the convention, we did not prepare our 
candidates to deal with the press that day. Curtis spoke 
to the reporter for over ten minutes about the People�s 
Campaign. The Home News Tribune editors printed only two 
sentences to represent their views, not ours. 
Block on Lock never called Curtis to raise their 
concerns about his quotes. They never considered the 
four years Curtis has dedicated in the struggle against 
police brutality in New Brunswick and the many public 
speeches he has made to promote the struggle for 
democracy and to oppose the corrupt City Machine. And 
they never considered the respect Curtis has earned in 
all of New Brunswick�s communities for his courage and 
integrity, which is why he received the most votes of 
any candidates at the People�s Convention. The letter 
Block on Lock is distributing is really an attempt to 
demoralize and disrupt the campaign at a time when 
everyone is working their hardest to gather hundreds of 
petition signatures in only two weeks to put our 
candidates on the ballot. It is an attempt to sabotage 
the campaign by trying to weaken us and to strengthen 
our opponents.
The People�s Campaign is based on a broad unity around 
our program and our candidates, democratically voted on 
at the People�s Convention. Everyone has the right 
distribute their own flyers as long as they do not go 
against the unity of the People�s Campaign. Anyone who 
wants to attack the People�s Campaign by insulting and 
slandering one of our candidates must do so from outside 
the campaign. I propose to the Steering Committee that 
all those who signed the Block on Lock letter be 
immediately suspended from all campaign activities. They 
should not be allowed back into the campaign unless they 
renounce their letter openly. This is not an easy 
decision for us to make since we work so hard to keep 
everyone united in the campaign. But we cannot let down 
the people of New Brunswick and allow the whole campaign 
to be divided and defeated because we are afraid to make 
hard choices. And we cannot win our struggle for 
democracy if we allow anyone to stab us in the back when 
we must all stand shoulder to shoulder on the front line.

Xavier Hansen
Campaign Manager
5/29/2000

***************************************

The Steering Committee suspended Cliff Smith, Joe Smith 
and Jayson Hawkins from all campaign activities. They 
may return to the campaign should they decide to 
renounce their slanderous letter in writing. 

Keith Joseph is writing a response to the Block on Lock 
letter on behalf of the People's Campaign. Copies of 
both letters will be available at the next General 
Meeting on June 17.

Post ID:314
Sender:xavier.hansen@...
Post Date/Time:2000-05-31 01:32:09
Subject:WOMEN & YOUTH CAUCUSES
Message:

Two proposals to form additional caucuses were brought 
to the Steering Committee meeting of 5/29/2000.

Nikki Engel proposes the formation of a Women's Caucus 
in the People's Campaign. The Steering Committee 
supports this proposal and recommends that the caucus be 
organized at the next General Meeting on June 17.

Kevin proposes the formation of a Youth Caucus in the 
People's Campaign. The Steering Committee supports this 
proposal as well and recommends that Outreach Chair 
Samantha Prince assist all interested youth in forming 
this caucus.  

Janice Payce and Curtis Warren have also begun 
organizing to form a Black Caucus in the People's 
Campaign. And of course, a Latino Caucus (Comite Latino) 
was formed at the People's Convention and held its first 
preparatory meeting last week with 12 participants.

The Steering Committee, by a vote of 6-0, passed the 
following guidelines for the caucuses in order to assure 
fair representation to all in the People's Campaign:

Any caucus that recruits 10 or more active organizers to 
its meetings may elect a representative to the Steering 
Committee.

In unity, 

Xavier Hansen
Campaign Manager

**********




         NEW BRUNSWICK: NBT event to focus on residents'
         quality of life 

         Published in the Home News Tribune 5/31/00 

         STAFF REPORT

         An overview of New Brunswick Tomorrow's plans for improving the
quality of
         life for the people of New Brunswick will be discussed by
Stephen O'Connor,
         president of NBT, at 12:15 p.m. June 7 at the New Brunswick
Public Library, 60
         Livingston Ave.

         The event is sponsored by the Friends of the library as its
final First Wednesday
         program of the current season.

         O'Connor will discuss in depth NBT's mission to provide social
and human
         services initiatives in the city. 

         O'Connor, a community development specialist, has been NBT
president nearly
         five years. Before coming to New Brunswick, he was executive
director of the
         New Jersey Housing Assistance Corp. and was a vice president of
the Matrix
         Development Group, which is now playing a major role in New
Brunswick's
         downtown commercial, retail and residential renewal.

         A graduate of Rutgers University, he has a master's degree from
Harvard
         University and is a candidate for a Ph.D. at Rutgers. 

         Active in many community service organizations, he received the
coveted
         Franklin Delano Roosevelt Award from the New Jersey Chapter of
the March of
         Dimes and served on the Board of Operation Smile, which
provides free
         reconstructive plastic surgery for children around the world
born with severe
         facial deformities. 

         The event is free and open to the public.

Post ID:316
Sender:b v <villavoice@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-05-31 13:31:58
Subject:School Ethics Commission Decision re Arocho of N.B. Board of Education
Message:

My complaint against New Brunswick Board of Education
member Martin Arocho has been substantiated. He has
been found to have broken state ethics law known as
the School Ethics Act. In its May 23rd meeting the New
Jersey School Ethics Commission found his employment
with the Puerto Rican Action Board and his vote to
award that organization a $415,000 contract a
violation of Section 24(c). The Commission's
recommendation of censure as a penalty will be
reviewed by the state Education Commissioner. After
this, this matter may be concluded. If not, the case
is then appealed to the State Board of Education.

The case will be available for viewing at the state
Department of Education's website under the School
Ethics Commission link. You will need Adobe Acrobat to
view the document.

For those who have helped and offered encouragement,
thank you, thank you!

La lucha continua...

--Brian Villa

Post ID:318
Sender:Villa@...
Post Date/Time:2000-06-01 09:35:33
Subject:School Board/Ethics Complaint Newspaper Articles
Message:


Here are the articles. I especially urge the members of the media
committee to study the differences in the articles and ask me
about the dynamics of the two newspapers and why "objective news"
has two distinctly different articles, and how this will impact
upcoming political efforts.

--BV

FROM THE 6/1/00 STAR_LEDGER:

School official faces censure 

                By Alexander Lane
                STAFF WRITER

                The state School Ethics Commission has recommended
that New Brunswick school board President Martin Arocho be formally
censured for crossing an ethical line. 

                Arocho should have abstained from a 1998 board
vote to award a $415,583 contract for preschool services to the
nonprofit Puerto Rican Action Board, for which Arocho works,
the commission ruled. 

                Arocho's employment at Puerto Rican Action Board
"might reasonably be expected to impair his objectivity," the
decision read. 

                Commissioner of Education David Hespe will now
decide whether to formally censure Arocho. Generally, the commissioner
follows the ethics commission's
suggestions. 

                Brian Villa, the activist who filed the complaint
against Arocho, called the decision a victory. 

                "The complaint was substantiated and he was found
to have violated the law, that's the bottom line," Villa said.
"This is also a message that thoughtful committed citizens can
impose moral and ethical standards on board members who often
flout the public's wishes." 

                Arocho was not reachable, but Superintendent
of Schools Ronald Larkin lauded the decision. 

                "I'm very happy with the censure, it basically
validates that there was no wrongdoing," Larkin said. "They had
to give him something and that was the least severe." 

                Larkin pointed out that the contract would have
passed easily had Arocho abstained, and Arocho's voting was just
an oversight. "It wasn't done with any favor or anything of that
nature," Larkin said. 

                Villa has long said the school board should be
democratically elected rather than appointed by the mayor. He
has a reputation for keeping a close eye on the board -- but
this is his first successful ethics complaint. 

                "I touched the Blarney stone and they said that
I would never do it," Villa said. "I won on the merits." 


FROM THE 6/1/00 HOME NEWS TRIBUNE:

NEW BRUNSWICK: State panel rules school board head broke law


VOTE INVOLVED EMPLOYER 

By JAKE STUIVER

           New Brunswick board of education President Martin
Arocho violated state law when he voted in favor of awarding
a contract to his employer, the Puerto Rican Action Board, the
state School Ethics Commission has ruled.

           The commission, which operates under the state Department
of Education, found May 23 that Arocho violated the School Ethics
Act. The commission recommended a penalty of censure.

           Arocho could not be reached for comment yesterday
evening. He became president of the board earlier this year.

           New Brunswick activist Brian Villa filed a complaint
against Arocho and board member Edwin Guiterrez
last year for voting on a July 1998 resolution awarding a $415,583
contract to the nonprofit PRAB to provide preschool for city
4-year-olds.

           Villa said the two board members should have abstained
from the vote because they were both listed as
members of PRAB in a board flier and because Arocho worked for
PRAB. He also challenged Guiterrez's appointment to the board
by Mayor Jim Cahill because he is a city employee working in
the Community Development Division.

           The commission dismissed the complaints against Guiterrez,
finding that Guiterrez's employment with the city
does not constitute a substantial conflict and that Guiterrez
was not a member of PRAB at the time of the
vote in 1998. Guiterrez was a founding member of PRAB in 1971
and served on the group's board of trustees until 1991.

           The commission found that Arocho also was not a member
of PRAB at the time of the vote, but he was an
employee of the organization and therefore violated a statute
that prohibits school officials from acting on
any matter in which they or an immediate family member has a
direct financial involvement.

           At the time, Board Attorney George Hendricks said
that if he knew Arocho was a PRAB employee when the vote was
taken, he would have advised him to abstain. According to the
state document detailing the finding, Hendricks also argued the
board first contracted with PRAB in July 1993, prior to Arocho's
employment with the organization in 1997.

           Hendricks also argued Arocho had been hired by PRAB
under a state Department of Community Affairs grant in 1997,
and that his job had nothing to do with PRAB's preschool program,
according to the document.

           Villa said he's satisfied with the judgment.

           "A lot of unnecessary things were said about my claim,
and those things turned out to be false," he said.

Post ID:323
Sender:Villa@...
Post Date/Time:2000-06-05 10:33:05
Subject:NEWS: Assistant City Attorney Accused of Stealing
Message:


This presents an opportunity to present efforts for good government,
accountability and open books at the next city council meeting.

Brian Villa
732-220-1405

**********
STAR-LEDGER
Lawyer accused of raiding account 

             06/01/00

             By Alexander Lane
             STAFF WRITER

             One of New Brunswick's part- time city
             prosecutors is facing state disciplinary action
for allegedly writing himself a $5,000 check from a
             client's escrow account to buy Christmas
             presents. 

             If the state Office of Attorney Ethics proves that
             charge against attorney Frank Shamy at a June
             15 hearing, it is likely Shamy will be disbarred,
             said Lee Gronikowski, deputy ethics counsel at
             the state agency. 

             ''If you do it, you go. There's not a lot of talk
about
             mitigation, extenuation, aggravation,"
             Gronikowski said. 

             The misappropriation charge is the most serious
             of three contained in an April 6 complaint
             Gronikowski lodged against Shamy after the
             agency did a random audit of financial records for
             Shamy's private law practice. 

             The agency -- an arm of the state Supreme Court
             -- also charged that Shamy misrepresented the
             status of a real estate transaction and committed
             record keeping violations. 

             In a written response to the complaint, Shamy
             said he borrowed the $5,000, but said he had his
             client's permission to do so. He denied
             intentionally lying about the real estate
             transaction, and said he corrected the
             record-keeping mistakes. 

             Shamy, at first, denied knowing anything about
             the complaint and then said he would not talk in
             detail about it. "This has nothing to do with my
job
             as prosecutor," Shamy said. 

             According to his written response, Shamy said he
             had his client's verbal permission to use the
             $5,000. 

             ''Respondent (Shamy) was unaware that this
             transaction had to be reduced to writing and
             certainly would have obtained his client's written
             consent had he known that was required," the
             response reads. 

             Shamy's attorney in the matter is E. Ronald
             Wright, a part-time New Brunswick municipal
             judge. Attempts to reach Wright were
             unsuccessful. 

             Shamy started working as a part- time prosecutor
             last June 26 and is paid a base salary of
             $18,000. 

             New Brunswick Mayor James Cahill did not return
             a call for comment about the matter and the city's
             attorney William Hamilton, who appointed Shamy,
             said he learned of the complaint only yesterday
             morning. 

             Hamilton said he was gathering all the relevant
             documents to prepare a report for the mayor. 

             The misappropriation complaint is related to a
             personal injury lawsuit Shamy filed in 1994 as a
             private attorney on behalf of John Ludlow. In
             1997, $125,000 in settlement funds was
             deposited into Shamy's attorney trust account. 

             The Middlesex County Board of Social Services
             then put a lien on Ludlow's settlement, entitling
the
             board to reclaim welfare money it had paid
             Ludlow. 

             On Dec. 1, 1998 -- with $6,747 in Shamy's trust
             account to pay the social services board --
             Shamy wrote himself the $5,000 check to pay for
             Christmas presents, the attorney ethics complaint
             says. 

             Shamy has denied his behavior was egregious
             enough to violate the Wilson Rule, based on a
             1971 state Supreme Court decision, that
             specifically prohibits attorneys from misusing
             clients' money. 

             ''It basically says 'Thou shalt not steal,'"
             Gronikowski said. 

             The complaint also alleges Shamy told the Smart
             Money Mortgage Center he was holding an
             $8,000 gift for Juan and Beatriz Marrero, whom
             he was representing in a real estate purchase. In
             fact, according to the complaint, he was holding
             no gifts for the Marreros, just a $20,000 loan from
             Juan Marrero's trade union. 

             Shamy said in his response that another attorney,
             James Feeney, was holding the gift, and what
             mattered most was that the $8,000 existed, not
             who was holding it. 

             The Office of Attorney Ethics has 15 three-person
             county committees that decide their cases. The
             Mercer County ethics committee, made up of two
             lawyers and one nonlawyer, will meet publicly to
             hear Shamy's case at a Princeton law office on
             June 15.

Post ID:324
Sender:Groovemeister007@...
Post Date/Time:2000-06-06 13:19:26
Subject:Board of Elections letter
Message:

Following is the text of the letter sent by the Peoples' Campaign to
the Board of Elections on June 1.

Groovemeister


NEW BRUNSWICK PEOPLES' CAMPAIGN
C/O FRANK BRIGHT
218 GEORGE STREET
NEW BRUNSWICK, NJ 08901

June 1, 2000

Matthew M. Vaughn
Middlesex County Board of Elections
777 Jersey Avenue
New Brunswick, NJ 08901

Dear Mr. Vaughn:

	I have your letter of May 10, 2000.  Because it utterly
avoided the issues we raised in our letter of April 7, 2000, in which
we petitioned the Board of Elections to override the city-recommended
sites for twelve polling districts in New Brunswick, I will not
dignify your letter by calling it a "response" to mine.

	Your letter contends, and indeed, we concede, that the
decennial census precludes meaningful changes to ward and district
lines this year.  N.J.S.A. 19:4-15.  However, those same election
statutes are equally clear that the selection of polling places is a
separate issue.  Selecting sites for polls is an annual exercise that
must be undertaken regardless of when the Census is taken.  N.J.S.A.
19:8-2 directs municipal clerks to suggest, and the County Board to
select, at specified deadlines in each year, polling places for
elections.  Your suggestion that the taking of the Census precludes
the Board from fulfilling its specific statutory mandate of annually
selecting appropriate polling places calculated to ease all possible
burdens on voting, is absurd.

	The Board's refusal to even consider changes in the location
of the polling places on a wholly unfounded legal rationale  the
taking of the Census this year  is itself arbitrary and
capricious,
and an abuse of the Board's discretion.  Turning to the merits,
we
convincingly demonstrated in our April 7, 2000 letter that the
current polling locations for twelve districts in New Brunswick are
inadequate.  There is no competent evidence known to us, or that has
been presented to the Board, that contradicts the polling places we
recommended, or our rationales supporting each such change.  Again,
the refusal to implement our recommendations is arbitrary,
capricious, and an abuse of discretion.

	Accordingly, we urge the Board to reconsider its decision.
If we do not hear from you by Monday, June 12, 2000, we will have no
choice but to ask a court to set aside these acts and omissions by
the County Board and implement the uncontradicted recommendations of
the Peoples' Campaign as to polling places.

	Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Respectfully submitted,

NEW BRUNSWICK
PEOPLES' CAMPAIGN

By:  /s/ Frank Bright
     FRANK BRIGHT


cc:	Sharon Young, Esq.
	  Attorney General's Office
	Daniel Torrisi,
	  New Brunswick City Clerk

Post ID:325
Sender:Groovemeister007@...
Post Date/Time:2000-06-06 13:29:34
Subject:Election activities tonight
Message:

Members of the Peoples' Campaign will be meeting at 6 pm _SHARP_ 
tonight at 218 Townsend for the purpose of visiting several polling 
places.  This learning exercise is important.  It meant to 
familiarize people with poll sites, new voting machines, and election 
day procedures.  Anyone who will be working on the campaign in ANY 
capacity in November, and anyone who can teach those that will be 
around in November is strongly encouraged to attend, so you can see 
exactly how things are done now, and it is not an entirely new 
experience in November.


Here is the agenda (subject to change)

6:10 Leave 218 Townsend, travel to Redshaw School

6:20 Arrive Redshaw School, meet district board workers, examine 
voting machines, get explanation of how they work, meet challengers, 
examine voting roll books, voting slips, and provisional ballots.

6:50 Exit Redshaw school, scope out 100-foot border from polling 
site, meet any GOTV workers on site.

7:00 Leave for Providence Square poll, where we will go in, look 
around, study surroundings, demarcate 100-foot line, and leave.

7:20 Arrive at Lincoln School

7:30 Study layout of poll site, meet district board workers

7:45 Role-play advising voter of which polling district to go to.

7:55 Talk to campaign / GOTV workers

8:00 Polls close, see how voting results are collected from machines

8:20 Leave for Corzine party at Hyatt.


GROOVEMEISTER

> >>>>>> REPUBLICAN ELECTED MAYOR OF DERRY
>
>
>  Sinn Fein's Cathal Crumley become the first ever Sinn Fein mayor
>  of Derry, the first Sinn Fein mayor of a major irish city since
>  1920.
>
>  Huge crowds attended the city's Guildhall to watch Mr Crumley
>  defeat unionist nominee, Ernie Hamilton by 21 votes to eight to
>  secure a historic victory. He is the first Sinn Fein mayor since
>  the death of Terence MacSwiney - following a hunger strike - in
>  Cork in 1920.
>
>  Ulster Unionist and outgoing deputy mayor, Mr Hamilton was
>  returned for a second term as deputy with the unanimous support
>  of council. Derry councillors abandoned normal procedure last
>  night to permit the huge crowds which attended the city's
>  Guildhall access to the council chamber.
>
>  A former prisoner of war and a blanket protestor at Long kesh
>  jail, Mr Crumley last night pledged to be mayor for all the
>  people of Derry.
>
>  In a miscarriage of justice, Mr Crumley, a father of three, was
>  convicted on the evidence of so-called Derry 'supergrasses' in
>  May 1984 and received nine life sentences and an additional 300
>  years in jail. However, all the convictions were quashed, and Mr
>  Crumley was released from prison in 1986.
>
>  When the result of the vote was announced last night, the new
>  mayor received a standing and prolonged ovation.
>
>  Education minister, Martin McGuinness - who was accompanied by
>  party chairman Mitchel McLaughlin - said Mr Crumley's success was
>  a "great night" for Derry.
>
>  In his acceptance speech, Mr Crumley said his election as mayor
>  closed a long and painful period. He said his election closed the
>  door on the politics of exclusion.
>
>  "The failed politics of exclusion end tonight and I can assure
>  you that during my term of office no-one will be denied their
>  rights. I will be open impartial, fair and pragmatic.
>
>  "I offer the hand of friendship to the unionist community and
>  trust they will have the maturity to react in a reciprocal
>  fashion for the betterment of this city," he said.

Post ID:329
Sender:"Audrey Allred" <audreya99@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-06-07 13:12:35
Subject:from the Steering Committee
Message:

A proposal was brought to the Steering Committee meeting on 5/29/00 to make 
all phone and contact lists collected while canvassing available to everyone 
working on the campaign.

The Steering Committee decided against this proposal for these reasons:
1) Due to the large amount of contact information that has been collected, 
it is virtually impossible to compile a complete list.

2) Having a list of numbers available to all campaign organizers would ruin 
the efficiency of the campaign. If people are receiving a potentially large 
amount of phone calls for various different reasons, they may get confused, 
irritated and discouraged from supporting and working with the campaign.

Instead, every organizer should keep a list of their own contacts and 
develop networks based on that information.

In unity,
Audrey Allred
Steering Committee

>From: "Vieques Libre" <viequeslibre@...>
>To: List Member <vivaohio@...>
>Subject: South Koreans Protest US Bombing Range
>Date: 7 Jun 2000 10:29:52 -0000

>Vieques Libre - http://www.viequeslibre.org
>
>http://dailynews.yahoo.com/h/ap/20000606/wl/skorea_us_military_1.html
>
>Yahoo World Headlines
>Tuesday June 6 11:19 AM ET
>
>Anti-U.S. Protest in South Korea
>
>SEOUL, South Korea (AP) - About 2,000 villagers and activists clashed with
>riot police Tuesday, demanding closure of a U.S. military bombing range on
>South Korea's west coast, police and reports said.
>
>Protesters shouted anti-U.S. slogans as they tried to march into the
>bombing range near Mae Hyang, a village 50 miles southwest of Seoul. They
>threw rocks and wielding sticks and security forces guarding the site,
>police said.
>
>Police, holding plastic shields locked together in front of them, blocked
>the march.
>
>Villagers have long demanded the relocation of the nearby Koon-Ni Range,
>and anti-U.S. protests have increased since early May, when a U.S. fighter
>jet with engine trouble dropped six bombs on the Koon-Ni Range near the
>village.
>
>Villagers claimed that six people were slightly injured and walls were
>cracked and windows shattered by the impact. But U.S. and Korean military
>investigators said the bombs caused no injuries or property damage.
>
>South Korea's Defense Ministry has ruled out moving the base and instead
>intends to relocate 236 homes close to the range to avoid friction - a
>plan opposed by villagers.
>
>``We'll risk our lives to fight until the Koon-Ni range is shut down,''
>Choi Yong-woon, a 45-year-old village leader, was quoted as saying by the
>national news agency Yonhap.
>
>Villagers said one activist was slightly injured in the clashes but police
>could not confirm it. No arrests were made.
>
>Civic and leftist groups have seized on the controversy over the bombing
>range to mount anti-U.S. protests, demanding the withdrawal of U.S. troops
>in South Korea. There are 37,000 American soldiers stationed here under a
>defense treaty.
>
>

These are the amendments made at the convention that we discussed adding to the new pamphlet - these are what I could remember from that day:

1. New Brunswick is a union friendly town, under jobs.

Post ID:342
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-06-12 14:22:10
Subject:RE:
Message:

I think one important issue that is behind our difficulties is that we havent addressed an approach to maintaining candidate's accountability to the campaign.  This is a next step.  Creating a democratic  accountability structure has not been done before so we are starting from scratch.  We all have said that we dont want our candidates to sell out at any point, thinking of once they get in office, and those we chose we have firm belief in them that they wont.  Is this enough at this point?  What do we expect a call for accountability to look like as we move forward?  Do we demand/expect that people make this call in a general meeting?  If we demand unity in the campaign do we ask that we not make our inital call a public attack, but more low key so as not to detract from the campaign and only move into the public realm once it is certain that the differences are irreconcilable with the campaign points, or that somewhere a mistake was not made or someone was not intentionally misquoted with the thought to divide and conquer? At what point are  we a ball and chain around our  candidates legs and at what point are we keeping the campaign accountable?  And if we create an accountability procedure, how can we make sure that it is not a bureaucratic nightmare or a reliance on someone knowing someone else - because alot of people don't know the organizers in the campaign well.

Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405

Post ID:344
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-06-14 11:25:34
Subject:Jobs Polls
Message:

From: 	"Greg LeRoy" <goodjobs@...>
To:	"Me" <goodjobs@...>
Date: 	6/13/00 5:52PM
Subject: 	Two Excellent Polls


Two excellent polls released last week reveal strong continuing public
concern over declining job quality in the U.S.  The first, released by the
National Alliance for Fair Employment, finds that two out of three Americans
consider it unfair when contingent workers are paid lower wages than
full-timers doing the same work at the same level. Six out of ten said they
were more likely to vote for a candidate who backs legislation to require
companies to pay part-time, contract or temporary employees the same rate of
pay and benefits as regular employees. See the poll at:

www.fairjobs.org/report/poll.php

The second, released by Jobs for the Future, finds that a whopping *94%* of
Americans agree that people who work full-time should be able to earn enough
to keep their families out of poverty (80% agree strongly). And 77% believe
that government should help people leaving welfare get good jobs that offer
opportunities for advancement and the chance to remain self-sufficient. Only
19% believe people should be moved into jobs as quickly as possible
regardless of the jobs' potential.  Asked how much a family of four needs to
"make ends meet," 69% said at least $35,000 a year -- more than twice the
federal poverty level for such a household! See this poll at:

www.jff.org/whatsnew.html

Greg LeRoy -- Good Jobs First
www.goodjobsfirst.org

Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405

Post ID:350
Sender:Louise Ammentorp <lknesta@...>

Subject:Re: [nbpeoplescampaign] Block on Lock Expelled
Message:

This statement was drafted by myself,  the Steering Committee of the People's Campaign
voted unanimously to support the expulsion of Block on Lock.
About Block on Lock
or who is selling out?

For the first time in memory residents of New Brunswick have begun to organize and
mobilize to seize control of government and begin to take control over their lives.
We have built for the first time a multi-national united front of Afro-Americans,
Latinos, and Euro-Americans uniting workers, students, professionals and other
segments of the middle class into an organization.  The People's Campaign represents
the first serious threat to the unchallenged domination of the city machine and the
giant corporations that back it. At this historic moment, when the people of New
Brunswick have finally begun to stretch out their arms and flex their muscles after a
long sleep, Block on Lock Productions takes up the job of attacking the people's
organization.  Block on Lock has done the only thing the City Machine can not do to
us, Block on Lock has called the Campaign a "sellout".  The have done the only job
that Cahil and all the other puppets of Johnson and Johnson in city government could
not do. We do not know if Block on Lock has been paid for their efforts.
      Block on Lock  has begun distributing literature attacking the People's Campaign
in general and the steering committee, our campaign manger, and our candidates in
particular.  The People's Campaign upholds everyone participating in the campaign's
right to criticize, question and discuss actions of the Campaign. We can not tolerate
member organizations slandering and viciously attacking our campaign. For these
reasons all members of Block on Lock Productions should be immediately expelled from
our organization.

Post ID:361
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-06-19 10:28:33
Subject:School update
Message:

More info regarding the K and Pre-K privatization issue:

The NB BOE is currently  filing suit against the state regarding their lack of supplemental funds for the rest of the district, related to the Abbott v. Burke funds the City is due.  There is an overcrowding problem since the City has not gotten its money - $8M alone in pre-K funds. More students must be enrolled b/c of A v B. Last year, 4 year olds were enrolled for 1/2 day (Abbott v Burke requires that 3 yrs on up be in all-day pre-K programs). Next year, the program must include 3 year olds, and 400 are registered.  The City was planning to lease space in trailers, buy properties buy the State has dragged their feet and prevented them from doing this. So privatization is a poor response to this overcrowding problem.  Certification for daycare centers providing daycare (HeadSart is just one provider) is being made more stringent and brought in line w/state standards, however, staff who were noncertified before receiving contracts have been grandfathered in.

Zofia Nowakowski
Fiscal Policy Institute
218 W 40th St, 3rd Fl
New York, NY 10018
Tel: 212.278.0878
Fax:212.730.1405

and low teacher-student ratio.

Post ID:366
Sender:timmy.o'toole@...
Post Date/Time:2000-06-20 21:08:38
Subject:Education, etc
Message:


Greetings --

I thought I would 'put down on paper' what I sought to express on 
Saturday, that is, my concerns over the "Higher Education" point of 
the platform as it is currently formulated, etc.. 

---

It is my understanding that the following was actually proposed and 
voted on as an integral component of the platform, at the convention:
             
             "College for all New Brunswick graduates"

Any further elaboration, in the form of specific policy 
recommendations and proposals, I understand need remain within the 
spirit of this (fairly general) point.  

Inside the current edition of the platform / candidates brochure, the 
following _specific_ policy recommendation appears, in attempted 
fulfillment of the above.  Verbatim --

"Negotiate with Rutgers University, as a condition any city 
assistance with plans for expansion, new buildings, or new programs 
in the city, to provide open admissions and free college education to 
all New Brunswick High School graduates."

I think the intentions here are quite good, and it isn't without 
merit to attempt to demand such an arrangement between Rutgers and 
the New Brunswick community. However, a number of problems arise.  At 
the same time, a number of considerations are omitted.   

1)  Rutgers is the 'State University of New Jersey'.  It is first and 
foremost accountable to the state legislature and the governor, 
alongside various corporate interests.  Secondly, only part of 
Rutgers College, Douglass College, and Mason Gross are actually in 
the City of New Brunswick.  The rest of it is in Piscataway, or in 
Newark or Camden.  

It would seem difficult for the City of New Brunswick to actually 
succeed in negotiating directly with the state university for such 
special consideration.  Would other cities and towns where Rutgers 
has campuses not demand the same arrangement?  This would have to 
become either a state policy, or no policy at all.  Of course, if the 
city council were to wish to put forward such a demand in a kind of 
activist role vis a vis the state or federal gov't -- there is 
nothing unusual about this -- it might be a good idea.  But the goal 
of the platform point seems to be something more concerete.

2)   It may be 'only fair' to extend open admissions selectively, to 
students from schools that perform so poorly that the state may well 
be obligated to give kids the benefit of the doubt, then compensate 
with remedial classes.  Rutgers is not that shy about lowering its 
admission standards for equality-of-opportunity considerations (as a 
state university).  What it fails at, like many large public 
universities undertaking this, is _retention_.  Open admissions won't 
guarantee that these NBHS graduates will go on to graduate from 
college.  This is perhaps more because of the "cultural capital" 
factor, knowing how to be a student, how to fake your way through 
certain things (like standardized tests), etc, than a lack of writing 
or math skills.  Or so I understand the consensus to be amongst many 
sociologists.

3)  The platform point above pays no attention to other state 
universities and colleges, vocational / technical / trade schools, 
and the county college.  Indeed, county colleges have a great deal of 
importance, if nothing else, in helping otherwise unprepared 
individuals to ultimately succeed in a four-year school.  (Also, MCC 
has a campus in New Brunswick)

So, what should be looked at more clearly is -- What opportunities 
_already_ exist, what community programs already exist, what are 
colleges in the state already doing, what scholarships exist, etc.. 
Furthermore, what sort of help are students recieving within the HS?  
Until these facts are known a little more clearly, it would probably 
be best to revise the platform to state something that includes more, 
but make less specific reccomendations.   

(Perhaps I am stating that the above proposal places the issue of 
higher education too much within the constellation of urban 
redevelopment issues rather than viewing it in terms of other 
educational and job-training/vocational issues)

This is all rudimentary, and issued with none but the most 
exploratory intent.  

Yours,

Jeremy

Post ID:367
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-06-21 09:35:10
Subject:City Council meeting tonite 7pm City Hall
Message:

The City council is expected to take final action tonight on a $49M budget that calls for a 9-cent property tax rate increase.  The municipal tax levy will increase by $2.2M to $17.2 million necessitating a tax hike from $1.03 per $100 of assessed value tro $1.12 per $100.  The increase is due to several expenditures including spending $600K to lease a new police headquarters next to city hall in Civic Square, which wil lbe leased for 20 yrs from the county.  The council will also bove on the proposed budget of the City Market special improvement distric that covers the downtown area - at $401,990, $1,500 more than last year.  It will be supplemented by corporate sponsor financing (whatever that means!) of $106,000.  The council will also conduct a public hearing on a proposed zoning ordinance that would set 2 1/2 stories as the maximum height of new one and 2 family homes in the city. (if this went through the planning board, I missed it - they spoke about the extra bedroom regulations which I spoke out against but this was not explained to me.)

New York, NY 10018

Post ID:368
Sender:"Louise Ammentorp" <lknesta@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-06-21 09:52:45
Subject:Home News BOE article
Message:

Great work!


NEW BRUNSWICK: Trailer plan for pupils protested


Published in the Home News Tribune 6/21/00
By JAKE STUIVER
STAFF WRITER
Parents, teacher's union leaders and political hopefules turned out en masse 
for a New Brunswick board of education meeting last night where the 
administration was expected to present a plan to house more prekindergarten 
pupils.

Representatives from the People's Campaign, an independent political group 
that's running candidates for City Council, were at the high school 
auditorium front door throughout the evening handing out fliers promoting an 
elected school board. City activists recently revived the campaign to wrest 
control of school board appointments from Mayor Jim Cahill and have a board 
elected by the public.

The school board went into closed session, upon which People's Campaign 
council candidate Curtis L. Warren Sr. went to the microphone and rallied 
the large crowd against the proposal to place prekindergarten and child-care 
programs in 26 temporary trailers and have a private company assist in their 
education.

Warren claimed the board would privatize the operation and undermine 
teacher's unions. His speech was followed by several women from the audience 
who spoke against the plan. One woman backed the call for an elected board.

The board was still in closed session at press time last night.

Schools Superintendent Ronald Larkin planned to present a temporary solution 
last night to an anticipated influx of pupils resulting from the state 
Deparment of Education's requirement to provide free prekindergarten and 
child-care programs to all residents.

New Brunswick doesn't have any more room to build facilities for a large 
enrollment increase, Larkin said Monday.

There are currently about 750 3-year-olds, 800 4-year-olds and 850 
kindergartners in the city's program, he said. Some of them are in schools 
and others are spread throughout various daycare facilities in the city, he 
said.

Under the temporary plan, there would be 26 trailers spread among the high 
school and Lord Stirling, McKinley and Woodrow Wilson schools, officials 
said.

The trailers and longer-term placements would come at no extra cost to 
taxpayers because they come with fees the district already pays for its 
child-care programs, Larkin said.

Kate M. Smith, president of the New Brunswick Education Association 
teacher's union, had a statement prepared to respond to the board's 
discussion last night.

In the statement, she complained that Innovative Educational Programs, the 
company that runs the city's science and technology high school, is proposed 
for taking over some of the child-care programs.

"It is a corporation," she said. "What does a corporation know about 
education? A corporation's reason for being is money, profit, not children's 
education."

The teachers provided by IEP would lack the benefits of the union contract 
or rights guaranteed to board employees under state law and wouldn't be able 
to get tenure or contribute to the pension fund, Smith said.

"Who, then, would be willing to work under such demeaning conditions?" she 
asked.

Larkin, interviewed prior to the meeting, insisted IEP is a reputable 
child-care provider with which the district has had a successful 
relationship at the science and technology high school.



from the Home News Tribune

Post ID:370
Sender:"kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-06-21 16:07:30
Subject:proposal to amend the platform
Message:

this is my proposal to amend our campaign platform. i want to replace the 
current description underneath the "JOBS" subsection, which i believe is 
disjointed and unclear, with the following:

Our goal is full and meaningful employment at a living wage for all people 
in the city of new brunswick. To accomplish this, we will support/lead 
initiatives to raise the state minimum wage; we will actively support the 
right of all workers to organize for the purposes of collective bargaining; 
and we will give businesses that employ a majority city residents 
(especially those that are unionized) special preference in the procurement 
of city contracts. We support funding for job training for city residents 
(especially for women and youth). We actively oppose any efforts to 
privatize public sector work. We will strongly advocate for pay equity 
policies that can begin to lessen the disparity in wages between workers of 
different genders and nationalities.

any comments/questions? can we vote on this?

thanks, Kristina

Post ID:374
Sender:"kristina bas" <KRISBAS@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-06-22 15:21:04
Subject:Re: [nbpeoplescampaign] Education, etc
Message:

jeremy,

i think you bring up excellent points. overall, considering the revisions 
that have been offered in the past week on some of the platform points, I 
think we've reached a point in the campaign when we have to move beyond the 
"sound bite" stage. that means researching our policy points and formulating 
clear and informed proposals. my suggestion to you is to reword the 
Education proposal to include what you've written. that way we can vote on 
it and continue transforming our platform for the better.

additionally, i want to reintroduce Zofia's idea that we assign "point 
people" to each topic on the platform. Experts, so to speak. i don't mean 
this to sound intimidating, but i think it would be easier if one or two 
people concentrated on one specific topic and made sure to research it 
thoroughly. that way, when the time comes, we can be prepared to talk about 
everything.

what do people think about this? i'd like to discuss this at the next 
tactical meeting if all are willing.

Kristina


>From: timmy.o'toole@...
>Reply-To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>To: nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com
>Subject: [nbpeoplescampaign] Education, etc
>Date: Wed, 21 Jun 2000 01:08:38 -0000
>
>
>Greetings --
>
>I thought I would 'put down on paper' what I sought to express on
>Saturday, that is, my concerns over the "Higher Education" point of
>the platform as it is currently formulated, etc..
>
>---
>
>It is my understanding that the following was actually proposed and
>voted on as an integral component of the platform, at the convention:
>
>              "College for all New Brunswick graduates"
>
>Any further elaboration, in the form of specific policy
>recommendations and proposals, I understand need remain within the
>spirit of this (fairly general) point.
>
>Inside the current edition of the platform / candidates brochure, the
>following _specific_ policy recommendation appears, in attempted
>fulfillment of the above.  Verbatim --
>
>"Negotiate with Rutgers University, as a condition any city
>assistance with plans for expansion, new buildings, or new programs
>in the city, to provide open admissions and free college education to
>all New Brunswick High School graduates."
>
>I think the intentions here are quite good, and it isn't without
>merit to attempt to demand such an arrangement between Rutgers and
>the New Brunswick community. However, a number of problems arise.  At
>the same time, a number of considerations are omitted.
>
>1)  Rutgers is the 'State University of New Jersey'.  It is first and
>foremost accountable to the state legislature and the governor,
>alongside various corporate interests.  Secondly, only part of
>Rutgers College, Douglass College, and Mason Gross are actually in
>the City of New Brunswick.  The rest of it is in Piscataway, or in
>Newark or Camden.
>
>It would seem difficult for the City of New Brunswick to actually
>succeed in negotiating directly with the state university for such
>special consideration.  Would other cities and towns where Rutgers
>has campuses not demand the same arrangement?  This would have to
>become either a state policy, or no policy at all.  Of course, if the
>city council were to wish to put forward such a demand in a kind of
>activist role vis a vis the state or federal gov't -- there is
>nothing unusual about this -- it might be a good idea.  But the goal
>of the platform point seems to be something more concerete.
>
>2)   It may be 'only fair' to extend open admissions selectively, to
>students from schools that perform so poorly that the state may well
>be obligated to give kids the benefit of the doubt, then compensate
>with remedial classes.  Rutgers is not that shy about lowering its
>admission standards for equality-of-opportunity considerations (as a
>state university).  What it fails at, like many large public
>universities undertaking this, is _retention_.  Open admissions won't
>guarantee that these NBHS graduates will go on to graduate from
>college.  This is perhaps more because of the "cultural capital"
>factor, knowing how to be a student, how to fake your way through
>certain things (like standardized tests), etc, than a lack of writing
>or math skills.  Or so I understand the consensus to be amongst many
>sociologists.
>
>3)  The platform point above pays no attention to other state
>universities and colleges, vocational / technical / trade schools,
>and the county college.  Indeed, county colleges have a great deal of
>importance, if nothing else, in helping otherwise unprepared
>individuals to ultimately succeed in a four-year school.  (Also, MCC
>has a campus in New Brunswick)
>
>So, what should be looked at more clearly is -- What opportunities
>_already_ exist, what community programs already exist, what are
>colleges in the state already doing, what scholarships exist, etc..
>Furthermore, what sort of help are students recieving within the HS?
>Until these facts are known a little more clearly, it would probably
>be best to revise the platform to state something that includes more,
>but make less specific reccomendations.
>
>(Perhaps I am stating that the above proposal places the issue of
>higher education too much within the constellation of urban
>redevelopment issues rather than viewing it in terms of other
>educational and job-training/vocational issues)
>
>This is all rudimentary, and issued with none but the most
>exploratory intent.
>
>Yours,
>
>Jeremy
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>

Kris, I think you make good points. Let's get volunteers to contact outside 
experts, enlist them in the campaign's efforts (there have to be folks out 
there who would love to add some real policy juice to our work, get their 
names on the end product so to speak).  Point people shouldn't do all the 
work themselves. They should busy themselves getting NB residents to work 
with us. But point people would be responsible for gathering the info, 
cooking it down, and presenting it to either tactical or steering. They 
could also be the people who help prepare the candidates for the public, 
prep for debates, etc.

Post ID:381
Sender:jmluceno@...
Post Date/Time:2000-06-26 02:25:29
Subject:Newspaper
Message:

Folks, the newspaper is really looking sparse right now.  
It resembles a weak agitational pamphlet more than an
organ of Truth dissemination.  

I want everyone to look through the following two articles ...
and engage in Ruthless Criticism.  Remember -- this is the 
tool you will carry on the streets and give to anyone who is
interested in the Campaign.  It has to look sharp, it has to
represent the United Front, and it has to be true to our 
real intentions.

Nobody had a chance to criticize anything about the last
paper before it went to print.  I don't want that to happen
this time.  I want everybody's criticism.  Plus!  We need
everybody's contribution.  We are actually running short on
material for this paper.  So if anybody has information they
think should be in the paper, then please write an article
dealing with that specific issue.  (BOE, Redevelopment,
Police Brutality, Healthcare, children, etc.)The more specific 
information we can bring to the people, the better our chances of 
winning them over.

With that in mind, I want to push off the completion date of
this project from Tuesday to this weekend.  I'd rather have it a 
little later and better than sooner and shittier.  So let 'er rip.

Jim

Blurb on canvass: (Sam/Jim)

Volunteers for the People's Campaign collected 1000 surveys, in 
response to the question, "What do you believe is of greatest 
importance to the New Brunswick community?". This served as the basis 
for the following platform, openly debated and voted upon at the 
People's Convention this past May. These seventeen points form a 
spirited call for accountability and progressive reform. Since 
February members of the People's Campaign have canvassed the city, 
registering people to vote and getting signatures for an elected 
Board of Education.  We meet every day at the New Brunswick Public 
Library at 12 noon on Saturdays and Sundays and 6 PM during the 
week.  Come meet your neighbors and join the growing popular struggle 
for democracy!

Article on Convention: (Jim)

The New Brunswick Peoples Campaign held its history-making Convention 
on May 13th, 2000 at the Paul Robeson School, ratifying a platform 
and nominating three candidates for City Council.  Resulting from the 
many months of hard work by activists, residents, students, and 
community leaders, the Convention was a product of determination and 
dedication in the struggle for democracy.  
Uniting Democrats, Republicans, independents, revolutionaries, 
moderates, Blacks, Latinos, Whites, the young, and the old, it also 
represented the diverse array of groups in New Brunswick, coming 
together to take action against the corruption and gross injustices 
of the city machine.
The Convention was a product of the mass mobilization of the New 
Brunswick Peoples Campaign, which formed in January of this year.  
The months leading up to the Convention saw the expansion of the 
Peoples Campaign into a multi-national coalition comprised of 
residents and organizers who are fighting for democratic reform in 
New Brunswick.  Campaign organizers canvassed New Brunswick for four 
months, collecting over 1000 survey results to form a platform that 
is by the people and for the people.  The top five issues concerning 
New Brunswick's residents are rent control, police brutality, 
education, job availability and training, and youth activities.
Over 150 people attended the Convention, expressing their right to 
democracy and political decision-making.  They unanimously voted in 
favor of the Campaign platform, with their own amendments, proving 
the ability of the people to make political decisions in their own 
interests.
The Convention also chose three candidates to represent them in the 
November election for New Brunswick City Council.  The people chose 
Curtis Warren (New Brunswick Coalition Against Police Brutality), 
Keith Joseph (New Jersey Freedom Organization), and Diego Morales 
(Mexican-American labor organizer).  The three candidates took an 
oath to uphold the will of the people as expressed at the Convention, 
making them the undisputed servants of the people of New Brunswick in 
this year's election.
The multi-national composition of the Convention shows the 
willingness of the people to unite across cultural and ethic lines, 
fighting together for their common interests.  The Latino Committee 
formed at the Convention, composed of more than 30 individuals, and 
nominated candidates from their communities.  Joined by Blacks and 
Euro-Americans, the Convention reflected the cultural and racial 
composition of New Brunswick.
The New Brunswick Peoples Campaign is more than this year's election 
or the three individuals running for City Council, and this is 
evidenced by the enthusiasm and turnout at the Convention.  It is the 
beginning of a mass-based movement that will shake the wealthy 
controllers of New Brunswick from their lofty heights.  The seizure 
of City Council by the people will sound the trumpet of defeat for 
the rulers of New Jersey's cities.  People's Campaigns must spread 
like brush fire -- across the city, across New Jersey, and across the 
country.  Starting in New Brunswick we will light the fire that will 
blaze the path to the overthrow of our oppressors.

Campaign and National Politics: (Keith Joseph)

The first election in United States allowed only 4% of the population 
to vote. You had to own property, you had to be a man and you had to 
be white.  96% of the population did not qualify.  They were women, 
Afro-American, Native Americans, and white men without property. Even 
then America was hailed as a democracy yet the majority of people in 
the country were not allowed to vote. They were ruled by a class of 
property owning white men. 
Since then progress has been: made the civil rights movement, the 
women's suffrage movement extended the right to vote, but for the 
most part the majority of people are stilled ruled by that same tiny 
class. In New Brunswick this has become obvious to many.  Johnson and 
Johnson and other large corporations and banks control the city 
government through the "Democratic" Party machine, and non-
governmental organizations like New Brunswick Tomorrow and  DevCo. 
Across the United States cities are changing.  "Redevelopment" is 
the "politically correct" code word for the ethnic cleansing of our 
cities.  Cities in America used to be the homes of working people of 
all different nationalities.  Now the wealthiest few  want to turn 
the cities into their elite amusement parks, shopping, restaurants 
and theatre.  None of it is affordable or accessible to working 
people.  None of it will be owned by small business people who live 
in New Brunswick.  As "Redevelopment" rolls on more and more of New 
Brunswick's small business are being driven out to make room 
for "National Stores".  In New Brunswick, the politicians of Johnson 
and Johnson are planning the demolition of Memorial Homes.  Yet, they 
have no plans for the relocation of the people in New Brunswick. They 
want the people to leave town. They require a brutal police force 
that can terrorize people who do not follow along with their plans. 
They require a failing school system so that parents will want to 
leave town in search of a good public education for their children.  
We must organize a resistance and struggle to seize political power.  
The People's Campaign is a multi-national, multi-racial organization 
of working people, small business owners, students, and middle class 
people who have come together to work for a different redevelopment 
plan.  We want good schools and recreation and cultural activities 
for the youth. We want an end to police brutality. We want 
redevelopment that puts the people before the profits the of Johnson 
and Johnson. The People's Campaign is about our platform and getting 
it effect.  Our candidates and our organization are tools to win our 
program.

>the ability of the people to make political decisions in their own
>interests.
>The Convention also chose three candidates to represent them in the
>November election for New Brunswick City Council.  The people chose
>Curtis Warren (New Brunswick Coalition Against Police Brutality),
>Keith Joseph (New Jersey Freedom Organization), and Diego Morales
>(Mexican-American labor organizer).  The three candidates took an
>oath to uphold the will of the people as expressed at the Convention,
>making them the undisputed servants of the people of New Brunswick in
>this year's election.
>The multi-national composition of the Convention shows the
>willingness of the people to unite across cultural and ethic lines,
>fighting together for their common interests.  The Latino Committee
>formed at the Convention, composed of more than 30 individuals, and
>nominated candidates from their communities.  Joined by Blacks and
>Euro-Americans, the Convention reflected the cultural and racial
>composition of New Brunswick.
>The New Brunswick Peoples Campaign is more than this year's election
>or the three individuals running for City Council, and this is
>evidenced by the enthusiasm and turnout at the Convention.  It is the
>beginning of a mass-based movement that will shake the wealthy
>controllers of New Brunswick from their lofty heights.  The seizure
>of City Council by the people will sound the trumpet of defeat for
>the rulers of New Jersey's cities.  People's Campaigns must spread
>like brush fire -- across the city, across New Jersey, and across the
>country.  Starting in New Brunswick we will light the fire that will
>blaze the path to the overthrow of our oppressors.
>
>Campaign and National Politics: (Keith Joseph)
>
>The first election in United States allowed only 4% of the population
>to vote. You had to own property, you had to be a man and you had to
>be white.  96% of the population did not qualify.  They were women,
>Afro-American, Native Americans, and white men without property. Even
>then America was hailed as a democracy yet the majority of people in
>the country were not allowed to vote. They were ruled by a class of
>property owning white men.
>Since then progress has been: made the civil rights movement, the
>women's suffrage movement extended the right to vote, but for the
>most part the majority of people are stilled ruled by that same tiny
>class. In New Brunswick this has become obvious to many.  Johnson and
>Johnson and other large corporations and banks control the city
>government through the "Democratic" Party machine, and non-
>governmental organizations like New Brunswick Tomorrow and  DevCo.
>Across the United States cities are changing.  "Redevelopment" is
>the "politically correct" code word for the ethnic cleansing of our
>cities.  Cities in America used to be the homes of working people of
>all different nationalities.  Now the wealthiest few  want to turn
>the cities into their elite amusement parks, shopping, restaurants
>and theatre.  None of it is affordable or accessible to working
>people.  None of it will be owned by small business people who live
>in New Brunswick.  As "Redevelopment" rolls on more and more of New
>Brunswick's small business are being driven out to make room
>for "National Stores".  In New Brunswick, the politicians of Johnson
>and Johnson are planning the demolition of Memorial Homes.  Yet, they
>have no plans for the relocation of the people in New Brunswick. They
>want the people to leave town. They require a brutal police force
>that can terrorize people who do not follow along with their plans.
>They require a failing school system so that parents will want to
>leave town in search of a good public education for their children.
>We must organize a resistance and struggle to seize political power.
>The People's Campaign is a multi-national, multi-racial organization
>of working people, small business owners, students, and middle class
>people who have come together to work for a different redevelopment
>plan.  We want good schools and recreation and cultural activities
>for the youth. We want an end to police brutality. We want
>redevelopment that puts the people before the profits the of Johnson
>and Johnson. The People's Campaign is about our platform and getting
>it effect.  Our candidates and our organization are tools to win our
>program.
>
>
>
>

Post ID:384
Sender:ShearsToMe@...
Post Date/Time:2000-06-27 01:50:28
Subject:Re: proposal to amend the platform
Message:


Hello.  I think your proposal is fairly well-conceived.  Let me offer 
some questions / problems.  

--- In nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com, "kristina bas" <KRISBAS@h...> 
wrote:

[quote]
 
Our goal is full and meaningful employment at a living wage for all 
people in the city of new brunswick. To accomplish this, we will 
support/lead initiatives to raise the state minimum wage; we will 
actively support the right of all workers to organize for the 
purposes of collective bargaining;  and we will give businesses that 
employ a majority city residents (especially those that are 
unionized) special preference in the procurement of city contracts. 
We support funding for job training for city residents 
(especially for women and youth). We actively oppose any efforts to 
privatize public sector work. We will strongly advocate for pay 
equity policies that can begin to lessen the disparity in wages 
between workers of different genders and nationalities.

any comments/questions? can we vote on this?

[unquote]

1)  The first sentence seems to be a statement of what the _core 
value_ is, what gives form and meaning to, the proposals that 
follow.  (This is a good way to write a point in a platform, I'd 
imagine).  Is "full and meaningful employment" the best statement of 
that core value -- especially in light of the concepts that follow?

1a)  Does it sound as though the campaign is _seriously_ 
promising "full employment" on the municipal level, as a realizable 
goal?  Will it be interpreted this way?  

1b)  "Meaningful employment" -- this phrase has all sorts of 
pitfalls.  There's is a sound of elitism to it.  I think professing 
the values of fairness and providing opportunities for advancement 
and free choice of vocation is sufficient.  

2)  The last sentence reads:  "We will strongly advocate for pay 
equity policies that can begin to lessen the disparity in wages 
between workers of different genders and nationalities."  This is 
different from, but close to, merely stating sympathy for AA/EEO 
laws, regulations, hiring policies.  The point should probably be 
reconfigured to take this into account -- though I also wonder to 
what extent companies in New Brunswick, and state and federal laws, 
already mandate pay equity (and to what extent they don't).

2b) I will post a critique of the concept of "nationality", as it's 
sometimes used in the campaign, in a separate message.  For the 
moment -- I would suggest changing "genders and nationalities" to 
something like "backgrounds and genders", "gender, racial and ethnic 
backgrounds",  etc.  If nothing else, what is excluded is sexual 
orientation and religion.  

3)  This is a matter of research (Again, I would probably be inclined 
to help on on such tasks):  What leeway does a city government have 
in preferentially granting contracts?  I understand that officially 
prefering unionized firms and firms with more 'diversity' has been 
done before by municipalities (and states).  But can it be mandated 
that companies hire a certain percentage of the town's residents?
Furthermore, any given company, of course, has different echelons of 
employment.  

Some points that came to me.  Hope this is of use.  

Yours,

Jeremy

Subject:Re: Education, etc
Message:

--- In nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com, "kristina bas" <KRISBAS@h...> 
wrote:
> jeremy,
> 
> i think you bring up excellent points. overall, considering the 
revisions 
> that have been offered in the past week on some of the platform 
points, I 
> think we've reached a point in the campaign when we have to move 
beyond the 
> "sound bite" stage. that means researching our policy points and 
formulating 
> clear and informed proposals. my suggestion to you is to reword the 
> Education proposal to include what you've written. that way we can 
vote on 
> it and continue transforming our platform for the better.

Thanks.  I'll try to put something together.  I think at this point, 
similarly, that it is vital that solid arguments with strong data 
exist behind every policy statement put forward.  The strongest claim 
that can be made is that the current administration is, 'bottom 
line', incompetent despite pretenses to the contrary.  What has to be 
shown is what, in the final analysis, a city council in New Brunswick 
could really be doing with the available resources.  At minimum.  
This is a minimum that can be proven quite concretely.  

> additionally, i want to reintroduce Zofia's idea that we 
assign "point 
> people" to each topic on the platform. Experts, so to speak. i 
don't mean 
> this to sound intimidating, but i think it would be easier if one 
or two 
> people concentrated on one specific topic and made sure to research 
it 
> thoroughly. that way, when the time comes, we can be prepared to 
talk about 
> everything.

I'll abstain for the moment from making arguments either way on this -
- I don't really know enough.  

I will, however, propose this:  If someone decides that a point on 
the platform should be changed, and if there's some determinable 
level of agreement as to this, the point should be revised to say 
something more general _until a sufficiently specific and well-
researched statement can be formulated_.  The process of agreeing to 
change it, and the process of providing an alternative, are thereby 
separated as to provide ample room for discussion.  

Yours,

Jeremy

Post ID:389
Sender:timmy.o'toole@...
Post Date/Time:2000-06-28 17:44:57
Subject:Terminology
Message:


Hello.  I will try not to make this too extensive :

I would suggest that there is a good deal of rhetoric being utilized 
in the campaign that should be discussed as to its coherence, 
consistency, accuracy and appropriateness.  There are a number of 
highly anomalous phrases, words that are not commonly recognized by 
most residents of the United States, nonetheless being used as though 
they were to be taken for granted.  OR, they are not commonly used in 
the sense or context in which they're being used in the campaign.  

Rather than analyze in any depth these terms, I will simply list
them.  
I believe they all warrant conscious and open consideration:  this is 
what is required whenever any new word is introduced into a language 
in a democratic society.  

1)  Euro-American
2)  Ethnic Cleansing
3)  Nationality, Multi-National, Nation
4)  The Struggle For Democracy
5)  The People

(#4 and #5 are meant where used in certain particular ways)

Post ID:392
Sender:jmluceno@...
Post Date/Time:2000-06-30 01:34:49
Subject:Board of Education article
Message:

Here's another anchor article for the paper.  Any comments?

Jim

No education without representation!
Zofia Nowakowski

This November 7th New Brunswick residents will vote whether or not to 
have an elected Board of Education.  Parents and the community could 
have real representation and control over decisions made about the 
schools.  For too long our schools have languished.  Change is 
stymied and frustrated by mayoral vetoes and deals for Superintendent 
Larkin's buddies.  The appointed school board's hands are
tied by 
mayoral relationships to organizations receiving contracts.

For too long New Brunswick schools have had poor quality education.  
Working parents decide to send their children to live with 
grandparents to get a decent education.  Parent activists throw up 
their hands in exasperation when they cannot succeed in reforming the 
schools, eventually sending their own children outside the district.

For too long the district schools have provided educational 
opportunities that depend on which school a child attends and who 
they are.  They have actively fostered inequality in the system, with 
our tax dollars, developing semi-private schools such as the charter 
school and Science and Technology High School.

For too long parents have actively engaged the schools for change and 
have seen their ideas ignored.  Recently a site-placed management 
plan hammered out by parents, teachers, and community members was 
vetoed by Mayor Cahill.  We must have recourse when these situations 
develop, and currently no board member is in an independent position 
to speak out against this injustice.

On June 20th the Board of Education met to discuss plans to privatize 
pre-K education.  The plan required moving 3 year-olds from local 
school areas to trailers at the high school.  A privately owned 
education "client company" with non-union teachers 
and "administrators" would direct the education of these
children.  
While the board met behind closed doors, deciding the fate of our 
children's education, the People's Campaign candidates, Keith
Joseph, 
Diego Morales, and Curtis Warren, took charge of the meeting, 
addressing a crowd of 500 parents, residents, and teachers.  The 
audience took over the meeting, expressing their concerns, and 
condemning the board for standing behind neither the children nor the 
teachers' unions.  Due to public outrage, the board cancelled
plans 
for the trailers, but they still intend to privatize the pre-K 
education.

Kate Smith, president of the New Brunswick Education Association, 
said she discussed the need for a contingency plan months before.  
Her suggestions were not addressed.  Contracting additional teachers 
with Innovative Educational Programs (I.E.P.) represented a direct 
attack on our own union teachers.  It favored a corporation that has 
a track record of high turnover in the last year in the Science and 
Technology High School.

New Brunswick, along with 29 other urban "Abbott v. Burke"
districts 
has waited far too long for funding from the state to address 
overcrowded and inadequate facilities, let alone the new mandated pre-
K programs.  Keith Joseph addressed the board on this point, 
demanding that the board act as "a sword for the people rather
than a 
shield for the state."  He called on them to assist residents in 
organizing a state-wide coalition and send residents to Trenton to 
lobby for the funds.

An elected Board of Education would require members to remain 
accountable and in touch with parents and the community.  The public 
would review the school budget, rather than a Board of School 
Estimates (the mayor, two council members, and two appointed board 
members).  Also, the board would increase from 7 to 9 members.
Only 20 of New Jersey's 550 municipalities have an appointed
school 
board.  It is time that New Brunswick win democratic representation 
on its school board so our schools can experience positive change in 
the near future.











-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:393
Sender:timmy.o'toole@...
Post Date/Time:2000-07-03 17:58:51
Subject:Platform Point
Message:

Hello.

I was advised to present a possible replacement for the 'college for 
all New Brunswick graduates' point on the platform.  For reference,
it 
currently reads: 

Negotiate with Rutgers University, as a condition any city assistance 
with plans for expansion, new buildings, or new programs in the city, 
to provide open admissions and free college education to all New 
Brunswick High School graduates.

I would suggest the following alternative, to be edited or modified 
however:

"Provide enhanced access to higher education and post-high school 
vocational training for all interested New Brunswick graduates.  
Ensure that high school students receive ample assistance with and 
information on scholarship funds and educational opportunities in the 
county, state and nationwide.  Work to guarantee that economic status 
not bar youth from pursuing their life goals."    

This is fairly general -- but it seems to be appropriate to the level 
of knowledge about "what's out there for NB students after
graduation" 
that we presently possess.

I present this as a temporary measure, until something more specific 
can be put together, discussed, and voted on at a general meeting.  I 
will make an argument about this specifically relating to the 
platform's forthcoming publication in the newspaper in a separate 
message.  

Yours,

Jeremy









-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Post ID:394
Sender:timmy.o'toole@...
Post Date/Time:2000-07-03 19:23:38
Subject:Important
Message:


The newspaper, I understand, is going to be published with a complete 
copy of the platform on one of its pages.  

I would argue that the changes I proposed for the 'college education' 
point be included in upcoming publication.  And I would submit this
to 
be feasible while still respecting democracy at all levels.

Why?

1)  The newspaper will be a definitive statement on the campaign and 
its activities, its foremost piece of literature, at least for a 
number of weeks.  The next general meeting, however, won't come until 
after the newspaper has been published.  Thus there's no way to vote 
on any changes in a general meeting beforehand.

2)  I would have proposed at the last General Meeting that the 
authorization to change the platform point to something less specific 
and more inclusive _as a temporary measure_ be voted upon, had I
known 
about the above (#1) problem.

3)  I think I successfully demonstrated that the platform point as it 
currently stands is either factually flawed, or has a great potential 
to prove difficult to defend under any kind of scrutiny.  Indeed, it 
seems that the problems I pointed out, with all due respect, simply 
weren't thought of when the platform's details were voted upon.  

If I were proposing a new addition to the platform, or a new policy 
proposal instead of the thing about Rutgers, that would be different. 
But I am merely proposing that, in the name of factual accuracy, the 
proposal be replaced with something more general -- a few sentences
of 
very generic rhetoric that is almost certainly implicit in the mere 
guarantee of "College for all New Brunswick Residents".  

4)  It should be noted, furthermore, that nobody spoke up to _oppose_ 
changing that point, nor in defense of that point as it was
originally 
formulated, either at the meeting or on this list.  

In fact, I thought that a tacit agreement to replace that point with
a 
more general, rhetorical placeholder had been reached -- provided
that 
it be eventually replaced with something more specific.  

I openly welcome any criticism of my arguments.  

Yours,

Jeremy
