murdered by former Officer James Consalvo back in Sept of 1996 (covered by 
WBAI's Wake Up Morning Show and Evening News); and Keith Joseph, a Rutgers 
graduate of Philosophy and a house painter, and a senior member of NJFO.

informing people of the issues that matter most to them, continuing our door 
to door canvass, and generally making the City Machine feel the heat of the 
people taken to the street!  Most recently, the Machine's incumbent 
candidates have backed out of a debate that was being organized by the Home 
News & Tribune, as their track record of lies, corruption and scandals leave 
them with more to lose than to gain by such public exposure as a debate 
would bring. (Covered by the Star Ledger and the Home News & Tribune) Like 
the Imperialist candidates at the national level, they have shown that they 
are not interested in democracy, or in hearing the cries of the people...so 
like the national pawns of International Finance Capital, THEY GOT TO GO!!!

All Power to the People!

From the Newark Star Ledger:

                Jury decides against policeman

                10/27/00

                STAFF WRITER

                A New Brunswick policeman gambled that he could beat charges 
that he and another officer ran a brothel in the city called the Pleasure 
Dome. Yesterday he lost the gamble, and now the two officers are facing 10 
years in prison.
                After six hours of deliberation, a jury in Middlesex County 
convicted Detective James Marshall and Sgt. Marco Chinchilla, along with 
three others, on charges of operating a bordello out of a seedy warehouse at 
121 Jersey Ave. in New Brunswick.
                In convicting the officers, the jury accepted the accounts 
of an admitted prostitute and her drug-addicted former boyfriend over those 
of two decorated cops, one of whom admitted he was at the warehouse but only 
to conduct a stakeout.
                The background of their two star witnesses had worried
prosecutors. Last weekend, as lawyers for both sides
prepared their closing arguments, prosecutors offered Marshall a highly 
unusual plea agreement, according to people involved in the case: In 
exchange for pleading guilty to lesser charges, Marshall would avoid prison. 
What's more, his four co-defendants would avoid prison, also.
              Convinced he would be acquitted, Marshall refused to
plead guilty. Yesterday he stood somberly in a New Brunswick courtroom as 
the jury convicted him, Chinchilla and the three others.
                "I think they made a mistake," Marshall later said of the 
jury. "The prosecutor is a liar. The witnesses lied. I still     insist I 
didn't do anything illegal and the truth will come out."
                Marshall, 44, and Chinchilla, 41, stared intently at the 
jurors as the verdict was announced. Chinchilla continued to stand for some 
minutes but bowed his head and sat down after his mother, seated in the 
first row of the gallery, started to sob.
                Marshall, Chinchilla and businessman Luis Posadas were
convicted of conspiracy, official misconduct and promoting prostitution. 
Posadas rented the third-floor warehouse space where the brothel was 
operated under the guise of a legitimate massage parlor, known as Club 121.
                Michelle Thibeault, 31, and Joyce Sweeney, 32,     masseuses 
at the brothel, were convicted of conspiracy.  Thibeault also was convicted 
of promoting prostitution, but  Sweeney was acquitted of that charge.
                Neither Chinchilla nor his family members would discuss the 
verdict. Middlesex County Prosecutor Glenn Berman said he was pleased with 
the verdict, but he added: "The conviction of two law-enforcement officers 
is not a cause for our office to celebrate. . . . I know this case has 
caused a divide with the New Brunswick Police Department. I have already 
talked to Director (Michael) Beltranena about this. We want to heal that 
rift."
                The jury of eight men and four women deliberated
Wednesday afternoon and a short time yesterday morning a brief ending to a 
trial that lasted five weeks.
                Superior Court Judge Barnett Hoffman said he will
sentence the defendants Dec. 18. They remained free on bail, although the 
judge ordered Posadas and Chinchilla, who have passports, to surrender them.
                The two police officers, both 16-year veterans, have been 
suspended without pay since they were indicted in December 1998. Beltranena 
said the suspensions would continue and additional action against the 
officers is pending. Upon sentencing, the officers face being barred from 
work in law enforcement.
                The case against Marshall and Chinchilla was closely
followed in the law-enforcement and legal communities --
not only because of the accusation against the two officers
but because of the backgrounds of the star witnesses, Katherine Saddler, 37, 
and Robert Rogers, 32.
                "Wow. I am surprised," former Bergen County Prosecutor John 
Fahy said after hearing about the verdict. "This was a
very risky case from the prosecutor's perspective. Who's going to believe a 
hooker or a junkie as compared with a police officer?"
                But Assistant Middlesex County Prosecutor Lawrence
Welle, who tried the case, said he never doubted the witnesses.  "People who 
violate the law do not do it with priests and rabbis and persons of the 
higher echelons of society,"
                Welle said. "For one reason or another, certain people tried 
to diminish how good a case it was. While the one woman was a prostitute and 
was not in the best period of her life, and they both were using drugs, the 
information they had was credible."
                Jurors were riveted, and sometimes amused, by the
testimony of Saddler and Rogers, who described a thriving house of 
prostitution that boasted a waiting room, massage tables, showers and a VIP 
room with a canopy bed.
                Prosecutors were aware that trying to convict two police 
officers, both personable and well-liked men, would be difficult. And the 
defense compounded the task by bringing in former and current employees of 
the prosecutor's office, including police and assistant prosecutors, as 
character witnesses.
                Marshall, who headed up vice investigations, testified he 
had been in the warehouse on more than a dozen occasions to stake out an 
auto theft ring operating in a backyard garage. He said he never saw any 
evidence of prostitution. On cross-examination, he acknowledged he had never 
filed any reports pertaining to his surveillance activity.
                Chinchilla, once named Officer of the Year for his
crime-fighting efforts, told the jury he never set foot in the
warehouse during the times the state's witnesses claimed
he was there.
                In the end, said juror George Levins, the panel believed 
Saddler, even as she faces criminal charges elsewhere, and Rogers. "We 
didn't believe everything she said, but she did have
some crucial evidence. So did Bobby Rogers," Levins said.
               "The prosecution did a good job and the defense did a
good job. We looked at the evidence and felt it backed up
our verdict."

                Staff writers Jim O'Neill and Tom Haydon contributed to this 
report.

              Convinced he would be acquitted, Marshall refused to
plead guilty. Yesterday he stood somberly in a New Brunswick courtroom as 
the jury convicted him, Chinchilla and the three others.
                "I think they made a mistake," Marshall later said of the 
jury. "The prosecutor is a liar. The witnesses lied. I still     insist I 
didn't do anything illegal and the truth will come out."
                Marshall, 44, and Chinchilla, 41, stared intently at the 
jurors as the verdict was announced. Chinchilla continued to stand for some 
minutes but bowed his head and sat down after his mother, seated in the 
first row of the gallery, started to sob.
                Marshall, Chinchilla and businessman Luis Posadas were
convicted of conspiracy, official misconduct and promoting prostitution. 
Posadas rented the third-floor warehouse space where the brothel was 
operated under the guise of a legitimate massage parlor, known as Club 121.
                Michelle Thibeault, 31, and Joyce Sweeney, 32,     masseuses 
at the brothel, were convicted of conspiracy.  Thibeault also was convicted 
of promoting prostitution, but  Sweeney was acquitted of that charge.
                Neither Chinchilla nor his family members would discuss the 
verdict. Middlesex County Prosecutor Glenn Berman said he was pleased with 
the verdict, but he added: "The conviction of two law-enforcement officers 
is not a cause for our office to celebrate. . . . I know this case has 
caused a divide with the New Brunswick Police Department. I have already 
talked to Director (Michael) Beltranena about this. We want to heal that 
rift."
                The jury of eight men and four women deliberated
Wednesday afternoon and a short time yesterday morning a brief ending to a 
trial that lasted five weeks.
                Superior Court Judge Barnett Hoffman said he will
sentence the defendants Dec. 18. They remained free on bail, although the 
judge ordered Posadas and Chinchilla, who have passports, to surrender them.
                The two police officers, both 16-year veterans, have been 
suspended without pay since they were indicted in December 1998. Beltranena 
said the suspensions would continue and additional action against the 
officers is pending. Upon sentencing, the officers face being barred from 
work in law enforcement.
                The case against Marshall and Chinchilla was closely
followed in the law-enforcement and legal communities --
not only because of the accusation against the two officers
but because of the backgrounds of the star witnesses, Katherine Saddler, 37, 
and Robert Rogers, 32.
                "Wow. I am surprised," former Bergen County Prosecutor John 
Fahy said after hearing about the verdict. "This was a
very risky case from the prosecutor's perspective. Who's going to believe a 
hooker or a junkie as compared with a police officer?"
                But Assistant Middlesex County Prosecutor Lawrence
Welle, who tried the case, said he never doubted the witnesses.  "People who 
violate the law do not do it with priests and rabbis and persons of the 
higher echelons of society,"
                Welle said. "For one reason or another, certain people tried 
to diminish how good a case it was. While the one woman was a prostitute and 
was not in the best period of her life, and they both were using drugs, the 
information they had was credible."
                Jurors were riveted, and sometimes amused, by the
testimony of Saddler and Rogers, who described a thriving house of 
prostitution that boasted a waiting room, massage tables, showers and a VIP 
room with a canopy bed.
                Prosecutors were aware that trying to convict two police 
officers, both personable and well-liked men, would be difficult. And the 
defense compounded the task by bringing in former and current employees of 
the prosecutor's office, including police and assistant prosecutors, as 
character witnesses.
                Marshall, who headed up vice investigations, testified he 
had been in the warehouse on more than a dozen occasions to stake out an 
auto theft ring operating in a backyard garage. He said he never saw any 
evidence of prostitution. On cross-examination, he acknowledged he had never 
filed any reports pertaining to his surveillance activity.
                Chinchilla, once named Officer of the Year for his
crime-fighting efforts, told the jury he never set foot in the
warehouse during the times the state's witnesses claimed
he was there.
                In the end, said juror George Levins, the panel believed 
Saddler, even as she faces criminal charges elsewhere, and Rogers. "We 
didn't believe everything she said, but she did have
some crucial evidence. So did Bobby Rogers," Levins said.
               "The prosecution did a good job and the defense did a
good job. We looked at the evidence and felt it backed up
our verdict."

                Staff writers Jim O'Neill and Tom Haydon contributed to this 
report.

Post ID:735
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-30 10:52:34
Subject:Re: [nbpc] statistics?
Message:

1999 Legislative Data Book, NJ - basically, of those students entering NB high schools, how many end up graduating from there.

These stats include those students who drop out of school AND those who transfer out b/c of moving or going to a different (such as private) school system.  It is a tricky number.  The board of Ed has stated the dropout rate at 10% but upon questioning it is not clear exactly what this stands for (for ex. is it for the senior class)- you might want to try again. One teacher has said that noone knows what the real dropout rate is and this needs to be better measured. Re: transfering out of the system - It is true that we have a mobile population, but I know many people who work something out w/ nieghboring districts such as East Brunswick through a relative etc.

Dear Mr. Nader and Campaign Staff:

I write visceral and blunt urgings for your organization to reexamine your
role in the presidential election.

I submit the following as cause to back out of the race at this eleventh
hour:

1.  George Bush is a serial killer, a chronic privatizer, and an incoherent
babbler. Al Gore is not. The first two facts have most impact for minorities
who have never had the franchise in this country. Those minorities are not
voting Nader this year.

2.  Al Gore is inextricably tied to the Democratic Party, making him
accountable to local organizations around the country, not just finance
capital. That's what makes a party, independent local organizations. You
have to beat dems and reps in local elections to have a snowball's chance in
hell to win nationally.

3.  I think it's clear that your party will not win its five percent popular
vote to get federal funds, so why run anymore? There are no more gains to be
made for the national Green Party at this point.

4.  Lastly, I cite the example of Rudy "sans the little moustache" Ghouliani
in NYC. Rudy ran against Dinkins in '94. Many of the same "Left" groups who
support Nader for President ran massive publicity campaigns against Dinkins.
These groups mainly called Dinkins a sellout, sd he wasn't revolutionary
enough, called him a Tom, etc.  Dinkins was not a serial killer, a chronic
privatizer, an undying friend of the most reactionary sectors of finance
capital since Weimar Germany-- but Herr Giuliani is!!!  So these so-called
Left groups succeeded in knocking down Dinkins so much that fascist Giuliani
got elected.

Don't make the same mistake that these lefties made.  Make no mistake, Bush
likes fascism. Let's not confuse party-building with spoiler politics.

In Unity and Struggle for a vigorous independent political party,

Paul McGee, New Jersey Freedom Organization

Board member asks N.B. to vote �no�



                                           By Angus Kress Gillespie
                                           Guest Commentary


                                           Lately we�ve been hearing a lot
about an important issue facing New Brunswick
                                           voters on the Nov. 7 ballot. For

                                           residents are being asked to
consider switching to an elected school board. On

                                           �no� on the Board of Education

                                           undo all of the progress we have

                                           of politics. On Nov. 7, please

i honestly don't care if Gore is a liar. They are all liars, as far as I'm

gain achieved in this country OR do we concentrate instead on building a 
REAL third party, from the ground up???????

the argument that it may be a good thing to have bush as president because 
it will 'mobilize' the people amounts to cutting off your nose to spite your 
face. the logic truly escapes me. i don't recall any grand mobilizations 
during the reagan/ bush eras.

i used to be an admirer of Ralph Nader. Now i'm convinced that he is more 
concerned with individual fame and celebrity than with any real 
party-building or seizing of power on behalf of working people.

plus, people should start paying attention to some of his political lines. 
like his statement this week that if R-v-W is thrown out by the Supreme 
Court it wouldn't really be that big of a problem cuz it would 'revert back 
to the states anyway'. wow. that makes me feel better. (see NY Times, 
October 31, 2000 "Democrats Ask Nader to Back Gore in Swing States")

if he really cared about the American people, he would REALIZE how fucking 
important it is that we do not wake up on november 8 with GW as president.

are matching funds the ultimate goal here? if everyone who's so concerned 
with 'voting with their conscience' would get out of their arm chairs and 
start organizing their communities locally so that third parties begin to 
sweep local elections, then we'd truly be on the path to something new. 
otherwise, it amounts to protest in the comfort of your voting booth.

> >the board. There are no campaigns, no campaign
> >                                            contributions, no special
> >interest influence and no self-promotion by elected
> >                                            school board members at the
> >expense of our children.
> >
> >                                            The board is made up of people
> >just like me, whose only interest is to provide our
> >                                            children with the best possible
> >education at a cost our residents can afford. So if
> >                                            youre a New Brunswick resident
> >and intend to vote on this ballot question, I
> >                                            hope you will join me in
> >rejecting the efforts of political candidates attempting to
> >                                            undo all of the progress we
> >have
> >made with a board that puts our children ahead
> >                                            of politics. On Nov. 7, please
> >say No to politics in our schools and vote no on
> >                                            the Board of Education
> >question.
> >
> >                                            Angus Kress Gillespie, Ph.D.,
> >is
> >a professor of American studies and a member
> >                                            of the New Brunswick Board of
> >Education.
> >

Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-31 14:07:09
Subject:A coincidence?
Message:

Nine women, 1 man arrested in prostitution sweep 
Published in the Home News Tribune 10/31/00

By KEN SERRANO
STAFF WRITER 

NEW BRUNSWICK: A police sweep targeting Commercial Avenue street walkers over the weekend resulted in nine women being arrested for prostitution and related charges and one man for seeking their services. 
Michael Beltranena Jr., director of police for New Brunswick, said residents' complaints of prostitution in the area sparked the weekend operation, although similar sweeps are carried out periodically. 

Arrested on prostitution charges were city women Renee Tillman, 42, of Hale Street; Jannen Sharp, 31, who gave her address as the Howard Johnson Hotel on Route 1; Lisa Williams, 40, of Elm Row; Maltha Baker, 34, of Suydam Street; Michelle Fama, 31 of Comstock Street, and Winafred Washington, 37, of Reservoir Avenue. Also facing prostitution chares is Chris Anne Ciandella, 37, of Monmouth Junction. 

The women were charged after they solicited undercover officers posing as customers, according to officials. 

Wanda Rogers, 30, and Reni Schneier, 33, both of Comstock Street, were arrested on charges of loitering for prostitution purposes. 
The women either posted or were held in lieu of bail set at between $975 and $5,000. 

Louis Rojas-Vindas, 30, of Quentin Avenue in the city was charged with seeking the services of a prostitute and released. Earlier this month, the city agreed to establish an outreach program to try to get prostitutes off the streets as the result of a lawsuit brought by the family of Carolyn Adams. Adams, a 39-year-old prostitute, was fatally shot by a city police officer in 1996. 
But these women will not be candidates yet. The program is not up and running. The "Change a Life" program will include medical treatment, career counseling and child care. 

from the Home News Tribune 
Published: October 31, 2000

Rhetoric, by definition, in the context I used it in, means as follows :  

rhetoric : language that is elaborate, pretentious, insincere, or intellectually vacuous, inflated language, pomposity.

Gillespie's article is conservative, in the sense that it aims to preserve the existing structure.  But 'rhetoric', a la Paul, it is not.  It is rather informative by comparison.

If you can't see that, Kristina, then it is pretty obvious that your bias transcends judgement by merit.  Given that circumstance, I would not trust you to be involved in any sort of government, where it is necessary to be objective, and not simplistically separate everything into 'us' and 'the machine.'  Or perhaps you see yourselves as 'good' while 'the machine' represents 'evil', the former infallible while the latter must invariably be malicious?

If it weren't for people like Zofia on the campaign, who put thought and compassion into their balanced judgements, the 'machine' would really start looking like the voice of reason.  Fanatics ruin the best intentions.

Chris

>From: Erin Smith <esmith@...>
>To: 'Tom Murphy' <murphman6000@...>, Wayne Cosney

>gavin  <rhinoqueen420@...>, "'galaxygirl420@...'"  
><galaxygirl420@...>
>Subject: Presidential Race Info
>Date: Tue, 31 Oct 2000 14:40:05 -0500
>
>
>Here is an un-biased article on Naders effect on the current Presidential
>race.  This article is from Salon.com, an online magazine. Not from Naders
>website or Gores or any other political figure that is trying to win this
>race. It's kind of long. Sorry about that.  Just give it a quick read. 
>There
>is some interesting stuff here.
>
>(sorry Tom)
>
>
>
>Unsafe in any state
>Ralph Nader's campaign is reckless, its justifications specious and its
>consequences possibly irreparable. But it does allow fundamentalist 
>leftists
>to keep living in their dream world.
>
>- - - - - - - - - - - -
>By Todd Gitlin
>
>Oct. 28, 2000 | The Gore-Bush contest has been as uninspired as it is
>overfinanced, a spectacle as tedious as it is dumbed-down (sorry, "on
>message"). So we arrive at that quadrennial moment when the disgruntled get
>tired of hitchhiking and look to their own vehicles. As citizen-viewers
>stream away from the presidential debates wishing out loud that they could
>vote for someone -- anyone -- other than the major party candidates, enter
>Ralph Nader on the Green ticket, apparently safe at any speed. No one
>accuses Nader of taking funny money, phonying his r�sum�, being out of his
>depth, talking down or making himself over too frequently. He bashes
>corporations like nobody's business, more rightly than wrongly.
>
>I'm the sort of voter who ought to be flocking to him. I was the third
>president of Students for a Democratic Society, active in New Left politics
>thereafter, frequently critical of Clinton-Gore politics from the left. I
>think the drug war is a disaster, the Colombia intervention wrongheaded,
>insurance companies and HMOs cruel and unnecessary punishment, big-money
>giveaways to media tycoons indefensible, free trade oversold, labor
>underprotected. Oh yes: Along the way, I stayed out of the 1968 vote -- and
>therefore, in the light of unforgiving history, did my tiny bit to help
>Nixon win, and all for the best of reasons, namely, emotions in revolt,
>disgust for Humphrey's pro-war position, and willful blindness about the
>left's marginality and the political payoff that could be expected for 
>going
>it alone.
>
>
>
>
>----------------------------------------------------------------------------
>----
>
>
>Here we go again. The arguments for Nader's campaign are dubious, a vote 
>for
>him reckless and the consequences of building him up severe and possibly
>irreversible. As I write, Nader strength in Oregon and Minnesota looks like
>enough to move those states into the Bush column; Nader could also matter 
>in
>Wisconsin, Michigan, Washington, even California. The outcome might well 
>be,
>with a few other states, catastrophic -- and not only for the next four
>years. Just as much of the ground lost to Reagan in the 1980s has never 
>been
>regained -- repeat, never: not in 20 years, not on labor policy, not on the
>environment, not on income and wealth inequality, not on support for
>military goons in the poor countries -- the ground to be lost by a
>Republican victory is likely to stay lost. As for the arguments about 
>what's
>to be gained by a big Nader turnout, they dissolve on inspection.
>
>What kind of case is made for the Nader vote? We hear, first of all, the
>notion that Gore and Bush, or Democrats and Republicans, are essentially 
>the
>same -- two names for the same Republicrats. Yet how a thoughtful person 
>can
>think the differences are negligible boggles the mind.
>
>
>Global warming? Gore knows it's happening, Bush isn't sure. Gore wanted a
>tax on fossil-fuel energy -- a tax that was blocked by Republicans and
>always will be -- while Bush governs over the worst air in the country and
>justifies it on the grounds of industrial growth. Gore knows the arguments
>against oil drilling; Bush looks at Alaska and sees barrels. Gore's an
>environmentalist who makes political deals; Bush is half of an
>all-oil-company team. No difference?
>
>
>The Supreme Court? Bush's favorite justices are Antonin Scalia and Clarence
>Thomas. He owes the Christian right bigger than big-time. The Bush court,
>one-third of whose membership he might get to appoint, might not repeal Roe
>vs. Wade, not quite, not yet, but would surely tilt mightily toward states'
>rights and corporate power, against labor, against gun control, against
>affirmative action.
>
>
>The nitty-gritty government that shapes public life in a thousand ways
>outside public attention? The National Labor Relations Board, the
>Occupational Safety and Health Administration, the Civil Rights Commission
>and hundreds of other boards that make crucial decisions, most of them
>outside the glare of sound-bite-besotted media, affecting every aspect of
>everyday life. See above. Bush will owe the fundamentalists, the
>union-busters, the South Carolina Confederate flag-fliers.
>
>Labor? Gore owes the AFL-CIO for its early support; Bush doesn't owe a 
>thing
>-- to the contrary. Gore's party has pushed up the minimum wage (not nearly
>high enough), Bush's couldn't care less. Despite the NAFTA loss, labor has
>started to regain strength because the Labor Relations Board has been more
>hospitable to organizers. Now? The Republican Party -- who might well end 
>up
>controlling both houses of Congress as well as the White House -- have
>negative interest in organized labor. They'll rig what they can for the
>bosses. That's what Republicans do.
>
>
>Poverty? Inequality? The Republicans practice class warfare from above. The
>Democrats are divided, but despite inconsistencies, President Clinton is
>responsible for an earned income tax credit, and finally, belatedly, the
>appalling inequality between rich and poor is shrinking, unemployment is 
>low
>(and for African-Americans and Latinos, unprecedentedly so).
>
>Nuclear weapons? Bush is for abrogating the anti-ballistic-missile treaty.
>He loves Star Wars. His party crushed the nuclear test ban. Gore has been
>flabby, alas, on these issues, but he is budgeable. Bush lacks even 
>Reagan's
>nutty antinuclear utopianism.
>
>I have not even mentioned the limited (but scarcely unimportant) issues the
>candidates talk about: the Social Security hoax Bush wants to perpetrate;
>the Bush tax cut that Puts Billionaires First; affirmative action, which
>Bush wants to end, not mend; campaign corruption (sorry, "finance"), the
>auctioning off of access and bias at which W. is so spectacular that he did
>not even need the Lincoln Bedroom -- he could offer an entire government.
>
>And none of this is to mention the person whom Nader stands poised to tip
>into power -- the lazy, intellectually slovenly Bush, the Bush who sneers 
>at
>the "Buddhist temple" (would he denounce a church fundraiser with quite 
>that
>curl of the lip?), the fumbling, evasive, thickheaded Bush, the 
>disingenuous
>Bush, the deceiving, dynastic Bush who aims to ratify stupidity as a
>qualification for high office.
>
>We come to the claim that a Nader vote is costless because his candidacy
>creates its own constituency, bringing masses hitherto demobilized (and
>rationally so) out of the woodwork. Turnout is surely important, especially
>for the unregistered blue-collar voters, but waiting for a rescue mission
>from suddenly lefty voters is the political equivalent of the beam-me-up
>wishfulness practiced by millennial cults -- and it has the same function.
>The trouble is, there's no persuasive evidence that large numbers of voters
>have been staying home because they've lacked a left-wing alternative.
>That's not the country we're living in.
>
>We have some recent and relevant experience to consider. Liberals supported
>(rightly) the motor voter bill to make registration easier, a bill that
>George H.W. Bush vetoed twice and President Clinton signed, not just on
>principle, but in the hope that the poor would register and vote to the
>left. That hope was more vain than not. It didn't happen. Most scholars
>who've studied the subject believe that people who don't vote have the same
>views as people who do. In the real world, Nader is plainly picking up
>support from Gore (not least because of Gore's lummox debate performances).
>Minnesota is one state where, last week, Bush had, surprisingly, crept 
>ahead
>of Gore in a statewide poll, and, according to the Minneapolis 
>Star-Tribune,
>"Nader has eroded Gore's base of support by attracting one-fifth of
>liberals, young voters and independents -- and one in 10 Democrats." Maybe
>it's not true in other states. Maybe it is. Maybe it's true enough in the
>right (or wrong) states to throw the election to Bush.
>
>In limited and belated recognition that there are real costs to a Green
>vote, some now propose "strategic voting" and urge people who live in 
>states
>where Gore-Bush poll margins are great to cast their ballots for Nader
>believing that they will not thereby be spoiling Gore's electoral vote. 
>This
>is supposed to be a free vote, but there is no such thing as a free vote.
>That calculated vote is both morally problematic and politically
>short-sighted. Letting the polls make up your mind for you conditions a
>moral choice on the presupposition that polls are reliable (when in fact
>they are swinging all over the place), and amounts, moreover, to a sudden
>burst of pragmatism from people who ordinarily despise the pragmatism of
>Gore support.
>
>Then, on practical grounds, we hear that a Nader vote builds up popular
>support for the Greens so they can get to 5 percent and therefore receive
>federal funds in 2004. Suppose, for the sake of argument, that Nader does
>get 5 percent, and the Greens get federal funds in future elections. Then
>what? On the off-chance that the Greens can avoid breaking into warring
>camps, � la the Reform Party, what they can realistically look forward to 
>is
>someday becoming, say, an 8 percent party. And then? After at least one 
>term
>of Republican rule, with its unambiguous passion for big oil, against a
>nuclear test ban, for Star Wars, against labor organizing, for HMO's, for
>kindness toward the Pinochets of the world, etc., maybe eight years on we
>get to -- 9 percent? 11 percent? The odds are for shrinkage, not increase,
>in a third party. This is a doomed enterprise. The Constitution is
>decisively tilted against it. In parliamentary systems, a single-digit 
>party
>can win seats, enter governments, make policy -- as witness the Greens in
>Germany and elsewhere in Europe. But in the American winner-take-all
>presidential system -- which is not going away -- the payoff for a
>third-party effort is the chance to be a spoiler again.
>
>There's worse. The so-called strategic vote, by lowering Gore's popular
>vote, helps undermine his popular mandate if he does win, thus dashing the
>prospects for progressive hopes -- as Clinton's 43 percent victory in 1992
>weakened his own popular base for egalitarian policies like "don't ask,
>don't tell." Like Bush, Nader supporters choose to forget that many of
>Clinton's stronger initiatives -- even his small, earnest "stimulus 
>package"
>of 1993 -- banged up against a Republican wall in Congress. Had Clinton 
>been
>bolstered by an electoral majority -- not to mention a better Congress, 
>many
>of whose Democrats were barely that -- he could have made better use of the
>bully pulpit. (He should have tried anyway.)
>
>Does voting for a third party contribute to "building a movement"? Claims 
>of
>this sort are always made by charismatic figures. The results are never --
>never -- delivered. The claim amounts to feel-good rhetoric to rationalize 
>a
>heady campaign. Tomorrow never comes. It is a parochial fantasy.
>
>Nader's claim that he's not the spoiler is bad faith. Perhaps he knows it,
>perhaps not. But there is a deeper force at work. What is at work in the
>Naderite camp, what lies behind the fantasy that the masses hanker for
>radical change, is a purist approach to politics. There are Nader 
>supporters
>-- as well as Democrats of the left like Michigan's John Conyers -- who 
>have
>urged Nader to drop his campaign in the states where he might throw the 
>race
>to Gore. He's refused. He shows no inclination to deal. (Neither,
>unfortunately, does Gore.) But deal-making is how politics happens.
>
>At bottom, Nader's all-or-nothing gambit is not politics, it is moral
>fundamentalism -- as if by venting one's anger, one were free to remake the
>world by willing it so, despite all those recalcitrant people who happen to
>live here.
>
>The arrogance of this "worsism" -- the worse, the better -- is chillingly
>expressed by a Nader voter in Portland, Ore., interviewed in Friday's New
>York Times: "If Bush gets in, I feel that it might bring things to a head
>much more quickly. Pollution's going to increase in the short term, but I
>think that will bring a lot more people into the environmental movement a
>lot more quickly. Sometimes you've got to hit bottom before you come back
>up." Notice how the means -- "a lot more people into the environmental
>movement" -- has become the end. Notice the spurious assumption that the
>masses will rise up if things come "to a head." It didn't happen after
>Reagan's depredations on the environment. It won't happen now. As for the
>Nader movement, it's well-meaning and broad but an inch deep. In Eric
>Alterman's trenchant words in the Nation, Nader's "nascent leftist movement
>has virtually no support among African-Americans, Latinos or
>Asian-Americans. It has no support among organized feminist groups,
>organized gay rights groups or mainstream environmental groups. To top it
>all off, it has no support in the national union movement. So Nader and
>company are building a nonblack, non-Latino, non-Asian, nonfeminist,
>nonenvironmentalist, nongay, non-working people's left: Now that really
>would be quite an achievement."
>
>On Earth, the only land ahead is the compromised land. Politics means
>satisfactions and dissatisfactions, not redemptions. There is this truth: 
>We
>are condemned to share the Earth with people we dislike, even despise. In a
>democracy, we are condemned to share power with them. A large party -- any
>large party -- is a coalition of interests. Imagine the Democrats away and
>replace them with a left-wing party, and it would still be a coalition of
>interests heading for disappointment. The question about the actually
>existing Democrats is this: How to make them more green, more
>labor-friendly, less punitive? And the prerequisite -- not the guarantee,
>but the prerequisite -- is a vote for Democrats, starting with Al Gore.
>
>True enough, after getting a boost from his "the people vs. the powerful"
>convention speech, Gore moved fitfully toward the center, and one can fight
>against his position on capital punishment and prisons, his trimming on gun
>control -- dispute all this and more far more effectively if he is 
>president
>than not. If Nader had run in the primaries, or half the Naderite energy
>went to organizing a Million Human March to welcome Gore to Washington the
>day after he's inaugurated, we on the left would stand a reasonable chance
>of seeing a Gore more to our liking. He is, as his fans and enemies all
>agree, a politician. No one accuses the man of being inflexible.
>
>Of course the parties are corrupt fundraising machines. Of course corporate
>lobbies run amok. Of course the Democrats need pressure. The question is,
>Whom do we want to put in a position to press? The choice of who will write
>the agenda, appoint the judges, negotiate (or tear up) the treaties,
>starting Jan. 20, 2001, is not between Al Gore and Jesus Christ, or, in
>fact, between Al Gore or Ralph Nader. In America, we're not going to get a
>president better than Gore. We may well get a lot worse: a country-club
>airhead whose occasional rhetoric of compassion obscures the fact that his
>deepest, most abiding, most consistent compassion is for untrammeled
>business. We could slam a lot of doors. Consider the choice uninspiring, 
>but
>there it is, and will not be wished away -- not by fulminating against
>corporations, not by imagining a mass movement, not by assuming that one
>shirks responsibility for bad consequences because others have a monopoly 
>on
>evil while we, we noble ones, we happy new, are pure, as George W. Bush
>would say, of heart.
>
>
>salon.com | Oct. 28, 2000

Post ID:763
Sender:"Mathew Levi" <ml@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-10-31 19:25:44
Subject:Re: [nbpc] RE: THE NADER FACTOR
Message:

An open invitation to debate.  Cool. :-)

Well, I disagree with the idea that a 'leftist-minded' person should vote
strategically for Gore, rather than vote on principle for Nader.  The
principle is simple:  one should not vote for a candidate whom one thinks is
'evil,' no matter how much less an evil.  In terms of actual policy, it is
true that a vote for Nader, which could potentially lead to a Bush victory,
would do harm for this country.  I have several things to say about this.

First of all, the actual damage this would do in terms of policy:  it's not
so drastic as it seems.  Bush is not a fascist, he's an old-style
conservative, old because he talks like a broken record and his policies are
pretty predictable.  But is Gore all that much different?  In truth, there
are few areas of some difference.  One is the Supreme Court:  Bush would
attempt to nominate conservative Christian-types, while Gore would
supposedly nominate liberals.  There is truth to this, but let's not get
carried away:  the Democrat-controlled Congress is to thank for Scalia,
Thomas, and others whose nomination they endorsed.  Lieberman, who is no
atheist himelf, has said on two occasions that he would have voted for
Bork's nomination.  Bork is worse than anyone on the Court now.

Another area of difference is gun control, and Clinton was able to get
somewhere with this, although not far.  But I think any serious improvement
is going to have to come through litigation, with the attack on the tobacco
industry as the model.  I can't think of too many other differences.
Abortion depends on the Court, but then again the Democratic Congress under
Reagan/Bush is partially to blame.  Health care is nowhere, despite
Clinton's best efforts;  the death penalty is wholly endorsed by Gore; the
environment is hardly an issue anymore, especially to Gore who is awash in
corporate sponsorship;  welfare policy was severely curtailed under Clinton.
The most important non-difference between the candidate is international
policy, which is identical:  the Pentagon hardly has much to fear from Gore.

By voting strategically for Gore, we do more than keep Bush out.  We give
him our consent:  he represents 'us.'  We all know this is a joke, that the
two-party system plays on our fears.  Yet, what motivation does Gore have to
do anything except move further to the right, more toward the so-called
'middle' of the political spectrum, the summit of the population pyramid?
Under Clinton/Gore, many 'progressive causes' were lost: welfare was rolled
back, we've bombed the hell out of a country illegally and immorally, and
we've watched the wealth gap increase.  It's a trend - Gore will hardly
'preserve' anything except his standing in his corporate sponsors' eyes.  On
the other hand, if the Democrats lose they will have no choice but think
'strategically' themselves, and at least move a bit more to the left.  If
we're lucky, perhaps the Greens will grow and grow over the long-term, and
one day the average person of this country will be able to live in a real
social democracy, instead of a backwards laissez-faire system with
institutionalized corruption and a government working hand-in-glove with its
corporate sponsors.

Matt

Subject:Nader Factor--MY 2 CENTS

Some comments for the record:

>Unsafe in any state
>Ralph Nader's campaign is reckless, its justifications specious and its
>consequences possibly irreparable. But it does allow fundamentalist 
>leftists to keep living in their dream world.
>
>- - - - - - - - - - - -
>By Todd Gitlin
>
>Oct. 28, 2000 | Oh yes: Along the way, I stayed out of the 1968 vote -- and 
>therefore, in the light of unforgiving history, did my tiny bit to help 
>Nixon win, and all for the best of reasons, namely, emotions in revolt, 
>disgust for Humphrey's pro-war position, and willful blindness about the 
>left's marginality and the political payoff that could be expected for 
>going it alone.
>

(Matthew writes:) A preface:  I believe this is a reference to 
anti-war/civil-rights movement people who opted agianst the "lesser of two 
evils" line, (much like the Nader-ites/Greens) thereby ushering in Nixon, 
and the ensuing widespread FBI surveillance, infiltration and systematic 
dismantling of leftist, progressive and revolutionary organizations form 
Student Non-Violent Coordinating Committee (SNCC) to Labor Unions to the 
Black Panther Party for Self-Defense (AKA: CoIntelPro).  If anyone knows 
more about this, please speak up.
>
>

>We come to the claim that a Nader vote is costless because his candidacy
>creates its own constituency, bringing masses hitherto demobilized (and
>rationally so) out of the woodwork. Turnout is surely important, especially
>for the unregistered blue-collar voters, but waiting for a rescue mission
>from suddenly lefty voters is the political equivalent of the beam-me-up
>wishfulness practiced by millennial cults -- and it has the same function.
>The trouble is, there's no persuasive evidence that large numbers of voters
>have been staying home because they've lacked a left-wing alternative.
>That's not the country we're living in.
>

(Matthew) Right and wrong:  Nader's campaign has certainly been rushed. I 
received an email at the beginning of this summer that Nader was "really in 
it this time".  I was wondering where he had been for the last 3 1/2 years 
since his last run (read:walk) for presidency. And this gets to my biggest 
criticism of the Green Party/Nader campaign: They're trying to go for the 
head (ie: the throne) before they build up the body (a real mass movement)  
But, this is where our author friend goes wrong.  There's an immense amount 
of evidence that voters have been staying home for lack of a candidate that 
truly represents their interests.  First of all, the huge rallies of support 
that Nader has been getting is the most immediate indicator.  Also, most 
people are simply not benifiting from this golden-calf economy.  All the 
corporate downsizing means that countless people are put out of work, real 
wages are far lower than they were 20 or 30 years ago, job security is 
practically nonexistant, more people are working 2 and 3 jobs without the 
benifits, and if you haven't noticed the lack of democracy in the inner 
cities, then reconsider the meriad of marches and protests against police 
brutality in cities all over the country...these are people for whom 
low-income housing is being replaced with prisons.


>Then, on practical grounds, we hear that a Nader vote builds up popular
>support for the Greens so they can get to 5 percent and therefore receive
>federal funds in 2004. Suppose, for the sake of argument, that Nader does
>get 5 percent, and the Greens get federal funds in future elections. Then
>what? On the off-chance that the Greens can avoid breaking into warring
>camps, � la the Reform Party, what they can realistically look forward to 
>is
>someday becoming, say, an 8 percent party. And then? After at least one 
>term
>of Republican rule, with its unambiguous passion for big oil, against a
>nuclear test ban, for Star Wars, against labor organizing, for HMO's, for
>kindness toward the Pinochets of the world, etc., maybe eight years on we
>get to -- 9 percent? 11 percent? The odds are for shrinkage, not increase,
>in a third party. This is a doomed enterprise.


This is where our author really lets his cynicism get the best of him.  The 
fact is that it would be an amazing and historic leap foward if the Greens 
got 5% of the vote (guaranteed Bush looses) But until Nov 7th at 8pm, this 
is amounts to reckless speculation and fantasizing for a quick solution to 
our country's deep social and economic problems.  IT AMOUNTS TO PLAYING 
RUSSIAN ROULLET WITH THE LIVES OF THE MOST VULNERABLE SECTIONS OF OUR 
POPULATION WHO WILL BE TROUNCED BY A BUSH VICTORY!

But we do indeed need a legitamate 3rd party movement. Again, the 
Green/Nader campaign should have been building up a UNITED FRONT/COALITION 
grassroots movement for the last 4 years, buy they haven't.  I saw Nader & 
Co. speak in Newark last week, and to be brutally honest, the audience 
didn't look a thing like Newark! It was primarily marginalized middle-class 
lefties from the 'burbs who came to Newark to declair themselves the 
People's Choice!  Bull-shit! Newark has a such deep and broad history of 
political and social struggle, countless community organizations that have 
for years taken on the "powers that be" fighting for more democracy and 
community control over the city's institutions.  Why weren't they 
represented?  The only Newark organization that I saw was the People's 
Organization for Progress, which has historically struggled against police 
brutality in Essex County and beyond.  A true third party movement has to 
include the entire spectrum of grassroots organizations, labor unions, 
student organizations, etc, etc. not one group or party to jump up at the 
11th hour and play savior at the risk of fucking us all for the next four 
years and more!


The Constitution is
>decisively tilted against it. In parliamentary systems, a single-digit 
>party
>can win seats, enter governments, make policy -- as witness the Greens in
>Germany and elsewhere in Europe. But in the American winner-take-all
>presidential system -- which is not going away -- the payoff for a
>third-party effort is the chance to be a spoiler again.
>


This is true and extremely important as we consider what it will mean to 
democratize the United States.  The only possible way that we can create the 
scope of change that is called for is to have a political aperatus 
completely entrenched in a broad based mass movement that is prepared to 
back up a call, let's say to abolish the Electoral College, or for that 
matter, the millionare's club called the Senate!


>
>Does voting for a third party contribute to "building a movement"? Claims 
>of
>this sort are always made by charismatic figures. The results are never --
>never -- delivered. The claim amounts to feel-good rhetoric to rationalize 
>a
>heady campaign. Tomorrow never comes. It is a parochial fantasy.
>

Too true, too true!


>Nader's claim that he's not the spoiler is bad faith. Perhaps he knows it,
>perhaps not. But there is a deeper force at work. What is at work in the
>Naderite camp, what lies behind the fantasy that the masses hanker for
>radical change, is a purist approach to politics.


Check it out: At the Nader forum, that jerk who's running for NJ Senate for 
the Greens, Bruce Afrin, had the nerve to get up on stage and moralize about 
Corzine trying to buy a Senate seat (no kidding), claiming it would be 
better to have an "honest conservative"!  I quote: "I will be proud if my 
campaign causes Jon Corzine to lose the election" Afrin's lucky he didn't 
leave the Brick City with a brick up side his head.


>The arrogance of this "worsism" -- the worse, the better -- is chillingly
>expressed by a Nader voter in Portland, Ore., interviewed in Friday's New
>York Times: "If Bush gets in, I feel that it might bring things to a head
>much more quickly. Pollution's going to increase in the short term, but I
>think that will bring a lot more people into the environmental movement a
>lot more quickly. Sometimes you've got to hit bottom before you come back
>up." Notice how the means -- "a lot more people into the environmental
>movement" -- has become the end. Notice the spurious assumption that the
>masses will rise up if things come "to a head." It didn't happen after
>Reagan's depredations on the environment. It won't happen now.


Yeah, this really get me too.  It's very telling that so many Nader 
supporters that I speak to make this claim, to-wit: Even if Nader causes 
Bush to win, it will bring the revolution on because people will have a 
clear enemy.   This is more "quick sollution"-ism!  An instant movement in 
Nader, and if not, an instant movement in Bush!  This is sort of impatient 
and whimsical "organizing" is dangerous and stupid.  It is put out by people 
who don't want to commit to the real, bare-knuckels, down-to-earth, 
day-to-day struggle to build a strong, sustainable movement, And, dare I 
say, it is a line put out by people who generally have access to at least 
basic resources and modest levels of democracy--who aren't worst hit by the 
lack of democracy that is supposed to usher in the up-rising.  Look, if 
people are out of work, they will be tired most of the time just trying to 
make ends meet and feed the kids, probably too tired to fight.  However, 
more democracy, such as low unemployment and strong unions empowers people 
and gives them strength and the idea that they can win...therefor they will 
fight harder.  Same goes for inner cities where less democracy means more 
people in prison, schools falling apart, and more CIA-shipped drugs on the 
street.  I've never heard any of these folks say, "Heck, I hope that cop 
comes over here and wacks me with his billy-club...THEN the revolution will 
come!"


As for the
>Nader movement, it's well-meaning and broad but an inch deep. In Eric
>Alterman's trenchant words in the Nation, Nader's "nascent leftist movement
>has virtually no support among African-Americans, Latinos or
>Asian-Americans. It has no support among organized feminist groups,
>organized gay rights groups or mainstream environmental groups. To top it
>all off, it has no support in the national union movement. So Nader and
>company are building a nonblack, non-Latino, non-Asian, nonfeminist,
>nonenvironmentalist, nongay, non-working people's left: Now that really
>would be quite an achievement."
>

Once again: A real (and future) third party movement must represent all of 
these forces and more.  It must be a coalition based united front of 
democratic people, classes, businesses, organizations, parties, and anyone 
else who will join in the historic effort to sieze political power away from 
the international corporate powers that Nader so elloquently admonishes.


>True enough, after getting a boost from his "the people vs. the powerful"
>convention speech, Gore moved fitfully toward the center, and one can fight
>against his position on capital punishment and prisons, his trimming on gun
>control -- dispute all this and more far more effectively if he is 
>president
>than not.


All this said, let it be known that I am voting AGAINST the phycopathic 
Shrub and for Gore.  I congradulate Nader for bringing issues to the table 
that may not otherwise have been brought up in the mainstream media.  But I 
don't for a minute think that the Whore-Gore will represent the people's 
wishes any more than his punk imperialist predecesor, Clinton, did.  WE MUST 
BUILD THE INDEPENDANT POLITICAL PARTY MOVEMENT at the local level and build 
up from there!

So, to wrap up:  1) Keep Bush and his extreme right constituency out of 
office on Nov. 7  2) Keep Gore beholden to his consituency as long as 
possible (unions, black churches, environmental org.'s etc) but know that he 
can't be trusted either, ultimately, & 3) GET BUSY!!! Organize in your 
neighborhood, on your block, at work, in school, wherever you can in 
anticipation that the next election is right around the corner, and we're 
going to have to be ready.  Rememeber, there are NO QUICK FIXES!


And if you're still reading this, then your probably interested enough to 
want to know that in New Brunswick, we're preparing to take the majority in 
City Council on election day!  Our truly grass-roots People's Campaign has a 
multi-national ticket running on a revolutionary-democratic platform, and 
we've been campaigning even longer that Nader ;) in NB to fundamentally 
transform and democratise NB.  AND WE NEED HELP!  If you can come down for 
the day on Tuesday, Nov. 7th, or even for a few hours to help us get out the 
vote, it may make all the difference in this race...for more info, email me, 
or call the Headquarters at (732) 545-5756.

For the future...Matthew Smith

everyone:

i'm sorry that this debate has detracted from the main purpose of this 
egroup, which is the Campaign. For the record, I do not in the least bit 
equate voting for Nader the same as voting for the People's Campaign for 
city council. It's important to realize here that Nader has publically 
stated that he is not trying to win. big difference. we are trying to win, 
and actually gain some power. In Nader's own words:

"You miss the critical point: we seek long-term political reform
through a growing party that pushes the two parties toward reforms
that you have espoused over the years, thus far in vain."
NY Times editorial - Oct. 27, 2000

These are his words. I can not support voting for someone who believes the 
purpose of a political camaign is to shame/push the two main parties to " do 
the right thing".

Also, if the Green party was only trying to garner 5% of the vote for 
matching funds, they could easily target only those states where Gore is 
assured a victory and still get the 5%. It seems to me, however, that Nader 
is targeting specifically those states where Gore is weak so that Gore does 
not win. He does not want Gore to win. He wants Bush to win. I do not want 
Bush to win.

I hate the Democratic Party (witness my involvement in our campaign) but i 
can not support a man who is only trying to be a grand scale consumer 
advocate and whose political lines are actually pretty skewed.

I also think that real change, the kind that doesn't happen too often, can 
only come from a solid base of local grassroots organizing. I don't think 
voting for Gore will change anything. I do think working on the People's 
Campaign will.

Again, I'm sorry that this debate has shifted our attention from the 
important work at hand. Please let's unite around our upcoming victory on 
election day!!!

In Unity,
Kristina

Post ID:776
Sender:"Chris Kozlowski" <razer@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-01 18:52:14
Subject:RE: [nbpc] UNITE, UNITE, UNITE
Message:

Nader has not stated publicly that he is not trying to win.  He has stated
that it is not probable.  This simply means that he is not delusional.  He
has stated quite explicitly that they are indeed trying to win, as well as
gather as much support as possible.

The logic you are putting forth is precisely the sort of panicky drivel that
led to Clinton's election in 1992 and his re-election in 1996.  Everyone
bought into it and the Clintons, thus unchallenged, gave us a rollback of
democracy unseen in the Bush years. Put quite simply, they could pose as the
'lesser evil' and still do business as usual -- in effect, nothing different
than the Republicans.

It does no good to run around like Chicken Little and yell that the
Republicans are coming.  You will invite a dose of hysteria among the naive,
while those who contemplate the history of these arguments and wish to work
within the system to put an end to the existing monopoly and
unaccountability of power will just shake their heads at you.  The way to
move the Democrats to the left, in the near future, is to scare them with
third-party candidates and allow them to lose if necessary.

It is symptomatic of the Homo Sovieticus in some of you to play along with
the 'lesser evil' mentality.  Your arguments sound much like the ones used
to elicit the "98% support" for candidates back in the USSR.  "If you don't
vote for so-and-so, you are clearly supporting imperialism."

You cite passages to support a mind you have already made up, Kristina.  I
am not impressed with your train of thought.  Your suggestion that he is
merely a "consumer advocate" dismisses the platform of the Green Party,
which I will include below.  I suspect that you have dismissed it out of
hand, as you NJFO-derived folks have done dozens of times to any thought
that did not originate from the illustrious poet-revolutionary Amiri Baraka.
But yet, there is wisdom elsewhere in the world.  I encourage you to explore
it.

Grassroots Democracy
Every human being deserves a say in the decisions that affect their lives;
no one should be subject to the will of another. Therefore we will work to
increase public participation at every level of government and to ensure
that our public representatives are fully accountable to the people who
elect them. We will also work to create new types of political organizations
that expand the process of participatory democracy by directly including
citizens in the decision-making process.

Ecological Wisdom
Human societies must operate with the understanding that we are part of
nature, not separate from nature. We must maintain an ecological balance and
live within the ecological and resource limits of our communities and our
planet. We support a sustainable society that utilizes resources in such a
way that future generations will benefit and not suffer from the practices
of our generation. To this end we must have agricultural practices that
replenish the soil; move to an energy efficient economy; and live in ways
that respect the integrity of natural systems.


Social Justice and Equal Opportunity
All persons should have the rights and opportunity to benefit equally from
the resources afforded us by society and the environment. We must
consciously confront in ourselves, our organizations, and society at large,
barriers such as racism and class oppression, sexism and heterosexism,
ageism and disability, which act to deny fair treatment and equal justice
under the law.

Nonviolence
It is essential that we develop effective alternatives to our current
patterns of violence at all levels, from the family and the streets, to
nations and the world. We will work to demilitarize our society and
eliminate weapons of mass destruction, without being naive about the
intentions of other governments. We recognize the need for self-defense and
the defense of others who are in helpless situations. We promote nonviolent
methods to oppose practices and policies with which we disagree, and will
guide our actions toward lasting personal, community and global peace.

Decentralization
Centralization of wealth and power contributes to social and economic
injustice, environmental destruction, and militarization. Therefore, we
support a restructuring of social, political and economic institutions away
from a system that is controlled by and mostly benefits the powerful few, to
a democratic, less bureaucratic system. Decision-making should, as much as
possible, remain at the individual and local level, while assuring that
civil rights are protected for all citizens.

Community Based Economics
We recognize it is essential to create a vibrant and sustainable economic
system, one that can create jobs and provide a decent standard of living,
for all people, while maintaining a healthy ecological balance. A successful
economic system will offer meaningful work with dignity, while paying a
"living wage" which reflects the real value of a person's work. Local
communities must look to economic development that assures protection of the
environment and workers' rights, broad citizen participation in planning,
and enhancement of our "quality of life". We support independently owned and
operated companies which are socially responsible, as well as co-operatives
and public enterprises that spread out resources and control to more people
through democratic participation.

Feminism
We have inherited a social system based on male domination of politics and
economics. We call for the replacement of the cultural ethics of domination
and control, with more cooperative ways of interacting which respect
differences of opinion and gender. Human values such as equity between
the -sexes, interpersonal responsibility, and honesty must be developed with
moral conscience. We should remember that the process that determines our
decisions and actions is just as important as achieving the outcome we want.

Respect for Diversity
We believe it is important to value cultural, ethnic, racial, sexual,
religious and spiritual diversity, and to promote the development of
respectful relationships across these lines. We believe the many diverse
elements of society should be reflected in our organizations and
decision-making bodies, and we support the leadership of people who have
been traditionally closed out of leadership roles. We acknowledge and
encourage respect for other life forms and the preservation of biodiversity.

Personal and Global responsibility
We encourage individuals to act to improve their personal well being and, at
the same time, to enhance ecological balance and social harmony. We seek to
join with people and organizations around the world to foster peace,
economic justice, and the health of the planet.

Future Focus and Sustainability
Our actions and policies should be motivated by long-term goals. We seek to
protect valuable natural resources, safely disposing of or "unmaking" all
waste we create, while developing a sustainable economics that does not
depend on continual expansion for survival. We must counter-balance the
drive for short-term profits by assuring that economic development, new
technologies, and fiscal policies are responsible to future generations who
will inherit the results of our actions. Our overall goal is not merely to
survive, but to share lives that are truly worth living. We believe the
quality of our individual lives is enriched by the quality of all of our
lives. We encourage everyone to see the dignity and intrinsic worth in all
of life, and to take the time to understand and appreciate themselves, their
community and the magnificent beauty of this world.

all working together because while are opinions do differ, we have enuf 
similarities that a joint effort is worthwhile.

Post ID:789
Sender:Wildf10wer@...
Post Date/Time:2000-11-02 18:39:57
Subject:synopsis of A Day Without Hate
Message:

Hello friends.  
I just wanted to follow up Ami's letter for those of you who may be 
interested in knowing more about what will be happening during this four day 
event.  
I agree with Ami. . .I, too, am tired of seeing senseless acts of hate.  This 
event has brought an amazing group of individuals together.  (Which, I feel, 
is a blessing in disguise.)  I feel empowered and motivated in creating a 
change that is reaching for a collective understanding of an interactive 
community built on kindness and successful communication. . .not ignorance, 
fear, and hate.  Can these four days make such a difference?  Yes. I already 
have learned so much and grown thanks to the many individuals involved with 
the organization of A Day Without Hate.  I feel confident that through the 
seminars, smiles, and outreach with music and art. . .we will be 
promoting/reminding our peers of the need for (and how to achieve) peace.    
I ask you to take a minute and read the synopsis that follows.  
Thank you.
With love,
Melissa Calabrese

A Day Without Hate
November 13-16

Imagine a day that stands up against the intolerance and negativity
present in the world.

Imagine a day that unites the Rutgers University and New Brunswick
Community. 

Imagine a week of kindness that culminates into a Day Without Hate.

Imagine that you and I could change the world. 

Help us make this a reality

We are looking for sponsors for funding as well as university student
group participation

Here is the synopsis for the weeks events. 

Monday, November 13:  For the Children
An assembly that will entertain and educate children at Lincoln School with 
interactive skits dealing with real life situations.  Our goal is to provide 
them with
conflict-resolution skills.  All students will receive literature to take
home and discuss with their parents.   We plan to set up a fair following the 
assembly that will allow the children to visit several stations concerning 
water issues
(provided by WaterWatch, an AmeriCorps program), communication skills, 
positive self-esteem, random acts of kindness, and art.  

Tuesday, November 14:  Diversity Day
With the recognition that there are several ways to communicate, we will
provide entertainment throughout College Ave, 
Douglass, Cook, Livingston and Busch campuses with music, theater,
artwork, and spirituality.  

Wednesday, November 15: Community and Self-awareness Day
This day, with the help of other organizations, we will focus on the
community and the self.  From clothing drives to blood donations, stress
management seminars to yoga workshops, we hope the individual will become
more aware of their personal actions.

Thursday, November 16: A Day Without Hate
This is a day of celebration and education.  First, a petition will be
circulated throughout the Rutgers community asking people to spend a day
without hatred.  Signers will receive a sticker to wear on November 16,
which will signify their participation in the program.  The pledge will be
placed as a display ad in the Daily Targum along with a list of the day's
events and an editorial explaining the motivation behind the establishment
of the day.  Again, all co-sponsors will be recognized.  

Second, throughout "A Day Without Hate", a series of seminars/events
discussing and focusing on hate, its causes, and solutions for dealing
with it will be held.  Each of these seminars will be run by a different
campus organization or department and will take place at a variety of
different locations throughout Rutgers.  "A Day Without Hate" will end
with a benefit concert and/or speaker.

If interested please e-mail contact phone number and we will reach you
asap

For questions only call: Ami Yares @ 247-9937 or Melissa Calabrese
@565-7969

MEETINGS WED NIGHT AT 9:15 at HILLEL 93 College Ave

Actually you're wrong.
Voting does make a difference, especially on a local level.
Okay- There isn't much of a choice as far as the presidential race goes. I 
hate the two party system as much as I don't want Bush to become president.

You're not going to change the system from the top down anyway.

But you can change the corrupt system of government from the bottom up. You 
can vote and make a difference here in New Brunswick. In case you haven't 
heard the news yet- there are 3 candidates running for city council, who are 
backed by a 17 point platform, and have pledged to struggle against 
corporate corruption in New Brunswick.

You claim to be protesting the system by refusing to vote. Really you are 
just perpetuating the system and giving corporations the power to continue 
doing whatever the hell they want!

By voting you can protest corporate power (i.e. J&J) and change the system 
starting on a local level. You can't change the world in a day, it takes 
small steps, and seizing power on a local level is a step towards democracy, 
changing the corrupt system of government and taking power back from the 
corporate elite.

In Unity,
Audrey Allred

Post ID:798
Sender:"Paul McGee" <shorepaulie@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-03 10:15:45
Subject:Why Not to Mock the Vote
Message:

Hi folks,

I happen to think that you need to make the most out of situations, and to 
that end, many of us are working around the clock in the People's Campaign 
to win a city council election.

This campaign could break the back of a vicious machine which is responsible 
for terrorizing black and latino neighborhoods, throwing people out of their 
housing, denying an effective education and systematically stripping people 
of their money and dignity for over THIRTY YEARS!

We can win this election if people turn out. That means working people, 
especially oppressed people, have much to gain by voting. Locally. And 
students play a major role in this local election.

And now this show comes to town, with hip groups putting out decent 
messages. And a really big crowd is coming to see them. And much of that 
crowd may be thinking about how to vote. The People's Campaign will be 
engaging every possible person about their role this coming Tuesday because 
the future of New Brunswick depends on it.

Straight up, I think Mock the Vote is irresponsible towards local politics.

Further, these artists have worked years and years to perfect their art, and 
if you protest the event, you may as well protest their work.

If you're protesting the lack of progressive culture over the airwaves, I 
suggest you go out and sponsor some shows of your own that promote positive 
culture. What positive will come of this Saturday? Many of us in People's 
Campaign have worked for years to get where we are now and some folks think 
it's cool to fight the man by fighting every manifestation of corporate this 
and that. We can build relationships at this event and leave with 
substantive gains. Protest here will only promote the cynicism that keeps 
people away from the voting booth, which is what the corporations want. I 
say "Don't bite yourself in the ass"

Paul McGee, New Jersey Freedom Organization

Subject:things heat up...
Message:


New Brunswick council race a sign that election can't come soon enough

Star-Ledger - 11/03/00
BY ALEXANDER LANE
STAFF WRITER

Campaign sign disputes are nothing new in New Jersey, but yesterday the sign 
wars in New Brunswick took a turn for the weird.


A placard for three incumbent Democratic councilmen appeared on a fence 
outside the campaign headquarters of their archrivals, three independent 
candidates running as the People's Campaign.


And it's not going anywhere. Not legally, anyway.


The People's Campaign landlord is Peter Dalton, 32, owner of a property 
management company. Dalton gave a basement office to the populist upstarts 
for the last seven months, rent-free. Now he feels he has to give the town 
Democrats a plug, too, by letting them put a sign on his property.


If this nasty city council race were a tug-of-war, Dalton would be the rope.


Dalton, a personable sort, seems a little naive when it comes to dicey local 
politics. He graciously gave the People's Campaign free use of the basement 
office, thinking he was doing a favor for neighborhood chums.


Then the election drew closer, and heat came from all sides.


"The city doesn't like me now. They call me up and they tell me," said 
Dalton. "I got to work with the city, you know what I'm saying?"


His brothers, one of whom works as a school bus driver in New Brunswick, 
even chastised him for taking on City Hall. "They hate me because I got 
People's Campaign in my basement," Dalton said.


Arguments erupted between Dalton and his wife, who is convinced the city 
will take revenge on their business, he said.


"One time, she came in and wrecked the whole office," Dalton said. "The 
People's Campaign helped me clean it up."


One thing is for sure, Dalton said, the People's Campaign stays. He promised 
the group an office until Nov. 8, and he does not intend to kick them out.


"If I told somebody I'm going to do something I'm going do it," Dalton said. 
"I just got a good heart and I want to help people out. That's what I do. If 
the Democrats came to me first and said they wanted my basement, I would've 
helped them out first."


When the Democrats asked if they could put up signs on all six of the 
properties he owns in the city, including the office at 149 Redmond St., 
Dalton said yes. So as far as Dalton is concerned, the signs stay, too.


But People's Campaign candidate Keith Joseph, who is running with Curtis 
Warren and Diego Morales, said it's a little more complicated than that.


"This is a neighborhood I live in, and I don't think it's going to last very 
long," Joseph predicted, though he stopped short of saying just how it would 
disappear.


"It's a desperate move on their part to put their sign in front of our 
office," Joseph said. "They try to intimidate people into putting up their 
stuff, and I think it's because they have no support in the community."


Dalton said the city stopped short of intimidation. "They're not bullying 
me. But yet they're not doing any favors for me, either," Dalton said.


T.K. Shamy, the campaign manager for incumbent Democrats Joseph Schrum, 
Robert Recine and Jimmie Cook, said he has never been to the People's 
Campaign headquarters and did not set out to irk them with the political 
sign.


"Mr. Dalton is a supporter of ours. We asked him to put up some signs, he 
put up the sign." Shamy said. "His brother and I went to grammar school 
together. He's been a New Brunswick resident for years. It doesn't surprise 
me that they're supporters of the (Democratic) candidates."


But Dalton said he does not care to take sides.


"My back is up against the wall, really. I want to help both people," Dalton 
said. "I'm putting my neck out . . . I'm in a weird situation here."


It's bound to get weirder before Tuesday. The man who got himself in trouble 
by being too generous is trying to dig himself out with more generosity -- 
Dalton gave a $700 campaign contribution to the Democrats early this week.


Alexander Lane covers New Brunswick. He can be reached at 
alane@... or at (732) 634-1236.
