Post ID:813
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakow@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-08 13:03:19
Subject:Poll report W1 D 4,5
Message:

Perhaps each can report to the list from their site?

I was challenger in W 1, D4 and D5.

1. I counted the tickets that are taken at the polling machine for W1 D5 and 
they were 7 more than the votes that the machine registered - so 7 votes 
were lost.  The 2 poll clerks I worked there with let me count the tickets 
to be able to confirm this, and they confirmed my number. The machines are a 
pain because they dont seem to have a foolproof system.  There are 2 beeps - 
one before voting generated by the poll clerk to prepare for the voter and 
one after generated by the voter entering their vote.  If the voter forgets 
to press enter or the poll clerk spaces for a moment in high activity and 
doesnt clear the machine for the next voter (and we needed more poll 
clerks), then the votes seem to get swallowed. I was trying to keep track 
for the 2 beeps on each machine but things go so fast and once a beep does 
or doesnt happen you cant scroll back in time to check it again.  W1 D4 
didnt let me count their tickets at the end so I dont know about that. They 
told me that is not what I was challenger for, its just just for the 
individual voters, not checking the final tally.

Before I went to check the consistency between tickets and the machine I 
heard them discussing something about it.  I asked them is there a 
discrepancy.  They said no.  One challenger joked, your so worried about the 
big bad democratic machine.  So I went and checked it myself and it didnt 
work out.  Then they admitted there was indeed a discrepancy.

Once I was out of the room and came back and heard several beeps in a row.  
I asked them if they had heard it too.  The voter leaving the machine seemed 
confused about it.  They looked at me and said no, but it seemed hesitant 
and they didnt attack me for making that claim.

2. We had the bold "NO" self-made challenger badge situation, but it never 
got used at our site, it just lay on the table.  After the court decision on 
the day of the election that prevented them from using their own challenger 
badges within the polls (after it had been used already), one gentleman wore 
the approved NO badge in addition to his Democratic badge which was alot 
less obvious.

3.  There was a PTA bake sale going on within the 100-foot line of the 
polling site.  People were milling about. These folks were not openly 
electioneering.  Apparently they have done this several times in the past 
years.

4.  At one point there were 3 challengers for Recine.  They didnt seem to be 
aware of the rules.  Once I explained them they switched to become a 
challenger for Gore.

5.  The candidates Recine and Cook were audibly critical of our candidates 
to eachother within the polling site 3-4 meters from the polls. I dont think 
they realized this was wrong though.  They were just talking to the 
challengers.

6.  They had no idea what the terms of use of the provisional ballots were 
and at one point placed the ballot directly in the orange pouch with no 
envelope so that the poll clerk saw the votes.  I ended up going into the 
pouch to find the envelopes for them which I think was a violation.  There 
were also fuzzy rules around who could use the ballot.  I ended up using 
this test, "Did you register to vote in NB?"  Fuzziness was around if the 
person hadnt voted in years, also if they had moved to NB but their kids got 
new registration in NB and they hadnt and thought they had been transferred 
because their kids were via the high school registration, or if they tried 
to register after the 30 days and the MCBOE let them and gave them an ID 
number. In these cases we also gave them a ballot.

7. One woman didnt understand the school board ballot question and I 
explained what yes and no meant.  She wanted to file a complaint when I told 
here that was possible but the poll clerks said there were no complaint 
forms. Flavio was there at that time and we got them to search their forms.  
We found a complaint form but it was too late she had left.

8. Explanations of how to vote in the machine sometimes included pointing a 
bit of a  sweep down the Democratic line with a little here and there  so it 
was hard to pinpoint any obvious violation.  I had a hard time checking what 
they were doing when the poll clerks were explaining to people by pointing 
within the machine how to vote, since I couldnt see in well.

9. In general, with Flavios work we were able to establish some type of 
rationale at the site for orderly voting.

10.  Note on the walking lists which should have been organized by last 
name.

11. Since the day was such a family and friends affair, people were coming 
up and chatting with the challengers all the time.  I didnt challenge this 
because the challengers were already testy with me.

Incumbents sweep in heated New Brunwick race 

11/08/00

BY ALEXANDER LANE
STAFF WRITER

















It was politics New Brunswick- style, and it wasn't pretty. 


Three Democratic councilmen in the Hub City fended off a slate of independent People's Campaign candidates, winning by more than a 2-to-1 ratio. 


And the Democratic Party defeated a push to change the school board from a body appointed by the mayor to one elected by voters. 


In the process, the mayor's right-hand man allegedly punched a citizen activist in the face and frustrated Rutgers students who'd been turned away from the polls complained their votes were being suppressed. Democratic op
eratives were criticized for wearing illegal challenger badges into polling places. And city police officers worked overtime at the polls, prompting accusations they were there to intimidate potential voters. 


Perhaps the day's ugliest incident was in the morning outside the Lord Stirling School polling place, where Kevin Jones, an aide to Mayor James Cahill, argued with Joe Smith, an activist who advocated an elected board of 
education. 


Witnesses said Jones objected to Smith's standing too close to one of the Democrats' signs. The argument came to an abrupt end when Jones allegedly punched Smith in the face, drawing blood, police said. 


Police Director Michael Beltranena said Smith was at fault. "Smith assaulted Kevin Jones, Kevin Jones defended himself. They were both asked if they wanted to sign complaints; they declined to sign complaints," Beltranena
 said. 


Smith and witnesses friendly to him said Jones, who is considerably bigger than Smith, was the aggressor. 


Jones, who earns $40,000 a year for his city job, would not talk about the incident. "No comment. I'll see you after the election," he said. 


The incident was one of three run-ins with the New Brunswick police for Smith. Later, acting on an anonymous phone tip, they arrested him for failing to appear in North Brunswick Municipal Court for a speeding ticket Mond
ay. Before dawn he was arrested for allegedly throwing eggs at a group of men putting up Democratic election signs, a charge Smith denied. 


Meanwhile, at Lincoln School, near the Rutgers campus, many students trying to vote were rebuffed for a variety of reasons throughout the day. People's Campaign activists said there was a concerted effort by the city to s
uppress the unpredictable student vote. 


Michelle Shin, 21, a Rutgers senior, said poll workers sent her to four different polling places before she finally arrived back at Lincoln School, where she had gone originally, to vote. "It's like a trail of tears. I go
t out of class at 2:10, and it's 3:10 now," Shin said. 


Ron Gambone, 23, a Rutgers senior, said he registered five weeks ago, but he did not appear on the rolls at Lincoln, and he was forced to vote by paper ballot. 


"They should make sure registered voters get on that list," Gambone said. "Not voting on a machine makes me more wary, especially when they tell you your vote may not count (if your eligibility cannot be verified)." 


Robert Reck of the Middlesex County Elections Board acknowledged many students were encountering problems voting, but said they are often difficult to keep track of because they frequently change addresses. 


But People's Campaign activists did not believe the confusion at Lincoln School was unintentional. 


"We're investigating the filing of charges against the poll workers here. It's a pattern, it was a pattern when I was a student here 12 years ago," said attorney Flavio Komuves, who represents the People's Campaign. 


Democratic poll challengers at several sites wore badges advocating an appointed school board in the polling area until the county elections board forced them to remove the unofficial credentials after a hearing in the mo
rning. 


People's Campaign activists also complained that too many city police were stationed at polling sites. A 1985 federal consent decree -- prompted by charges that police were intimidating potential voters -- prohibits more 
than one officer per site, but up to six were at Lincoln and Lord Stirling at various times. 


Beltranena said he added officers to keep the peace after the 
confrontation between Jones and Smith. He said the consent 
decree allows him to increase the number of officers at stations if 
necessary. 


Alexander Lane covers New Brunswick. He can be reached at 
alane@... or at (732) 634-1236.

Incumbents sweep in heated New Brunwick race 

11/08/00

BY ALEXANDER LANE

It was politics New Brunswick- style, and it wasn't pretty. 


Three Democratic councilmen in the Hub City fended off a slate of independent People's Campaign candidates, winning by more than a 2-to-1 ratio.

*********************************************************************************
Confidential and Privileged.
Do not read if you are not the intended recipient.
Unauthorized use prohibited and taken at your own risk.
**********************************************************************************

I am pleased and impressed with the thoroughness of Zofia's report which will go a long way towards enforcing our promises to the community and the campus of zero tolerance for voter suppression.  

In that vein, I would like each of the thirteen poll captains to make similar reports for the express purpose of using them in litigation.  Make them soon while your memory is fresh!  I do NOT, however, want them posted on the group.  They should be sent to me and to Campaign Manager Xavier Hansen at Flavio.Komuves@... and xavier.hansen@..., respectively.  Others with knowledge of violations should also send reports of same to me and Hansen as stated above.  They should not be shared with anyone except other poll captains.

Please also give to me or Hansen all contemporaneous notes that you took that day, keeping a copy for yourself.

With that said, however, let me add some things:

1. When you refer to somebody, tell me their name, physical description and the capacity in which they were acting e.g. poll judge, democratic challenger, etc.  Since most poll workers were photographed or videotaped, tell me who did it and tell me the time they were photographed or videotaped.  (This is my sole criticism of Zofia's report and I will most definitely need such information).

2. When you refer to an event, tell me the time it occurred; if at a polling site, tell me what ward and district it occurred at.

3. Any repeated activity of electioneering by candidates, poll workers, or challengers inside should be reported.  I am not interested in a voter talking with a friend working the polls on an isolated basis; I want the repeat violators.

4. With respect to the provisionals, I need the list of the names and phone numbers or addresses of all persons who were given OR refused provisionals.  With respect to each, state: (1) why were they given a provisional, e.g. name not in the book, wrong address, etc.; (2) were they asked for ID?; (3) was ID presented, and if so, what was that ID; and (4) were they given a ballot or not?  Please also let me know the total number of provisionals for your ward and district.

5. With regard to white "no" ribbons (not the pieces of cardboard they were replaced with), give me the names or descriptions of all persons wearing or possessing them and the time when they took them off.

Thanks.

Flavio L. Komuves
General Counsel

Subject:at least one elected board question passes...

This is interesting...


NY Times
November 9, 2000

Englewood Voters Approve Shift to Elected School Board
By MARIA NEWMAN

Voters in Englewood, N.J., decided on Tuesday that they wanted to elect the 
members of their school board, rather than continue to have the mayor 
appoint them.

The ballot measure was approved by a vote of 4,289 to 3,427 after a 
hard-fought campaign in which a group of homeowners, Concerned Residents of 
Englewood, told voters in frequent mailings and telephone calls that 
electing a board was the only way to improve the city's low- achieving 
schools.

"This is great tribute to democracy in Englewood," said Eugenia Vogel, a 
supporter of the ballot measure. "If you elect somebody to do the job and 
they don't do the job, then you vote him out of office."

But Mayor Paul T. Fader and another group, Englewood Citizens for Education, 
warned that changing the method of choosing board members would not 
guarantee better schools.

Englewood is the only school district in Bergen County with an appointed 
school board. Attempts to make the board an elected one failed here in 1975 
and 1980.

Mr. Fader said he was not surprised that the ballot measure was approved 
this time, especially because its supporters raised more than $28,000 for 
their efforts, according to election campaign records.

"It was clear to me it would pass," he said, "but it's also clear to me that 
it's not in the best interest of the city."

The mayor said he feared that only candidates with enough money to wage 
expensive campaigns would consider running for the board. He also said that 
voter turnout at school board elections was historically low in New Jersey, 
so a small and elite group of residents could end up deciding the board's 
membership.

But Mr. Fader said it was hard to compete with the pro-election campaign.

"It's very difficult to go out and tell the public they should vote against 
their right to vote," he said.

Englewood, which has a large wealthy community and high property taxes, has 
some of the poorest test scores in Bergen County, and almost half of its 
school-age children attend private schools.

The district has also been involved in a costly 15-year legal battle to keep 
a well-to-do neighboring community, Englewood Cliffs, from pulling its 
students � most of them white � out of Englewood High School, which is a 
disproportionate 97 percent nonwhite, and placing them in another public 
school.

Mr. Fader said the schools have improved since Dr. Joyce Baynes was named 
superintendent two years ago, and he said he thought those improvements 
would have continued under an appointed board.

"This group has not articulated any educational goals," Mr. Fader said. 
"They haven't talked about the need to reduce class sizes, which we've 
already done, or to create magnet schools, which we did. Now it's incumbent 
upon the people who have expressed an interest in education to articulate 
their vision for the schools.

"Some very wealthy people were willing to put a lot of money into this 
campaign for this measure," Mr. Fader said. "Was it their goal to improve 
education here, or just to cut the school budget? I guess we'll find out in 
the next two years."

Mrs. Vogel said the changes would not come immediately.

"Eventually they will get better," she said. "Not right away, but very soon, 
maybe in two years."

According to state law, the board will increase to nine members from its 
current seven. An election must be held in 60 days to elect the two new 
members. Elections will be held to replace the other members when their 
terms, which are staggered, are up. In about two years, the entire board 
will be elected.

Englewood was one of 19 school districts in the state that had an appointed 
school board, according to the New Jersey School Boards Association. On 
Tuesday, voters in New Brunswick rejected, for the fourth time in seven 
years, a measure to elect their board members. In Elizabeth, where voters 
have selected the school board since 1988, the City Council placed a measure 
on the ballot to return to an appointed board, but voters rejected the 
proposal by a 2-to-1 ratio.

In New Brunswick, voters deserve better 


Published in the Home News Tribune 11/10/00
A Home News Tribune editorial
The New Brunswick Democratic Party shouldn't be bragging about how voters 
reinstated three incumbents to the City Council this week. Instead, if party 
officials want to keep their credibility, they'd better start taking 
opposition seriously.

The party's dismissal of rivals shows not only the arrogance of power but the 
foolishness of thinking there's no way to lose it.

The folks who oppose the grip the Democratic party holds on the city aren't 
going to disappear - nor should they. Who knows how much more money and 
support they'll garner before Mayor James Cahill's term expires in two years? 
Maybe by then their quest might not seem so quixotic.

"The People's Campaign didn't actually lose, we learned," says Curtis L. 
Warren, who ran for council. "This is just a practice for two years from now, 
when we go after two City Council seats and the mayor's office."

During the fall campaign for council, the city's Democratic political 
organization refused to debate The People's Campaign, a new and hodgepodge 
group of residents who were offering alternatives to entrenched Democrats.

The lack of debate accomplished two things. First, it denied residents the 
opportunity to hear and question the two camps' competing visions of New 
Brunswick and thus make more informed decisions about who should run the city 
and its public schools.

Second, it left the Democratic Party vulnerable to allegations City Hall 
officials harass opposition groups.

Why was The People's Campaign forced a few days before the election to move 
its headquarters of five months? Were any Rutgers University students 
intimidated on Election Day by city police officers stationed at polling 
places? Why was there a scuffle between the organizer of the movement to 
bring an elected school board to the city and a poll challenger for 
Democratic City Council candidates?

To be sure, all sorts of positive changes are happening in New Brunswick -- 
from a fledgling regional charter school on Commercial Avenue to a 
reinvigorated downtown. But as the city grows more sophisticated, so, too, 
should its Democratic leaders.



------------------------------------------------------------------------------

--

Elizabeth voters couldn't be fooled

A Home News Tribune editorialThankfully, voters in Elizabeth saw through 
slickly worded rhetoric and recognized exactly what Mayor J. Christian 
Bollwage and City Council President Manny Grova Jr. wanted them to do Tuesday 
- give up their right to vote for the people who run the Elizabeth School 
Board. 
The public question on switching from an elected school board to a 
mayor-appointed one lost 10,327 to 5,260.

There are many ways to ease the challenges facing New Jersey's urban public 
schools. Whether the board is appointed or elected won't be the determinant 
of students' success. In fact, some could argue it makes no difference at 
all, because urban school districts with both elected and appointed boards 
are failing. 

But given the possibility of enabling taxpayers to choose the people who run 
their public schools and raise their taxes, or letting an elected official do 
their bidding for them, it's far better to let taxpayers, not politicians, 
hold board members accountable.



from the Home News Tribune 

Published: November 10, 2000

Post ID:826
Sender:FBRIGHT123@...

Subject:Re:Targum 11/10/00

Student voters must take action
Commentary 


By Derek Broderick
Guest Commentary 

------------------------------------------------------------------------------

--



The Targum’s coverage of the difficulties Rutgers students faced in casting 
their vote on election day fell short of addressing the scope of the problem, 
and failed to identify important trends in those who were turned away at the 
polls (The Daily Targum, Nov. 8). 

I volunteered as a poll challenger for the People’s Campaign at the Sacred 
Heart School, where residents of Ward 2, Districts 1 and 2 were supposed to 
be able to vote. District 1 encompasses much of the Cook and Douglass 
campuses, including the Newell Apartments, Katzenbach, Lippincott and 
Nicholas residence halls. By my own estimation, one out of every three 
students from these residence halls who came to vote was not on the list of 
registered voters. All of these students claimed to have registered to vote. 
Many claimed to have received a sample ballot in the mail, and many came with 
their voter registration cards in hand.

Based on my own observations, and overlooked in Targum coverage, was the fact 
that this puzzling phenomenon of deregistered voters was disproportionately 
confined to those students who live in residence halls. There were only a 
handful of cases at my voting site of off-campus residents that had the same 
problems as on-campus students. At polling sites which did not encompass 
dorms, there were rarely more than 20 provisional ballots filled out. At the 
Sacred Heart School there were nearly 150, an overwhelming majority of these 
cast by students who lived in the residence halls. 

The most frustrating and disturbing part of the day for me occurred before 
noon, as the provisional ballots were running low. A call was placed to the 
Middlesex County Board of Elections, and an attorney for the City of New 
Brunswick agreed, in conjunction with the non-partisan poll judge, to pick up 
200 more provisional ballots. That city attorney did not bother to come back. 
The polling site soon ran out of provisional ballots, at which point frantic 
calls were made to the Board of Elections. During the hour and a half period 
that it took the Board of Elections to provide the necessary provisional 
ballots, upwards of 30 students left off of the voter registration lists were 
told that they could not vote, even if they had brought proof of registration 
with them. Many of these students were voting for the first time, and many 
had to go to work or class and could not come back later to vote. 

The Targum’s assertion in an editorial that said, “In order to obtain a 
provisional ballot they had to speak with the state attorney general and 
obtain a signed affidavit” (The Daily Targum, Nov. 8) is factually 
inaccurate, and is a lie that was used at the voting site by Democratic 
Challengers who were actively seeking to drive away the student vote. Anybody 
left off of the lists that did not have a court order and wanted to vote had 
to “sign an affidavit saying he registered within 30 days prior to the 
election,” at which time that person was able fill out a provisional ballot. 
Those voters who returned with a court order were allowed to vote in the 
voting booths. 

Rather than titling the editorial “Fix the city’s machines,” the Targum 
should have dropped the apostrophe and recognized that it is time to “Fix the 
City Machine” that year after year suppresses the student vote. The fact that 
such a disproportionate number of those left off the list are students that 
live on campus is no more of a coincidence than the fact that The People’s 
Campaign carried Ward 6, District 3, a district with an extremely high 
population of students. 

Bearing direct witness to such widespread voter suppression has led me to 
believe that the work of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee and 
the Freedom Riders is not yet complete in this country. The Targum’s 
minimizing coverage and failure to recognize this as a civil rights issue is 
a threat to the Democratic freedoms of the students of Rutgers. The City of 
New Brunswick cannot be trusted to reform the current system — as the 
editorial suggested — because the city relies on the suppression of student 
votes to keep the corrupt city machine going. Such widespread and systematic 
denial of voting rights is worthy of state and even federal investigation. 
The people of New Brunswick must stand united and demand our right to vote.

Derek Broderick is a Livingston College senior majoring in political science.

      to the White House. The <B><I>letter</B></I> of the law gives them that

Subject:Virus alert
Message:

I stupidly opened a viral attachment to an e-mail this morning. (The e-mail had the subject line "funny joke" in it.) If you get an e-mail with this subject, delete it. It's hiding the "love letter" worm that went around a few months ago. It infects graphics files, and I've spent most of today quarantining my computer and disinfecting it, deleting hundreds of graphics files in the process.

If you received the virus from me, please accept my apologies. Likewise, if this e-mail is a duplicate, also accept my apologies.

--- In nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com, "kristina bas" <KRISBAS@h...>

> This is interesting...
> 
> 
> NY Times
> November 9, 2000
> 
> Englewood Voters Approve Shift to Elected School Board
> By MARIA NEWMAN
> 
> Voters in Englewood, N.J., decided on Tuesday that they wanted to 
elect the 
> members of their school board, rather than continue to have the 
mayor 
> appoint them.
> 
> The ballot measure was approved by a vote of 4,289 to 3,427 after a 
> hard-fought campaign in which a group of homeowners, Concerned 
Residents of 
> Englewood, told voters in frequent mailings and telephone calls 
that 
> electing a board was the only way to improve the city's low- 
achieving 
> schools.
> 
> "This is great tribute to democracy in Englewood," said Eugenia 
Vogel, a 
> supporter of the ballot measure. "If you elect somebody to do the 
job and 
> they don't do the job, then you vote him out of office."
> 
> But Mayor Paul T. Fader and another group, Englewood Citizens for 
Education, 
> warned that changing the method of choosing board members would not 
> guarantee better schools.
> 
> Englewood is the only school district in Bergen County with an 
appointed 
> school board. Attempts to make the board an elected one failed here 
in 1975 
> and 1980.
> 
> Mr. Fader said he was not surprised that the ballot measure was 
approved 
> this time, especially because its supporters raised more than 
$28,000 for 
> their efforts, according to election campaign records.
> 
> "It was clear to me it would pass," he said, "but it's also clear 
to me that 
> it's not in the best interest of the city."
> 
> The mayor said he feared that only candidates with enough money to 
wage 
> expensive campaigns would consider running for the board. He also 
said that 
> voter turnout at school board elections was historically low in New 
Jersey, 
> so a small and elite group of residents could end up deciding the 
board's 
> membership.
> 
> But Mr. Fader said it was hard to compete with the pro-election 
campaign.
> 
> "It's very difficult to go out and tell the public they should vote 
against 
> their right to vote," he said.
> 
> Englewood, which has a large wealthy community and high property 
taxes, has 
> some of the poorest test scores in Bergen County, and almost half 
of its 
> school-age children attend private schools.
> 
> The district has also been involved in a costly 15-year legal 
battle to keep 
> a well-to-do neighboring community, Englewood Cliffs, from pulling 
its 
> students  most of them white  out of Englewood High School, which 
is a 
> disproportionate 97 percent nonwhite, and placing them in another 
public 
> school.
> 
> Mr. Fader said the schools have improved since Dr. Joyce Baynes was 
named 
> superintendent two years ago, and he said he thought those 
improvements 
> would have continued under an appointed board.
> 
> "This group has not articulated any educational goals," Mr. Fader 
said. 
> "They haven't talked about the need to reduce class sizes, which 
we've 
> already done, or to create magnet schools, which we did. Now it's 
incumbent 
> upon the people who have expressed an interest in education to 
articulate 
> their vision for the schools.
> 
> "Some very wealthy people were willing to put a lot of money into 
this 
> campaign for this measure," Mr. Fader said. "Was it their goal to 
improve 
> education here, or just to cut the school budget? I guess we'll 
find out in 
> the next two years."
> 
> Mrs. Vogel said the changes would not come immediately.
> 
> "Eventually they will get better," she said. "Not right away, but 
very soon, 
> maybe in two years."
> 
> According to state law, the board will increase to nine members 
from its 
> current seven. An election must be held in 60 days to elect the two 
new 
> members. Elections will be held to replace the other members when 
their 
> terms, which are staggered, are up. In about two years, the entire 
board 
> will be elected.
> 
> Englewood was one of 19 school districts in the state that had an 
appointed 
> school board, according to the New Jersey School Boards 
Association. On 
> Tuesday, voters in New Brunswick rejected, for the fourth time in 
seven 
> years, a measure to elect their board members. In Elizabeth, where 
voters 
> have selected the school board since 1988, the City Council placed 
a measure 
> on the ballot to return to an appointed board, but voters rejected 
the 
> proposal by a 2-to-1 ratio.
>

Post ID:833
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-12 18:23:59
Subject:Re: [njfo] Pondering the election
Message:

DLJ-  Couple of points:

First, I didn't vote for Nader, or FOR the lesser of two evils.
I voted AGAINST the GREATEST evil...an ignorant serial killer whose 
interests lie firmly with the Oil Barons who carried out the Persian Gulf 
Massacre, and whose idea of a domestic program is a fast track to a 60 
billion dollar missile defense system.  I've never thought for a moment that 
Gore is a progressive who will rescue us from immenent melt-down, and he'll 
most likely maintain the embargo against Iraq, Cuba, etc. but he's not Bush, 
no matter how much the Greens or anyone else wants to insist on this. Point 
in fact: Why is it that the flip side of the argument to vote for Nader was 
almost invariably "Well, maybe if Bush wins, then it'll galvanize the 
resistance and the people will rise up quicker." ?!?  I suggest it's that 
most people, Greens included, realize that Gore is in fact to the left of 
Bush, if only a sliver, and is certainly not beholden to the Bob Jones 
constituency who advocate "pick-up truck justice" in lieu of a "jury of your 
peers".  And for the record, Hillary, while she can be very reactionary and 
sleezy on many issues (i.e. the Palestinian Question) is to to the left of 
Gore. Witness her recent call for the abolishment of the Electoral College 
and direct vote!

Secondly, Nader is not the great utopian thinker that he's made out to be.  
He's actually down right reactionary on issues such as States Rights (ie: 
his position that under Bush, abortion would merely go back to the states 
and not actually be abolished!!)  This shows that he has no real grasp of 
the history of states rights in the US, and how they have always been used 
to turn the clock backward on Civil Rights struggle.  This further points to 
the lack of any working relationship with the grassroots in the urban 
centers, as was evident when I saw him speak in Newark.  With the exception 
of Larry Hamm and a handful of POP-ers, the audience looked more like a 
Greatful Dead parking lot than an epicenter for decades of revolutionary 
struggle and the heart of the Black Arts.  & I don't accept their excuse 
that it was a last minute event.  It clearly shows that the Greens and Nader 
were trying to ride ripples left from the recent wave of protests (police 
brutality, Seattle, IMF, etc), formerly-disallusioned now middle class 
lefties going for the HEAD (president, congress, etc.) rather than building 
the BODY (GrassRoots Coalitions, United Front work, local office) AS IN 
PEOPLE'S CAMPAIGN.  Why is it that in our first ever election in NB, the PC 
was able to get almost 3 times as many votes for City Council as any of the 
Green Party Candidates got in in NB for president or congress?  It's because 
the People's Campaign has put itself out there as an alternative to the 
alternative.  If we're going to build a third party movement, then it has to 
be through this sort of broad based Coalition building.
Otherwise, if we followed the Green's model, then NJFO for instance would 
have just run for City Council ourselves!  Actually, if we did that, and was 
Bush running in NB on the Republican ticket, then I would be telling people 
two things: 1. to vote for Crook Racist & Scum to keep Bush out, and 2. that 
NJFO, while it's intentions are admirable, is trying to become a white, 
middle-class messiah rather than the revolutionary democratic organization 
that we thankfully are, capable of leading a multi-national united front of 
democratic classes, that will ultimately topple the icy grip that the 
Machine has on NB; and which will indeed serve as a model that when 
developed elsewhere will be the vehicle with which the people can sieze 
power regionally and state-wide!

To sum up, the movement has to come from the bottom up, not the top down.  
Every Republican knows that the Greens/Nader played into their cold hands, 
but if the left movement remains defensive and indignant regarding this 
election rather than learn from it over the next four years, than we're 
doomed to repeat the same mistakes.

Matthew Smith

>show me they are more about their party's standing than they are about our

>when it is not.
>

>they were living in resorting to killing his comrades and returning to his 
>original state of ignorance, rather that accepting reality.
>
>Cyper was taken out real quick, remember?
>
>I have to say I write this out of anger. I am angry because for the past 
>year I found myself at odds with people I never thought I would be at odds 
>at on this. It is a hell of a shock to me when I hear people who routinely 
>called out Clinton (or as they will say KKKlinton) now tell people to 
>support his vice-president.
>
>It is going to be a lot of fun in four years, because Hillary KKKlinton 
>will be running for president then. She will also win. The has the 
>shrewdness of anyone before her to do so, and she is better liked than her 
>husband. This move will happen because not only the lesser of two evils 
>will play itself out again, but the possibility of a female president for 
>the first time ever will be incredibly strong.
>
>If the third parties are not as strong as they were in this election it

>
>In the meantime, I suggest those who voted for the major parties take a

>
>When it happens you may be a part of what is swept away.

with you.

President Bush II

Post ID:837
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakow@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-13 13:07:18
Subject:BOE campaign
Message:

Theres alot more to the BOE loss, I think (in addition to what happened on 
election day).  I dont want us to throw up our hands and say that money is 
the only way to go until we have maxed out local organizing.

A.  The same people who worked on it the last time have been doing it for 
years.  They recycled the same contacts, the same literature, the same 
slogans.  Their slogans/flyers were the same lies from the last time so they 
were relatively simple to lay out to print.  Our lit was very topic based 
and based on research that we were continually conducting, which took time 
and effort to develop. We also brought the issue to the local level and 
spent alot of time and energy doing advocacy as various issues came up - for 
union teachers for childcare, for information re: transfers, etc.

B. Many of our contacts could not go public because of fear.  Even 
supportive PTA presidents could not go public or invite us to their 
meetings, even if they were friends with people on the other side.  The 
local teachers union did not take a stand which we saw they did in 
Elizabeth, although the state level did.  The machine was able to get 
friends and landlords to put up a bunch of their signs, and as we learned, 
at least one was coerced.  At the same time the machine was able to use 
schools like St. Marys in closed private forums to get their word out to 
parents.

C.  Granted, money did do alot - they had about 7-10 mailings and lit drops. 
  When we finally got lit together that I was confident in we didnt have the 
money or time to get it out to everybody.

D. They had people in each local neighborhood sending out letters and having 
kaffeklatsches.  We had local people doing this work in  key neighborhoods, 
but perhaps not as many, and in  neighborhoods that we were more likely to 
win anyway.

E.  We didnt canvass all of NB.

F. I was running it for the PC and it took me a long time to become 
strident. My plan was to develop a large enough group of people that it 
would be all of us that would be doing the press work and advocacy, I didnt 
want it to be just me going out front since I am not known like Joy Sheehan. 
  So many of our contacts were not going out front, I kept on thinking it 
was my fault organizing or the lack of passion about the issue that wasnt 
getting them out and not the fact that they were so afraid. Still, many 
parents did come forward.  By the end I could see more clearly what was 
going on.


Zofia

> > voter turnout at school board elections was historically low in New
>Jersey,
> > so a small and elite group of residents could end up deciding the
>board's
> > membership.
> >
> > But Mr. Fader said it was hard to compete with the pro-election
>campaign.
> >
> > "It's very difficult to go out and tell the public they should vote
>against
> > their right to vote," he said.
> >
> > Englewood, which has a large wealthy community and high property
>taxes, has
> > some of the poorest test scores in Bergen County, and almost half
>of its
> > school-age children attend private schools.
> >
> > The district has also been involved in a costly 15-year legal
>battle to keep
> > a well-to-do neighboring community, Englewood Cliffs, from pulling
>its
> > students � most of them white � out of Englewood High School, which
>is a
> > disproportionate 97 percent nonwhite, and placing them in another
>public
> > school.
> >
> > Mr. Fader said the schools have improved since Dr. Joyce Baynes was
>named
> > superintendent two years ago, and he said he thought those
>improvements
> > would have continued under an appointed board.
> >
> > "This group has not articulated any educational goals," Mr. Fader
>said.
> > "They haven't talked about the need to reduce class sizes, which
>we've
> > already done, or to create magnet schools, which we did. Now it's
>incumbent
> > upon the people who have expressed an interest in education to
>articulate
> > their vision for the schools.
> >
> > "Some very wealthy people were willing to put a lot of money into
>this
> > campaign for this measure," Mr. Fader said. "Was it their goal to
>improve
> > education here, or just to cut the school budget? I guess we'll
>find out in
> > the next two years."
> >
> > Mrs. Vogel said the changes would not come immediately.
> >
> > "Eventually they will get better," she said. "Not right away, but
>very soon,
> > maybe in two years."
> >
> > According to state law, the board will increase to nine members
>from its
> > current seven. An election must be held in 60 days to elect the two
>new
> > members. Elections will be held to replace the other members when
>their
> > terms, which are staggered, are up. In about two years, the entire
>board
> > will be elected.
> >
> > Englewood was one of 19 school districts in the state that had an
>appointed
> > school board, according to the New Jersey School Boards
>Association. On
> > Tuesday, voters in New Brunswick rejected, for the fourth time in
>seven
> > years, a measure to elect their board members. In Elizabeth, where
>voters
> > have selected the school board since 1988, the City Council placed
>a measure
> > on the ballot to return to an appointed board, but voters rejected
>the
> > proposal by a 2-to-1 ratio.
> >

> the only way to go until we have maxed out local organizing.

> A.  The same people who worked on it the last time have been doing 
it for 
> years.  They recycled the same contacts, the same literature, the 
same 
> slogans.  Their slogans/flyers were the same lies from the last 
time so they 
> were relatively simple to lay out to print.  Our lit was very topic 
based 
> and based on research that we were continually conducting, which 
took time 
> and effort to develop. We also brought the issue to the local level 
and 
> spent alot of time and energy doing advocacy as various issues came 
up - for 
> union teachers for childcare, for information re: transfers, etc.
> 
> B. Many of our contacts could not go public because of fear.  Even 
> supportive PTA presidents could not go public or invite us to their 
> meetings, even if they were friends with people on the other side.  
The 
> local teachers union did not take a stand which we saw they did in 
> Elizabeth, although the state level did.  The machine was able to 
get 
> friends and landlords to put up a bunch of their signs, and as we 
learned, 
> at least one was coerced.  At the same time the machine was able to 
use 
> schools like St. Marys in closed private forums to get their word 
out to 
> parents.
>

lit drops. 
>   When we finally got lit together that I was confident in we didnt 
have the 
> money or time to get it out to everybody.

likely to 
> win anyway.

>

Post ID:841
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>

Subject:Re: [nbpc] Re: at least one elected board question passes...
Message:

Folks-  Let's not get swept up in electoral politics, bourgeois style!  
While a "warchest" is crucial to electoral success, it is not principal 
asset we must obatain, and certainly not the pricipal reason for having 
lost.  From what I've heard, the results of the NB City Council election 
indicate that the People's Campaign received more votes from campus than we 
did from the community.  While this is a great tesamony to the level of 
organizing we reached on campus, it tells us that we have an immense amount 
of work towards consolidating support in the community.  It is this that 
seperates us from bourgeois politicians... we won't crawl off the wall-paper 
6 months before an election to coddle the community.  We will continue as we 
have before working with the community, building relationships and trust, 
and transforming institutions along with social consciousness.  This is our 
principal task and this, in 2002, will be the deciding factor.  Matthew

i am in no way advocating that raising money is the 'only way to go'. while 
organizing among the community (building trust) is our principle task (and 
yes what separates us from the opposition), being able to PAY our people to 
organize could make the difference between canvassing one neighborhood or 
one town. we made many sacrifices due to lack of money that could've made a 
big difference. if we were able to pay people to work full time, that 
would've made a HUGE difference in disseminating our message in the first 
place. many people digged deep into their pockets to finance this election, 
and i think it's unfair to expect everyone to do it again, especially if we 
can start early to put ourselves at a greater advantage than we were.

Post ID:845
Sender:FBRIGHT123@...
Post Date/Time:2000-11-14 12:37:35
Subject:Re: Targum
Message:

Activists call for basic democratic rights
Commentary 





------------------------------------------------------------------------------

--



Last week’s City Council race in New Brunswick was one of the most-contested 
in recent history. As the national elections are demonstrating immense 
systematic problems in our voting process, our local elections have revealed 
deep-seated corruption and blatant disregard for democracy. The People’s 
Campaign is currently assessing reports from every corner of the city, from 
polling places such as Lord Stirling, Schwartz-Robeson and Lincoln schools, 
among others. We are deeply disturbed by what these reports reveal.

Close to 1,000 people, both Rutgers students and community residents, were 
denied their right to vote in New Brunswick last Tuesday. Our city resembled 
Mississippi circa 1960 as the current city administration used violence, 
terroristic threats, fraud and racial slurs to deny our city any democratic 
electoral process. While hundreds of students were being turned away from the 
polls, voter cards in hand, operatives for the Cahill administration, some of 
whom are city officials, threatened and harassed community activists. Some 
People’s Campaign supporters were insulted with racial slurs, told to “go 
back to your own country,” and in one instance, physically attacked by an aid 
to Mayor Cahill. 

Inside the polls, illegal activity was commonplace: 

• Paid operatives for the Cahill administration openly engaged in partisan 
electioneering inside the polling place.

• Witnesses are reporting that voting machines were tampered with while 
people were told how to vote and illegally required to check in with 
“challengers” working for the incumbents. 

• The City Machine refused to grant provisional ballots to hundreds who had 
registered to vote this year on the grounds that they “couldn’t find” their 
names in the voter rolls. Their votes were effectively suppressed and we 
still have no guarantee that the hundreds of provisional ballots that were 
cast will even be counted.

The People’s Campaign was successful in overcoming external intimidation in 
New Brunswick. We won in the streets and we won on campus. For the first time 
in recent history, the Cahill machine was unable to prevent the organizing 
activity of an opposition ticket. The next step is to overcome internal 
intimidation and fraud and ensure a fair voting process.

We need to continue to struggle for democracy and we will not give up on that 
struggle. We are drafting a Report on Voter Suppression and Electoral Fraud 
in New Brunswick and calling for the establishment of a nonpartisan 
investigation committee. Everything we’ve learned should be used to struggle 
for fair elections in the future. We must demand independent monitors from 
the Board of Elections for all future New Brunswick races. If the board 
refuses, we will go to the United Nations.

To report your experiences on Election Day, whether you were denied the right 
to vote or not, you can reach us at right2votenb@..., or call us at 
732-545-5756. We are fighting, in the tradition of the civil rights movement, 
to overcome entrenched anti-democratic forces. New Brunswick will have 
democracy and the people of this city are fighting for it. Be forewarned, we 
will not rest until this goal is achieved.

Brendan Prawdzik, Rutgers College Governing Association; Audrey Allred, 
Douglass College Government Association; Tom DeGloma, University Senate; Dan 
Van Nostrand, Cook College sophomore and Whitney Rukab, Student Action Union

Post ID:847
Sender:"Matthew Smith" <vivaohio@...>

Subject:Federalist Papers RE: Presidential Elections
Message:

FEDERALIST PAPERS


Federalist No. 68

The Mode of Electing the President
From the New York Packet
Friday, March 14, 1788.

Author: Alexander Hamilton

To the People of the State of New York:

THE mode of appointment of the Chief Magistrate of the United States is 
almost the only part of the system, of any consequence, which has escaped 
without severe censure, or which has received the slightest mark of 
approbation from its opponents. The most plausible of these, who has 
appeared in print, has even deigned to admit that the election of the 
President is pretty well guarded. [1] I venture somewhat further, and 
hesitate not to affirm, that if the manner of it be not perfect, it is at 
least excellent. It unites in an eminent degree all the advantages, the 
union of which was to be wished for.

It was desirable that the sense of the people should operate in the choice 
of the person to whom so important a trust was to be confided. This end will 
be answered by committing the right of making it, not to any preestablished 
body, but to men chosen by the people for the special purpose, and at the 
particular conjuncture.

It was equally desirable, that the immediate election should be made by men 
most capable of analyzing the qualities adapted to the station, and acting 
under circumstances favorable to deliberation, and to a judicious 
combination of all the reasons and inducements which were proper to govern 
their choice. A small number of persons, selected by their fellow-citizens 
from the general mass, will be most likely to possess the information and 
discernment requisite to such complicated investigations.

It was also peculiarly desirable to afford as little opportunity as possible 
to tumult and disorder. This evil was not least to be dreaded in the 
election of a magistrate, who was to have so important an agency in the 
administration of the government as the President of the United States. But 
the precautions which have been so happily concerted in the system under 
consideration, promise an effectual security against this mischief. The 
choice of SEVERAL, to form an intermediate body of electors, will be much 
less apt to convulse the community with any extraordinary or violent 
movements, than the choice of ONE who was himself to be the final object of 
the public wishes. And as the electors, chosen in each State, are to 
assemble and vote in the State in which they are chosen, this detached and 
divided situation will expose them much less to heats and ferments, which 
might be communicated from them to the people, than if they were all to be 
convened at one time, in one place.

Nothing was more to be desired than that every practicable obstacle should 
be opposed to cabal, intrigue, and corruption. These most deadly adversaries 
of republican government might naturally have been expected to make their 
approaches from more than one quarter, but chiefly from the desire in 
foreign powers to gain an improper ascendant in our councils. How could they 
better gratify this, than by raising a creature of their own to the chief 
magistracy of the Union? But the convention have guarded against all danger 
of this sort, with the most provident and judicious attention. They have not 
made the appointment of the President to depend on any preexisting bodies of 
men, who might be tampered with beforehand to prostitute their votes; but 
they have referred it in the first instance to an immediate act of the 
people of America, to be exerted in the choice of persons for the temporary 
and sole purpose of making the appointment. And they have excluded from 
eligibility to this trust, all those who from situation might be suspected 
of too great devotion to the President in office. No senator, 
representative, or other person holding a place of trust or profit under the 
United States, can be of the numbers of the electors. Thus without 
corrupting the body of the people, the immediate agents in the election will 
at least enter upon the task free from any sinister bias. Their transient 
existence, and their detached situation, already taken notice of, afford a 
satisfactory prospect of their continuing so, to the conclusion of it. The 
business of corruption, when it is to embrace so considerable a number of 
men, requires time as well as means. Nor would it be found easy suddenly to 
embark them, dispersed as they would be over thirteen States, in any 
combinations founded upon motives, which though they could not properly be 
denominated corrupt, might yet be of a nature to mislead them from their 
duty.

Another and no less important desideratum was, that the Executive should be 
independent for his continuance in office on all but the people themselves. 
He might otherwise be tempted to sacrifice his duty to his complaisance for 
those whose favor was necessary to the duration of his official consequence. 
This advantage will also be secured, by making his re-election to depend on 
a special body of representatives, deputed by the society for the single 
purpose of making the important choice.

All these advantages will happily combine in the plan devised by the 
convention; which is, that the people of each State shall choose a number of 
persons as electors, equal to the number of senators and representatives of 
such State in the national government, who shall assemble within the State, 
and vote for some fit person as President. Their votes, thus given, are to 
be transmitted to the seat of the national government, and the person who 
may happen to have a majority of the whole number of votes will be the 
President. But as a majority of the votes might not always happen to centre 
in one man, and as it might be unsafe to permit less than a majority to be 
conclusive, it is provided that, in such a contingency, the House of 
Representatives shall select out of the candidates who shall have the five 
highest number of votes, the man who in their opinion may be best qualified 
for the office.

The process of election affords a moral certainty, that the office of 
President will never fall to the lot of any man who is not in an eminent 
degree endowed with the requisite qualifications. Talents for low intrigue, 
and the little arts of popularity, may alone suffice to elevate a man to the 
first honors in a single State; but it will require other talents, and a 
different kind of merit, to establish him in the esteem and confidence of 
the whole Union, or of so considerable a portion of it as would be necessary 
to make him a successful candidate for the distinguished office of President 
of the United States. It will not be too strong to say, that there will be a 
constant probability of seeing the station filled by characters pre-eminent 
for ability and virtue. And this will be thought no inconsiderable 
recommendation of the Constitution, by those who are able to estimate the 
share which the executive in every government must necessarily have in its 
good or ill administration. Though we cannot acquiesce in the political 
heresy of the poet who says: ``For forms of government let fools contest 
That which is best administered is best,'' yet we may safely pronounce, that 
the true test of a good government is its aptitude and tendency to produce a 
good administration.

The Vice-President is to be chosen in the same manner with the President; 
with this difference, that the Senate is to do, in respect to the former, 
what is to be done by the House of Representatives, in respect to the 
latter.

The appointment of an extraordinary person, as Vice-President, has been 
objected to as superfluous, if not mischievous. It has been alleged, that it 
would have been preferable to have authorized the Senate to elect out of 
their own body an officer answering that description. But two considerations 
seem to justify the ideas of the convention in this respect. One is, that to 
secure at all times the possibility of a definite resolution of the body, it 
is necessary that the President should have only a casting vote. And to take 
the senator of any State from his seat as senator, to place him in that of 
President of the Senate, would be to exchange, in regard to the State from 
which he came, a constant for a contingent vote. The other consideration is, 
that as the Vice-President may occasionally become a substitute for the 
President, in the supreme executive magistracy, all the reasons which 
recommend the mode of election prescribed for the one, apply with great if 
not with equal force to the manner of appointing the other. It is remarkable 
that in this, as in most other instances, the objection which is made would 
lie against the constitution of this State. We have a Lieutenant-Governor, 
chosen by the people at large, who presides in the Senate, and is the 
constitutional substitute for the Governor, in casualties similar to those 
which would authorize the Vice-President to exercise the authorities and 
discharge the duties of the President.

PUBLIUS.

President Hastert? President Thurmond? It Could Happen...

By CURT ANDERSON
.c The Associated Press
  
WASHINGTON  - Should a legal battle drag on for weeks between Al Gore and 
George W. Bush over the presidential election results, Americans could wake 
up in late January with a man named J. Dennis Hastert in the Oval Office. 

Hastert, a 14-year member of Congress from Illinois, is the Republican 
speaker of the House of Representatives. Under the Constitution, in certain 
circumstances when the president and vice president cannot take office by the 
Jan. 20 inauguration date, the House speaker takes the reins of power for the 
time being. 

Taking it a step further, if there is no speaker, or that person doesn't meet 
requirements to be president, the temporary White House occupant would be the 
president pro tempore of the Senate. That person is 97-year-old Sen. Strom 
Thurmond of South Carolina. 

Thurmond won 39 electoral votes in a 1948 run for the presidency as a "States 
Rights Democrat.'' 

But the duty, unprecedented in the nation's history, most likely would fall 
to Hastert, a former high school teacher and wrestling coach who took over as 
speaker in 1998 for conservative firebrand Newt Gingrich and has tried to 
steer a less confrontational course for the GOP congressional majority. 

"The House speaker would assume the position of acting president,'' said 
Jonathan Turley, a constitutional law professor at George Washington 
University. "He would assume the position until any controversy is 
resolved.'' 

Hastert also would have to resign from the House, forcing the majority 
Republicans to choose a new speaker for the incoming 107th Congress and 
requiring a special election for the open 14th District seat in Illinois. 

"This is a remarkably bitter prospect for any House speaker in exchange for 
being a historical footnote,'' Turley said. "He would have to decapitate his 
political career.'' 

Still, Republicans could dodge that possibility by choosing someone else as 
speaker and letting that person resign to become temporary president. And 
nothing would prevent Hastert from running again for his Illinois seat once 
the Gore-Bush race is finished. 

The Constitution makes the speaker of the House third in the line of 
succession if both the president and vice president are unable to serve. 
Under the 20th Amendment - the one that limits presidents to a pair of 
four-year terms - the terms of President Clinton and Vice President Gore will 
end at noon on Jan. 20, when presumably the new team would be sworn in. 

The amendment says that if the new president and vice president aren't yet 
"qualified'' for their offices - a long legal challenge could delay the 
Electoral College from the final act of the 2000 election, naming the 
president - the law should dictate who should temporarily take over. Federal 
law identifies that person as the speaker, after he has quit the House. 

A separate provision would have the presidential election decided by the 
House of Representatives, with the Senate choosing the vice president. But 
that would happen only if neither Bush nor Gore got the required 270 
electoral votes. Florida would put either man over the top.

Post ID:850
Sender:jagross@...
Post Date/Time:2000-11-14 17:43:14
Subject:Re: President
Message:

--- In nbpeoplescampaign@egroups.com, Louise Ammentorp <lknesta@i...> 
wrote:

> The slogan of revolutionary democracy should be
> "Abolish the electorial college, let the popular vote decide!"

I'm still an agnostic on this question.  Here's why.  I'm not 100% 
certain that deemphasizing the state-by-state electoral vote system in 
favor of 'letting the popular vote decide' will be empowering to those 
places where the least politically powerful live.  To put it simply, 
is this strategically good for the political interests of the rural 
poor and the urban poor alike?  

Let's say you have state A and state B, and both traditionally go to 
the Democrats because of their large urban minority population, 
combined with, say, a large number of traditionally Democratic groups 
living in the suburbs (Catholics and Jews, for example).  This might 
roughly describe NY and NJ; I'm not thinking too hard here, though, so 
let's just keep it hypothetical.  The Republicans won't really even 
bother with these two states, usually, because the urban votes and 
some of the suburban votes will outweigh the more conservative 
suburban and rural voters by, maybe, 10%.  

Switch to direct election and you get this:  the Republicans will 
suddenly campaign vigorously to get the conservative votes from those 
two states, and be able to combine those votes to make them count 
nationally in a way they never could before.

This is just a (not that great) hypothetical.  But you get my point.  
There's just as much possibility for a swing in favor of the 
Republicans as there is in favor of the Democrats.    

> I think that this crisis in bourgeois democracy provides us a great
> opportunity to advance direct democracy.  A poll published in todays
> papers cited 80% of the population is oppossed to the electorial
> college. Agitation, Education, and organization around this call 
> could be very effective.

Well, first, 'direct democracy' in the sense of eliminating mediating 
factors between the individual voter and Congress, the President, etc, 
isn't necessarily a great thing.  It's definitely an excessive 
exaggeration to call it 'revolutionary'.   

Here's how I'd look at it.  Progressive reforms, in the traditional 
sense of the term 'Progressive', have always been quite 
well-intentioned in terms of advancing democratic empowerment.  But 
they tend to reduce politics to the rational choice of the individual, 
solitary voter.  The means is seemingly very democratic, but the end 
can _become_ bourgeois-liberal, as you'd say, in the worst sort of 
way.  Think of the primary system: it's arguably become a disaster.
I'm not saying that Progressive reforms are uniformly 'bad', I'm just 
identifying a problem or a tension that has to be taken seriously.

As a secondary matter, perhaps you should be 'taking up the banner' 
of rank-choice ('Individual Runoff Voting') voting rather than 
worrying so much about the electoral college.  It's my understanding 
that this may actually be workable under the Constitution, whereas the 
abolition of the EC would require an amendment.  It's an uncommonly 
good idea, I think.  You vote for your first choice, second choice, 
and so on.  You can make, in short, Gore your second choice and Nader 
your first; if nobody gets a majority of the votes, the second choices 
are factored in.  In this way, Gore would've won.

TTYL.

>
>Sarasota Herald-Tribune 11/11/2000
>http://www.newscoast.com/headlinesstory2.cfm?ID=35115
>  Author links Bush family to Nazis
>STAFF REPORT
>
>The president of the Florida Holocaust Museum said Saturday that George W.
>Bush's grandfather derived a portion of his personal fortune through his
>affiliation with a Nazi-controlled bank.
>
>John Loftus, a former prosecutor in the Justice Department's Nazi War 
>Crimes
>Unit, said his research found that Bush's grandfather, Prescott Bush, was a
>principal in the Union Banking Corp. in Manhattan in the late 1930s and the
>1940s.
>
>Leading Nazi industrialists secretly owned the bank at that time, Loftus
>said, and were moving money into it through a second bank in Holland even
>after the United States declared war on Germany. The bank was liquidated in
>1951, Loftus said, and Bush's grandfather and great-grandfather received 
>$1.5
>million from the bank as part of that dissolution.
>
>"That's where the Bush family fortune came from: It came from the Third
>Reich," Loftus said.
>
>Loftus made his remarks during a speech as part of the Sarasota Reading
>Festival. The author of "Unholy Trinity: The Vatican, The Nazis and the 
>Swiss
>Banks," Loftus documented the Swiss bank accounts that harbored funds
>confiscated from Holocaust victims and the participation of Italian priests
>in smuggling Nazi war criminals to safe haven in Canada, Central and South
>America and the United States after the war.
>
>Although he said he had a file of paperwork linking the bank and Prescott
>Bush to Nazi money, Loftus did not provide that documentation Saturday.
>
>Loftus pointed out that the Bush family would not be the only American
>political dynasty to have ties to the "wrong side of World War II." The
>Rockefellers had financial connections to Nazi Germany, he said.
>
>Loftus also reminded his audience that John F. Kennedy's father, an avowed
>isolationist and former ambassador to Great Britain, profited during the
>1930s and '40s from Nazi stocks that he owned.
>
>"No one today blames the Democrats because Jack Kennedy's father bought 
>Nazi
>stocks," Loftus said. Still, he said, it is important to understand these
>historical connections for what they tell us about politics today. The 
>World
>War II experience points out how easy it was then -- and remains today -- 
>to
>hide money in multinational funds.
>
>That money flows into American politics today, he said, from "a series of
>multinational corporations behaving like pirates. They don't care about
>ideology; they care about money."
>
>Loftus' speech left many in tears.
>
>"I am absolutely shocked," said Nancy Krauss of Punta Gorda. "I wish this
>would have come out before the election. My husband voted for Bush. I don't
>think he would have voted for him if he would have known."
>
>

A Call to Arms across Middlesex County. . . 

Business and community leaders will meet to bring
accountable government back to Middlesex County 


Nov, 27, 2000 at 6:30 PM, East Brunswick Library


NEW BRUNSWICK, NJ -- Hardly a day goes by that some
credible individual or organization does not report on
the reckless disregard and wasteful spending of the
Middlesex County government. Having personal knowledge
of the corruption and collusion behind the Roosevelt
Care Center privatization fiasco, we are deeply
concerned that a band of incompetent and irresponsible
persons under the guise of government leadership can
operate arrogantly and defiantly -- not as proper
government representatives -- rather using the power
of government office in protection of their
self-interests. As an agent of the Federal government
once advised, Federal agents can not arrest County
officials for obvious stupidity. Perhaps not. However,
as taxpayers, we do have an absolute right to expect
responsible government accountable to its people. 

Everyone -- yes, its time to admit it, everyone -- in
the state of NJ is well aware of this County's
political stronghold. And it exercises improper and
undue influence on persons, media and businesses that
paralyzes constituents with fear, forever demanding
their loyalty, if they are to retain the County
government's favor, tax breaks, jobs, revenue or
contracts that the freeholders have selectively
awarded them. 

Enough. Middlesex County government is an atrocity and
begs to be brought down with accountability. It needs
to be investigated, its books audited, its conflicts
of interests exposed and a light of truth shined
behind its closed doors. We must undercover its
well-kept secrets that enriches its special interests
and impoverishes the rights and needs of every County
man, woman and child who has the audacity not to
contribute to the freeholders' Democratic Party
campaigns. 

We are asking -- indeed, we are expecting -- we are
believing -- that all companies and all persons who
have serious and valid concerns with the Middlesex
County Freeholders or Improvement Authority
commissioners will come together on November 27,
6:30PM at the East Brunswick Library and discuss
strategies on how we will legally hold these so-called
government leaders professionally and personally
accountable for their egregious acts. This "Call to
Arms" -- formidable representatives of business and
community interests -- will join hands and their
commitment to rid themselves of bad government. By
finally speaking out in protection of the common good,
we will symbolically empower people to stop sheepishly
dismissing what we have long known the County
government capable of doing. Bad government in
Middlesex County is no longer a laughing matter beyond
the taxpayers' ability to control. We can and will
restore good government to Middlesex County. 

All businesses or individuals committed to joining the
Middlesex County Call to Arms initiative, please
contact:
Patricia Nelson at Glendas House, An Affiliate of the
Association for Protection of the Elderly, Inc., PO
Box 7574, Princeton, NJ, 08543-7574
732-545-0304; Fax: 732-545-2519; e-Mail:
GlendasHouse@bigplanet.com.

Post ID:858
Sender:"Zofia Nowakowski" <znowakowski@...>
Post Date/Time:2000-11-16 15:16:04
Subject:Model study: Contingent work as a cause of ethnoracial polarization of income in Toronto
Message:

From: 	Alice deWolff <alicedew@...>
To:	NYC7.GWIA("contingent-org@igc.topica.com","alicede...
Date: 	Thu, Nov 16, 2000  8:42 AM
Subject: 	[contingent-org] Toronto Study of Contingent Workers

*************************************************
This message sent via the contingent-org listserv
*************************************************

Toronto Organizing for Fair Employment (TOFFE) released this study yesterday. 
********

Breaking the Myths of Flexible Work 


A Study Conducted by the Contingent Workers Project 

Report Prepared by Alice de Wolff 



The realities facing Toronto workers in the "new global economy" are laid bare in this startling new study by the Contingent Workers Project. 

Breaking the Myths of Flexible Work provides a timely picture of the concerns of temporary, contract, part time and self employed workers across all occupations and industries. Approximately half the country*s workers are in non-permanent jobs. Sixty percent of the new "jobs" created in the last decade were contract self employment. In Toronto, many of the city*s newer immigrants are channeled into temporary work or low waged contracting, and this appears to be central to the ethno-racial polarization of income in the city. 

Breaking the Myths involved over 200 contingent workers. Flexible jobs are not meeting the needs of workers who participated in the study. A large proportion of contingent work is low waged, These workers have to carry more costs than people in permanent jobs. Most study participants did not receive sick leave, vacations, insurance, training or pensions from their employers. These workers, among the lowest income earners in the city, are taking the brunt of government and employer actions to "download" costs. Because they do not have full time jobs, many are not eligible for Employment Insurance and are not covered by Workers Safety Insurance. They are more likely to be hurt on the job; and the impact of irregular scheduling on workers* stress, health and caring responsibilities is significant. The study participants needed good information about their rights as workers, but more importantly, they wanted full time permanent work and collective action to promote fair working conditions.

For more information contact:


Deena Ladd, Toronto Organizing For Fair Employment (TOFFE), 416-531-0778

or 

Alice de Wolff, email alicedew@idirect.com

or

Download the Report from www.actew.web.net

WASHINGTON, DC--Denouncing the American electoral process as "immoral and 
corrupt," President Clinton announced Tuesday that he will not step down on 
Jan. 20, 2001, declaring himself "President For Life."

Proclaiming Nov. 14 a new national holiday as "Day One of Americlintonian 
Year Zero," Clinton issued a directive of total martial law over "all 
territories formerly known as these United States, from now on to be called 
the Holy United Imperial Americlintonian Demopublic (HUIAD)." He added that 
all election results are "hereby invalidated under Demopublican provisional 
law."

"The American people have spoken," Clinton said. "By failing to generate a 
51 percent majority for either candidate, they have shown their inability 
to muster the drive to collective action. The time has come for a new 
America, a strong Americlintonian Empire, capable of providing the 
indecisive electorate with direction through one man's sheer force of will."

Dressed in full military regalia and flanked by members of his elite 
Demopublican Guard, Clinton told reporters, "Let all peoples of the land 
know this: The era of bipartisan inaction and paralysis has ended. The Age 
of the Great Cleansing Fire begins today."

A significant portion of the U.S. Armed Forces has sworn loyalty to the 
Imperial Demopublic Council of Generals, the new military wing of the 
Clinton regime. But despite such support, many political observers question 
the constitutionality of Clinton's actions, which include the burning of 
the Constitution, the dissolution of Congress, and the establishment of 
"re-education camps" in suburban D.C.

At a sparsely attended press conference, U.S. Attorney General Janet Reno 
raised the prospect of a Justice Department investigation of "possible 
illegal activities" on the part of Clinton. Most observers, however, 
believe that such a probe is unlikely: Less than an hour after Reno spoke, 
her battered and broken body was publicly fed to Clinton's dogs.

"Let them bring their pitiful reprisals to the impotent courts. Their 
lawyers and lawsuits shall face the wrath of a people united by the 
almighty fist," said Clinton, whose divinity as HUIAD's first Emperor-God 
was ratified late Tuesday night by the Americlintonic High Priest Council. 
"Let them recount their puny, paper ballots. They shall wither, as will the 
bankers, lawyers, and lobbyists all, before the Holy Cause of 
Americlintonia's glorious, righteous might."

Defiant in the face of objections from the Bush and Gore camps, Clinton has 
consolidated his power over the last several days, ordering armed takeovers 
of major federal buildings and the systematic collection and display of his 
enemies' heads on iron pikes.

In a test of the new regime's power outside the nation's capital, 
Senator-Elect Hillary Clinton, rechristened "Bride of The Lord Clinton On 
Earth," summarily ordered HUIAD troops to fire on Manhattan crowds, leaving 
more than 2,500 dead on Wall Street and quickly dispersing protesters loyal 
to defeated Republican challenger Rick Lazio.

Resistance movements are already forming. The new Legion Of Californians 
has sworn to defeat HUIAD in the west, and anti-Clinton groups have been 
reported across the U.S., including Naderist factions in Washington State 
and Maine.

Clinton has publicly dismissed such insurrections as "pathetic," confident 
that nothing will stem his authority over "the former U.S."

"The rebels are but mewling kittens who shall taste blood instead of milk," 
said Clinton, threatening to deploy HUAID-controlled nuclear weapons 
against members of resistance movements. "The holy power of the atom shall, 
if it must, cleanse this nation of all infidels."

Subject:News Flash #2 - Important

BELGRADE--Serbian president Vojislav Kostunica deployed more than 30,000 
peacekeeping troops to the U.S. Monday, pledging full support to the 
troubled North American nation as it struggles to establish democracy.

"We must do all we can to support free elections in America and allow 
democracy to gain a foothold there," Kostunica said. "The U.S. is a major 
player in the Western Hemisphere and its continued stability is vital to 
Serbian interests in that region."

Kostunica urged Al Gore, the U.S. opposition-party leader who is refusing 
to recognize the nation's Nov. 7 election results, to "let the democratic 
process take its course."

"Mr. Gore needs to acknowledge the will of the people and concede that he 
has lost this election," Kostunica said. "Until America's political figures 
learn to respect the institutions that have been put in place, the nation 
will never be a true democracy."

Serbian forces have been stationed throughout the U.S., with an emphasis on 
certain trouble zones. Among them are Oregon, Florida, and eastern 
Tennessee, where Gore set up headquarters in Bush territory. An additional 
10,000 troops are expected to arrive in the capital city of Washington, 
D.C. by Friday.

Though Kostunica has pledged to work with U.S. leaders, he did not rule out 
the possibility of economic sanctions if the crisis is not resolved soon.

"For democracy to take root and flourish, it must be planted in the rich 
soil of liberty. And the cornerstone of liberty is elections free of 
tampering or corruption," Kostunica said. "Should America prove itself 
incapable of learning this lesson on its own, the international community 
may be forced to take stronger measures."

                   America, where millions feel vindicated after many

                   According to Gabriel Guerra Castellanos, another Mexican 
columnist,
                   "the entire world is laughing" at the United States and 
the crisis would be
                   funny if it wasn�t happening in the world�s most powerful 
country.

                   Neri da Silveira, president of the Brazilian electoral 
board, acting as an
                   observer at the U.S. elections, said that the U.S. 
electoral system is
                   "archaic and defective" and allows for fraud. "What 
struck me most was
                   the variety of voting and vote counting practices among 
the states. They
                   still use traditional ballot boxes and other obsolete 
equipment. Their
                   electronic ballot box is the size of a refrigerator."

                   Many have recalled the old refrain about "the only 
country on the
                   continent that has never had a military coup..." and now 
they are adding
                   the question: "Why doesn�t Washington have a U.S. 
embassy?"

                   There has been no lack of jokes about Latin American 
politicians with
                   questionable electoral ethics who have supposedly visited 
Miami to
                   advise its governor, Jeb Bush, brother of the Republican 
candidate.

                   "We Latin Americans would be delighted if an OAS 
delegation were to
                   arrive in the capital of Florida to supervise�naturally 
while trying to
                   keep straight faces�the revision of the U.S. electoral 
procedures,"
                   wrote Ra�l Gangotena in Quito�s El Comercio.

                   According to Panama�s El Universal, if what is currently 
happening in
                   the United States were to happen anywhere else in the 
world, "they
                   would have already set up a commission of observers 
making
                   declarations, sniffing out the vaguest shadow of possible

                   demanding precision, a recount of the votes and

                   1989 to arrest General Manuel A. Noriega.
